PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate their extreme concern at the proposal to charge entry fees for people needing nursing home care. Furthermore, the petitioners are extremely concerned that the charging of up front entry fees will force people to sell their homes in order to gain a nursing home bed.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that access to nursing home care is available on the basis of need and further that the family home is exempt from any asset test used to determine eligibility for such care.

PETITION.TITLE: Mobile Phone Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives their extreme concern at the proposal for a mobile phone base station to be erected on top of the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club building. Furthermore, the petitioners are concerned that with the proposed installation of 12 antennae and 4 microwave dishes within the Ettalong Beach commercial, retail, residential, school, recreational and leisure district, the health and welfare of countless people within the 300 metre danger zone will be adversely affected.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure the installation of a mobile phone base does not proceed within 300 metres of any residential, school, commercial, retail, recreational or leisure area in Ettalong Beach.

PETITION.TITLE: Mobile Phone Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that certain citizens of the Central Coast of New South Wales draw to the attention of the Senate their objection to the proposal to erect a mobile phone base station on top of the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club building. Your petitioners are particularly concerned that position of the base station is within 300 metres of the Ettalong Public School and could potentially constitute a health risk.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that a carrier must not construct a mobile phone base station within 300 metres of a child care centre, kindergarten, school or hospital.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Health
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of Senate that the Federal Government wants to direct funding away from services aimed at women's health.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate ensures that funding is directly spent on providing vital health services for women. In addition we request that funding is directed to women's health centres so that women can continue to seek medical advice from places that cater specifically for their needs.

PETITION.TITLE: Paper
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned that 14 overseas countries are allegedly dumping paper into the Australian market putting at risk up to 1,000 Coastal jobs and the loss of tens of millions of dollars to the local North West economy.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate do everything in its power to stop this paper dumping and protect the jobs of 1,000 Tasmanians from unfair foreign competitors.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: Meat Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned with the impost of new AQIS meat inspection fees and charges and their affect on abattoirs in North West Tasmania.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate support Tasmania's meat industry by rejecting the new AQIS meat inspection fees and charges.

PETITION.TITLE: Means Test Exemption
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned with the measures which remove the means test exemption of superannuation and rollover assets from the social security and veterans affairs means test for people over 55 but below pension age. These measures would see 67,000 people lose part or all of their income support benefit.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support the thousands of hard working Australians who already face uncertainty, ongoing retrenchments and great difficulty in finding a secure job by rejecting the Coalition Government's measures to remove the means test exemption for superannuation and rollover assets for over 55's.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 27th report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing entitled Transfer of responsibility for the administration of senators' travelling allowances .

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate adopt the committee's recommendation and agree to the transfer of responsibility for the administration of senators' travelling allowances from the Department of the Senate to the Department of Administrative Services.

I will not speak very long to this. I think it was the view of the opposition very early on that travel allowance should be centralised in one department and not cut across two. This view has generally been supported both by the government and opposition. Senator Bourne, however, has put in a dissenting report. I regard most of that dissenting report as irrelevant to this decision, although not irrelevant to the decision making of government. I think some of the issues Senator Bourne has raised in that report, which has also been raised by Senate officers, will be pursued in the estimates process both in regard to the Senate and DAS.

What we in the opposition are responding to is a government decision, not the Baxter report. I want to make that absolutely clear. If the Baxter report is flawed, we will be looking at the flaws and the amount of expenditure that has been paid. However, we take the view based on two factors for the centralisation of TA. First, it is easier in our view to cross‐reference all this material in one department, and the very departmental jealousies we have seen that were involved in the reception of the Baxter report will not come into play.

Even more so, we would much rather make the Department of Administrative Services accountable than the Department of the Senate. It is a very simple process. We do not like to get into an adversarial position with Senate officers, the clerks, the President and the department as a whole. It is a much more friendly relationship that senators have with their own department than they necessarily would have with DAS.

Some people might even suggest that a poisoned chalice is going across to DAS. I am not sure that is particularly right. They understand that, by taking it over, they will be subject to a fairly rigorous examination process. Whilst I have a lot of sympathy with the general points made by Senator Bourne, I do not agree with the basic principle.

Finally, I do not think you do get better scrutiny across two departments. You get better scrutiny in one department provided we, as senators, the Auditor-General and everyone else puts proper scrutiny on that department. I cannot accept the conclusion, even though I can accept the thrust of what Senator Bourne has said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ray for being so measured and polite in his response to my dissenting report. My dissenting report is based on a couple of things. I would like to see the Baxter report for a start. I have not seen it; no-one in the Democrats has seen it. I understood that the proposal to transfer administration rested on the Baxter report, but I do not know that for sure because I have not seen it and I have not been given a copy. I would not know what was in it except for the information that has been tabled in estimates, which I have also attached to this dissenting report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of problems with changing everything into the one department. I do take the point that it is easier if it is all in the one department, but it has been in two departments and it is not the Department of the Senate that has caused any problems. I do not even think it is DAS that has caused problems; it is circumstances that has caused problems. I would like to see cross‐checking. I think cross‐checking is more effective and easier when it is in the two departments. I think that is an important point. I recommend that all senators read the dissenting report and the document that was tabled in estimates. I hope that that will prove to be useful for future estimates.

The last point I feel I have to make is that I believe every single person on the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing—and probably pretty well everybody in the Senate—wants to make sure that this is done properly; that that is the outcome of any changes or of keeping it the same; that there is very strict scrutiny of what happens here. Absolutely none of us wants to take money that we are not entitled to. The end result is just stupidity.

I do not think there is anybody who would want to do that, certainly not on the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. We are all absolutely sure that what we want is a fair and reasonable system where we only get what we are entitled to and where mistakes cannot be made. It is far more difficult to make mistakes and do anything, even inadvertently, that would go against the system.

I still believe that what I said in the dissenting report is correct. I still believe it should be kept in the two departments and cross-checked. I will be voting that way, but I understand, as I did in the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, that the numbers are well and truly against us here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposal before the chair. The opposition has made very clear that any proposals in relation to the administration of the parliamentary entitlements need to meet certain criteria. The sorts of criteria that are of concern to the opposition, which I have outlined previously, are those of transparency, accountability, equity, workability and independent arbitration. I hope that those criteria have been uppermost in the government's mind as it reviews the parliamentary entitlements system.

SPEECH.PARA: The key issue before the chamber at the moment via the vehicle of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing is that of centralisation of entitlements in DAS. This has the support of the opposition. Very early in this debate I think the opposi tion was the first political party in this country to argue that case.

We have a situation where currently salaries, electorate and travelling allowances and some other minor entitlements for senators and members of the House of Representatives are administered by the parliamentary departments—the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate respectively. All the other entitlements that go to postage, telephones, stationery and papers are administered by DAS. DAS han dles ministerial salaries and travelling allowance and entitlements for ministers and entitlements for other office holders.

We say that this creates unnecessary confusion and duplication of effort. We believe that—to avoid that confusion and duplication, to ensure that there is transparency and accountability and, I hope, for many of the reasons that Senator Ray indicated, to improve transparency and accountability of the system of administration of all salaries, allowances and entitlements—the centralisation in one department, in this case the Department of Administrative Services, will lead to that more desirable outcome. That improvement is what many in this parliament and, I am very confident, many outside this parliament are looking for.

I, too, accept the spirit of what Senator Bourne has said, and I appreciate where she is coming from. I suspect that her objectives in this are no different from those that I have expressed. The issues of accountability and transparency and the issue I have raised in relation to workability are all very important ones that I hope would be shared by the vast majority in this chamber and in this parliament.
That is why the opposition proposes to support the 27th report of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee. I commend the question before the Senate to senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the major issues to keep an eye on—and I have listened carefully to what Senator Bourne, Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner have said—is that the changes are not ones that subject these issues to more rather than less politicisation; and it is possible. It is important we make sure that, if what is now a centralisation comes to be under the control of a minister, it is not the case that it becomes a political argument rather than a careful scrutiny. I think we will all be watching carefully to see what happens as the outcome of these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I present a paper entitled Scrutiny by the committee of regulations providing for the leasing of Commonwealth airports which was presented to the sixth Australian and Pacific Conference of Delegated Legislation and the Scrutiny of Bills, in Adelaide in July 1997. I seek leave to have the paper incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The paper read as follows—
Sixth Australian and Pacific Conference on Delegated Legislation and the Scrutiny of Bills
Adelaide, 16‐18 July 1997
Scrutiny by the Committee of regulations providing for the leasing of Commonwealth airports

On 7 May 1997 the government announced the successful bidders for the long term leases of Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports. The announcement advised that the leases would maximise efficient airport operations and facilitate future airport developments on a commercial basis. Total consideration for the leases was $3.34 billion, with Brisbane airport bringing $1.39 billion, Melbourne $1.31 billion and Perth $640 million.

The government announcement further advised that, while sales proceeds were an important element in the sale, the evaluation methodology took into consideration a whole range of other criteria. For instance, the successful bidders were all high quality, committed operators with international experience, who would bring world best practice to the management and operation of these airports. Also, the private leases would introduce a level of innovation and competitiveness otherwise difficult to achieve within the previous management system. All the successful bidders had agreed to comply with the government's post privatisation pricing regime, which would result in substantial real reductions in aeronautical charges over the next five years.

The result of this process was so successful that on 12 June 1997 the government announced that it was offering a further fifteen Federal airports for simultaneous trade sale, including Adelaide, Hobart, Darwin and Canberra.

All this appears a satisfactory outcome of a process which commenced under the previous Federal government and which is now being completed under the present one. What may not be well known, however, is that the whole basis of the operation of leased airports was established largely by regulations. Indeed, the actual choice of Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports as the first to be privatised was prescribed by regulation. The broad framework of the scheme was provided for by the Airports Act 1996 , the second reading speech for which advised that regulations would play an important part in the final supervisory framework. A quantitative indication of this importance is that the original Airports Act includes 236 references to "regulations" or to "prescribe", which in the context of Commonwealth legislative drafting means to make regulations. In addition, earlier this year an amendment of the Airports Act included fifty‐five more references to "regulations". A more general indication of their importance is that the Minister circulated drafts of the regulations for information and comment, which is not usual Commonwealth practice.

The administrative scheme of the Airports Act was in fact implemented through no fewer than six different principal regulations, due to the amount of detail to be included in the regulatory regime. The Appendix to this paper sets out the full citations of these regulations. The first set of regulations, the Airports (Building Control) Regulations, provided for the approval and supervision of building works at leased airports. The Airports (Protection of Airspace) Regulations established a system to provide for the safety and efficiency of air transport around leased airports. The Airports (Ownership‐Interest in Shares) Regulations provided for increased Australian investment in leased airports by establishing a system of exemptions for the foreign ownership provisions of the Act. The Airports Regulations, which were the key regulations, actually prescribed that Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports would be leased and provided for their leasing and management, for land use and planning, and for accounts and reports of airport‐operator companies. The Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations, which were the longest regulations, provided for environmental strategies, duties of operators of undertakings at airports, monitoring and remedial action, and enforcement. Finally, the Airports (Control of On‐Airport Activities) Regulations provided for the control of commercial activities and vehicles at leased airports, including the control of liquor, gambling and smoking.

The Committee scrutinised all these regulations with the assistance of its independent legal adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan AM, to ensure that they complied with its high standards of personal rights and parliamentary propriety. The Committee detected a number of apparent deficiencies in four of the six sets of regulations and, as it does in these cases, wrote to the Minister seeking an explanation. I will now describe what the Committee regarded as deficiencies and the response of the Minister to the Committee's concerns.

One of the most important aspects of the work of the Committee is to ensure that legislative instruments are legally valid. Every year the Committee scrutinises legislation which is invalid for a number of reasons. In the case of the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations the Committee questioned a provision which authorised the use of environmental testing methods approved by the United States Environment Protection Agency or by two other United States bodies. The Committee was concerned because s.49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that legislative instruments may incorporate or adopt material, apart from Acts and regulations, only as in existence at a particular time, not as in existence from time to time. The reason for this provision is that incorporation of material which might be changed without the approval or even knowledge of Parliament would effectively delegate legislative power, a process which would be most undesirable. The Committee noted that, in contrast, four other provisions of the Regulations expressly incorporated Australian material, from both government and non‐government bodies, that was in force at a particular date or at the date of commencement of the Regulations. In the case of the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations the Minister agreed to meet our concern about validity and the Airports Act was amended to provide legal authority for the incorporation.

Another aspect of the Committee's work which is of crucial importance is the protection of personal rights, which the Committee interprets in a very broad fashion. Every year the Committee detects many provisions which appear to breach personal rights and raises these with the relevant Minister. The Committee was concerned at the following aspects of personal rights relating to the different regulations providing for the leasing of airports.

The Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations provide that airport lessee companies have the right of entry to a sub‐lessee's premises and of access to any document under the control of the sub‐lessee, with penalties for non‐compliance. The Committee noted that these are very wide powers, which even the police do not have without a warrant. Also, the entry provisions did not include the usual safeguard under which those entering must produce photographic identity passes. As well, the people given power to enter did not appear to be employees of the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency and therefore may not be subject to the safeguards provided under, for instance, legislation relating to privacy or the Ombudsman. The Minister advised the Committee that the airport lessee company needed these powers to monitor environmental impacts and that entry must be at a reasonable time and after notice in writing. However, the Committee's concerns would be referred to the Attorney‐General's Department for advice. Also, while some powers of entry would be exercised by a private entity, related powers to enter to perform remedial work would be exercised by a statutory office holder, who would be subject to the usual safeguards including privacy and the Ombudsman.

The Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations also provide for a system of penalties imposed by infringement notices. The Committee does not object to such provisions, which may be appropriate in the circumstances. In this case, however, the provisions did not include the usual and necessary safeguard that infringement notices should advise that, if the fine is paid, then payment not only discharges the liability and prevents any prosecution for the matter, but also the person affected is not to be regarded as having been convicted of an offence. The Minister advised the Committee that the Regulations would be amended to provide for this advice.

The final concern about personal rights which the Committee had in respect of the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations was a provision that notices or directives from a government official to a member of the public could be given by a number of methods, including by pre‐paid post. The Regulations, however, did not extend this concession to notices given to officials by the public, who were required to deliver notices to an office during business hours. The Minister advised the Committee that the Regulations would be amended.

The Airports (Control of On‐Airport Activities) Regulations also included provisions which may have affected personal rights. Four provisions in those Regulations included the appropriate safeguard that action which would affect a person adversely could be taken only if reasonable. One provision, for instance, provided that a vehicle may be removed if the driver cannot be found within a reasonable time after reasonable inquiries. Two other provisions, however, did not include this reasonability safeguard although it may have been appropriate to do so. In this instance, however, the Minister persuaded the Committee that reasonability provisions were not necessary in these two cases.

The Airports (Building Control) Regulations included the appropriate safeguard that if the building controller does not make a decision on a building application within twenty‐eight days then he or she is deemed to have rejected the application. In three other similar cases, however, there was no such effective time limit. These related to variations of approvals, certificates of fitness and variation of certificates of fitness, all of which could have important commercial consequences. The Minister advised the Committee that the Regulations would be amended.

The Airports Regulations provided that if an airport lease is terminated then the Minister may direct that the Commonwealth or a nominee of the Minister be substituted for the former lessee. The Committee advised the Minister that this appeared reasonable, but questioned a further provision that the substituted nominee would not be liable for any existing liabilities. The Committee asked whether this would prejudice the creditors of the terminated airport lessee company. The Minister assured the Committee that the provision would not affect the rights of creditors or their legal options in relation to any obligations owed to them.

Another aspect of the Committee's work is to ensure that legislative instruments provide for appropriate merits review of administrative decisions. At the Commonwealth level it is broadly accepted policy that persons who are adversely affected by the exercise of an administrative discretion should be able to have the merits of that decision reviewed by an independent external body, which would usually be the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This general principle is a safeguard subject to only a few limited exceptions. In the case of the regulations providing for the leasing of airports each of the four sets of regulations about which the Committee was concerned in respect of validity and personal rights also did not appear to provide in all cases for administrative review.

The Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations provided for environment testing by accredited laboratories, but did not appear to provide for review for a laboratory refused accreditation. Also, although some decisions made under the Regulations were subject to full AAT review, numbers were subject only to internal review by the Secretary. The Committee suggested that it may be suitable to provide for ultimate AAT review, even if preliminary review by the Secretary was appropriate. Some other discretions, including commercially valuable decisions, did not appear to be subject to any review. The Minister advised the Committee that the accreditation body was the only suitable accrediting agency in Australia, but if this should change then it would certainly be appropriate to amend the Regulations. Laboratories are informed of any deficiencies and of how these may be remedied. Laboratories may then apply again for accreditation and request a different assessor. The Minister further advised that he had asked for a review of the other discretions and the Regulations would be amended to reflect that review's findings.

The Airports Regulations provided for commercially valuable discretions to exempt subleases from a general prohibition. The Minister advised the Committee that the Regulations would be amended to provide for AAT review. The Airports (Control of On‐Airport Activities) Regulations provided for a number of discretions in relation to the control of the sale of liquor, with no apparent AAT review. The Minister advised that State liquor law would apply at leased airports and that the present provisions were intended to facilitate this application. AAT review was therefore not appropriate. The Airports (Building Control) Regulations provided for extensive AAT review of decisions by the building controller but the Committee noted a few gaps. The Minister advised that the Regulations would be amended.

The Committee considers that the quality of drafting of regulations should not be less than that of Acts. In the present case the four sets of regulations all included drafting errors and oversights which the Minister agreed to amend.

The Committee is grateful to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon John Sharp MP, for his cooperation in this whole exercise. The Minister's actions demonstrate a commitment to personal rights and parliamentary propriety. These sets of regulations were among the most important dealt with by the Committee this year. They illustrate not only the importance of regulations in contemporary public administration but also the actions of the Committee in ensuring that regulations are of the highest quality.

DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1997, together with the submissions and transcript of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1997 is, on the face of it, a small bill. It does not involve a great deal of controversy, if you were to just rely upon the explanatory memorandum. What this committee report reveals is that these are matters of great substance. These are issues of great importance to this country and to the way in which our TAFE system is actually administered.

What you see before the parliament is yet another example of way in which the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) is quite prepared to make statements on the public record which would suggest one course of action is being followed, while all the time quite a contrary course of action is being followed. This inquiry has revealed that a bill has been put before the parliament which purports to maintain funding for the TAFE system in this country, but in fact it does not do that.

The report highlights that the government is currently at war with the states on the issue of TAFE funding. It is at war with the states on the issue of vocational education and training. Yet, if we were to rely upon the documents put before this parliament in terms of official communiques from this government, we would not get that impression.

A bill is being presented to the parliament which provides the base funding for what is supposed to be a new five‐year agreement regarding the Australian National Training Authority, which is the funding basis for the Commonwealth's contribution to TAFE colleges across the country. The Senate would be aware that some $3 billion a year is spent in this area, of which a Commonwealth contributes about $1 billion. This report highlights that this base funding proposal—which the minister uses as the index year on which he says real funding will be maintained—has been wound right back as a result of two rounds of efficiency cuts to various programs in vocational education and training and TAFE programs.

BREAK.PARA: It is $158 million over the forward estimates; a further $72 million in this year's budget; a further $12.8 million dollars, or a 27 per cent reduction in ANTA's operating funds; the unilateral decision to end the $70 million growth funding which was an integral part of the last ANTA agreement and the basis on which the Labor government funded the TAFE system; and the removal of about $1.8 billion in labour market programs which are the basis on which much of the funding went to TAFE colleges.

The baseline funding which this bill is proposing that we should pass and be the basis for the funding over the next five‐year agreement is inadequate of the task it ostensibly serves. This committee inquiry has revealed that it quite clearly does not meet the level of the demand within the system which at the moment—and I am sure the Senate would be aware of this—is running at some three times the level of the unmet demand in the higher education sector.

The proposition being advanced by this government suggests that this growth in vocational education and training should be funded entirely from efficiencies by the states themselves. This report reveals and details that the measures being proposed by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone—who has been participating in the meetings around this issue—are that the states fund the Commonwealth's initiatives in this area and that the states be required to pay the cost of the Commonwealth's largess. When you add the various initiatives in regard to the new apprenticeship scheme, the Commonwealth youth allowance and the various vocational education in schools programs that this government is claiming to champion, you see that it does not put its money where it mouth is.

The KPMG consultancy report undertaken by ANTA revealed earlier this year that the level of underfunding is quite substantial and it is getting worse. What we are seeing from a range of sources now is that the TAFE system in this country is being seriously put at risk by the policies of this government because it is not providing the proper resourcing to ensure that there is adequate provision across the country. Further, because of the changes that they are undertaking in the new programs being introduced, this is leading to a substantial decline in quality. There is a real serious risk here in terms of the provision of programs to TAFE institutes which would lead to a deterioration in the level of the training provided and a deterioration in the level of service provided which would lead in my judgment—and there is some grave concern—to a deskilling of the Australian work force and would further undermine what is already a relatively poor record in regard to our international performance in such a critical area.

On top of that, a program is to be initiated by this bill for the widespread privatisation of TAFE in this country. Some very serious issues are developing as to the way in which the Commonwealth is seeking to impose these policies without proper discussion in this country and without proper consideration of the costs of these policies.

The whole proposition that the states should fund this measure is intellectually flawed. It is flawed on the basis of logic or public policy and will lead to a very serious deterioration in the quality of services actually provided. Such a policy assumes that the states do have efficiencies of such size that will provide sufficient funds to actually fund growth in the TAFE sector. The policy does not acknowledge that particularly for TAFE teachers that means a further reduction in the conditions they are employed under and will lead in the case of Victoria—which is often used as the benchmark for such measures and where the wages and conditions for TAFE teachers are some 10 per cent behind that of the rest of country—to yet a further reduction in the conditions under which they work. What it ignores is that the states already provide substantial efficiency dividends to their budgets through the TAFE sector. On a whole series of measures it cannot be sustained that such a proposition can be funded through efficiencies of the scale that this government is proposing.
It is little wonder that we see such open warfare developing between the states. Mr Honeywood, a fellow Victorian of Dr Kemp's, indicated:
Dr Kemp is more interested in his profile than in solving youth unemployment.
He also said:
At the end of the day David is so hooked on his national profile and gaining kudos for the federal government for its training reforms that he completely ignores his responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the junior minister?
—This is the junior minister. On 19 August, Mr Honeywood further stated:

BREAK.PARA: The states and territories have just given up basically. Dr Kemp, just to get headlines, goes out after each minister's meeting . . . and hits us with another bombshell which we haven't agreed to.
Further, on 29 August, in respect of Dr Kemp, it was said:
The agreement proposed by the Commonwealth would represent the biggest cost shift (to the states) to a portfolio since Federation.
What he went on to say was that Dr Kemp is a total centralist. It is good to see that within the Liberal family there are such warm relations. Mr Honeywood indicated:
He reminds me very much of the former Prime Minister Billy Hughes. When he didn't want to do something he turned his hearing aid off.

We see further comments in the press today. Mr Honeywood said: Dr Kemp's arrogance has no bounds. It does a disservice to the young people of Australia to assume that you know in three to four years' time the level of funding needed given the fluctuations in unemployment and (the) changing needs for skilled labour . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you deliberately wasting time? You can debate this this afternoon.

—Senator Campbell says that this is all a waste of time. That is his attitude. If you try to put a proposition through this parliament, you do not want to debate it. You want to make sure that people do not know what is going on within this government. You want to make sure that people do not understand what you are doing to the education system in this country. The last thing you would want to see is a public debate about these questions.
—Why are you such a barefaced liar?
—Oh, come on!
—Order! You will have to withdraw that, Senator Campbell.
—That is a very strange view of the standing orders.
—Order! Senator Carr. I ask you to withdraw that, Senator Campbell.
—I withdraw.
—I frankly am not particularly fussed by Senator Campbell's outburst, other than it reveals the acute sensitivity of this government to exposure of the truth. (Time expired)

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.XREF: FRANCHISE FEES WINDFALL TAX (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September and 3 September, on motions by Senator Newman and Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 , and nine associated bills. It is a very important package of legislation and very complex. I will not read the titles of all of them.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation arises largely from the recent High Court decision about the states `fees' on alcoholic beverages and tobacco products. Whilst we are critical of the handling of the issues relating to this legislation by the Commonwealth Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Labor opposition is taking a responsible attitude to this legislation, and we will be supporting its quick passage through the Senate.

Labor has supported the relaxation of the cut‐off rules in the Senate to allow swift consideration of this legislation. It should be known that the government ruthlessly guillotined this package through the House on Tuesday evening, even though the opposition had given a commitment to pass it anyway.

The package of bills proposes to implement the temporary Commonwealth safety net taxation arrangements announced by the Treasurer on 6 August 1997. The need for these proposed new arrangements has arisen from the decisions in what is known as the Ha and Limb and Walter Hammond cases, which were handed down by the High Court on 5 August 1997.

These cases considered the constitutional validity of the Business Franchise Licences (Tobacco) Act 1987 of New South Wales. This legislation prohibited persons under penalty from selling tobacco, whether by wholesale or retail, without a licence. These licences are issued on application for periods of up to one month. The licence fee payable prior to the licence period was $10, plus 100 per cent of the value of the tobacco sold in the two months prior to the period of the licence. For example, the fee for the month of August 1997 was payable at the end of July 1997 and was based on the sales which occurred in June 1997.
The question at issue in the cases was does the licence fee constitute an excise for the purposes of section 90 of the Australian constitution? The first portion of section 90 states:

On the imposition of uniform duties of customs the power of the Parliament to impose duties of customs and of excise, and to grant bounties on the production or export of goods, shall become exclusive.

The first condition of section 90—the imposition of uniform duties of customs—was achieved at 4 p.m. on 8 October 1901. From that time onwards, the Commonwealth has had the exclusive right to levy customs and excise duties. The plaintiffs claimed that the New South Wales statute breached section 90. New South Wales, with the support of all the other states and territories, submitted that the licence fees were not duties of customs or of excise within the meaning of section 90.

The specific argument of the states was that the term `duties of custom or of excise' does not cover all taxes on goods but merely duties imposed respectively on the importation or the local production or manufacture of goods. The submission sought to reopen issues decided in previous cases on the basis that incorrect reasoning had been used and that the reasoning had been followed in later cases.

Specifically, the states argued that the extension of the definition of `excise' to include taxes on the distribution and/or sale of goods was incorrect and should be reviewed by the High Court. The High Court did agree to reopen the issues. However, four of the seven justices found for the plaintiffs and therefore against the states, thereby invalidating the New South Wales legislation and, by extension, the legislation of the other states and territories concerning licence fees for tobacco.

Whilst not certain, the decision probably meant the court would strike down the licence fees on petroleum and alcohol as well. The revenue threat to the states and territories of these decisions is estimated to be $5 billion in 1997‐98, which is around one‐sixth of their own source revenue. Clearly, this is a very major issue for the states.

The only options for the states were to either recoup the threatened revenue from other tax bases or to request the Commonwealth to use its power under section 90 to collect the moneys effectively as an agent and to on‐pass the revenue. State and territory leaders unanimously requested the Commonwealth to utilise Commonwealth tax bases to collect the revenue formally raised by the BFFs and to remit these moneys to the states and territories. The Commonwealth agreed.

The issue of the Commonwealth stepping into the breach is complicated by the fact that the states and the territories impose their own BFFs on differing bases and at different rates. As the constitution limits the Commonwealth to impose identical taxes across the whole nation, compromise rates have to be struck and a complicated formula devised to equitably share the revenue. Accordingly, the Commonwealth government has announced increases in, firstly, the level of customs and excise duties on petroleum products by 8.1c per litre; secondly, the level of customs and excise duties on tobacco by $167 per kilogram; and, thirdly, the rate of wholesale sales tax on alcoholic beverages by 15 per cent, except for low alcohol wine, which will not be affected. These bills seek to implement these announced increases. The Commonwealth has stated that these increases will be reviewed within six months prior to permanent measures being decided upon.

To ensure that the increase in the wholesale sales tax rates does not detrimentally affect small business, the small business exemption and the quarterly remittance regime, which both provide greater assistance to small business than the normal administrative arrangements, will be calculated with the additional tax on alcohol being excluded. These small business adjustments are appropriate and are supported by Labor.

Furthermore, I wish to formally set on the record that the opposition supports the amendments moved by the government in the House to the Sales Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1997 , which has introduced a crediting system that was absent from the original bill. This addresses potential anomalies—for example, where damaged goods are returned—which would have arisen without any crediting arrangements. The crediting should then be taken into account when the grants are made to the states and territories.

The total revenue raised is estimated to be around $6 billion. This is obviously substantially more than the lost revenue for this financial year of $5 billion. No details are provided. The revenue from each of the increased taxes is measured on the basis that the financial impact on the Commonwealth will be nil. This is not sufficient reason to not inform the Senate of the amounts estimated to be raised. These bills propose an enormous increase in Commonwealth receipts—in excess of one per cent of gross domestic product per year—and there must be a full account of the estimates of the revenue effects of each decision. I would ask Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, to provide full details to the Senate of the estimated receipts flowing from each of these measures.

All revenue raised, less the Commonwealth's administrative costs, will be passed on to the states and territories. Labor supports this approach as there is no justification for the Commonwealth to benefit financially from the High Court decisions. The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 was amended in the House last week with opposition support to facilitate the on‐passing of the revenue to the other jurisdictions. Identified proportions of the separate revenue streams are to be handed back to each jurisdiction. In turn, the states and territories have the responsibility of making payments back to producers and distributors to ensure that businesses and consumers are not detrimentally affected and so that no windfall profits are made by governments.

It is in this final phase—the reimbursement of businesses—that the whole response to the decision has been mismanaged. The High Court decision did not come out of the blue. Everyone knew the potential gravity of the decisions and the timing of the judgments. Accordingly, there is no excuse for some of the chaos that has reigned after the temporary Commonwealth arrangements came into effect. The potential for this result was known years ago and the former government had considered the issue back in 1993. There is no doubt that the Treasurer should have formulated detailed contingency plans with the other jurisdictions prior to the decisions which could have been implemented immediately. Apparently little, if anything, was done beforehand, which is a damning indictment of the judgment of the current Treasurer.

The issues are apparently still not resolved. In the area of tobacco there is apparently the likelihood of a significant price hike in the price of a packet of cigarettes in South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. The Financial Review of 27 August reports that these three conservative state governments—I might say, in the case of Tasmania, a state Liberal government supported by a Green party—have boycotted a recent meeting between Commonwealth Treasury officials and industry representatives to try to sort out the confusion. In that article the industry estimates that the new regime could result in increases in cigarette prices of between 84c and $1.75 per packet.

There was a further article by Stuart Washington in the Financial Review reporting an apparent increase of around 2.5 per cent in cigarettes which will flow from the flawed implementation process of this package. Consumers are entitled to ask why this has happened. The Commonwealth Treasurer has assured the public that they would not be detrimentally affected, yet there appear to be substantial price hikes in some or all of the three commodities affected.

Some government members have sought to link the High Court decisions with the need to introduce a GST. The Labor opposition rejects this absolutely. Indeed, we argue that the botched implementation of what is a very minor change compared with that which would occur with a GST is an indication of the absolute chaos that a GST would involve.

We have already had Mr Stockdale reported in the Age of 14 August as complaining that profiteering was occurring and the liquor industry was using the High Court decisions to rip people off. If a very conservative state treasurer is prepared to go on the public record in this way, it indicates that the implementation process is flawed.

Clearly, the huge changes which are inevitable under a GST would involve enormous cost to consumers over and above those that would flow from the imposition of a new tax. I do note that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has re‐christened the GST `a broad based indirect tax', or BBIT for short. It has an interesting ring to it. I am sure we will hear a lot more about the BBIT. I am surprised that Senator Kemp—and I note that he is here—did not re‐christen the GST a `GSS', or a goods and services surcharge, given the performance of this government in this area to date.

In addition to affecting the current and future revenue of the states and territories, the High Court decisions have opened up the possibility of past licence fee payments being reclaimed by taxpayers. This would both severely damage the fiscal position of the states and territories and provide a windfall gain to the taxpayers, as the licence fees have already been passed on to consumers. To overcome this unfair result, the three windfall tax bills in the package will impose a 100 per cent tax on any refunds of tobacco, alcohol or petroleum licence fees originally paid before 5 August 1997 where the refund arises because the licence fee is unconstitutional.

Apart from the other problems I have identified, there is a further significant commercial issue which arises from these bills. The use by the Commonwealth of the excise tax base instead of the wholesale sales tax base is expected to significantly affect the profitability of the three tobacco producers. Estimates provided to Labor from an analysis by Deloitte, Touche and Tohmatsu and the Allen Consulting Group indicate that moving from an ad valorem or value based system to a weight based system of taxation for tobacco will change profits significantly for the three domestic manufacturers. Estimates are that Phillip Morris will lose around $5 million per annum in profits, Wills will lose over $31 million and Rothmans will gain around $36 million per annum. The actual effect will probably now be greater, given that the total amount of taxation being imposed on tobacco is being increased by around half a billion dollars per annum. The Treasurer has acknowledged the issue in his press release of 6 August. However, the response does nothing to ameliorate the effects of the decision. Labor will seek an assurance from the government that the switch to excise will not result in any job losses for the thousands of people involved in this industry.

In our response to the High Court decision, my colleague the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gareth Evans, indicated there were four principles which we need to be assured of to facilitate the passage of this legislation; namely, that the revenue package has the agreement of the states and territories, that it fairly distributes the revenue to the states and territories, that it does not involve extra taxes being imposed on Australians and that it is equitable in its impact on businesses immediately affected. We accept that the first two of these conditions have been met by the temporary Commonwealth response. We are concerned that the government has been less than competent in ensuring that consumers and businesses have not been detrimentally affected. Nevertheless, we realise that these bills are urgent to ensure that even further confusion and chaos is avoided and we will be supporting their passage. However, as I said earlier, I ask the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, to provide the revenue details which I have requested so that the Australian people are properly informed about the important package of legislation.

I would now like to make comment about the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill. The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill is critical to the smooth functioning of the federation and is a non‐controversial measure. Around $16.8 billion in funding is being provided through this bill as originally introduced. In addition, the government amended the bill in the House to facilitate the on‐passing of the revenue from the Commonwealth's temporary revenue safety net arrangements which is estimated at around $6 billion in 1997-98. Labor will be supporting the bill's passage through the parliament.

BREAK.PARA: Quite literally, the quality and in some cases the actual existence of the state and territory government core services, such as health, education, law and order, public transport et cetera, rely heavily on the grants appropriated by this bill. The monies appropriated in this bill represent a large proportion of the financial phenomenon known as vertical fiscal imbalance, VFI, a subject I will comment on later in my speech.

The bill proposes to implement the general revenue assistance measures `agreed to' at the 1997 Premiers Conference. Of course, senators would know that when push comes to shove it is the Commonwealth's position which is agreed to at the Premiers Conference. These grants are the untied funds provided by the Commonwealth for general use by state and territory governments according to their own priorities. These untied funds are provided for two purposes: firstly, to compensate for the takeover by the Common wealth of the income tax base during World War II and, secondly, to fulfil the horizontal fiscal equalisation obligations of the Commonwealth—that is, to grant particular states and territories the additional revenue they need to provide an average level of services without resorting to above average revenue effort.

The 1997 Premiers Conference agreement involved a reaffirmation of the funding formula introduced by Labor; namely that of the real per capita indexation of the financial assistance grants—commonly known as FAGs—pool of previous years. Of course, the sting in the tail for the states and territories was that they agreed to make fiscal contributions to the Commonwealth in 1997-98 of around $627 million, building on the estimated $609 million contributed in the 1996-97 years—that is, they are to have their funding cut relative to the real per capita arrangement originally struck by Labor. In order to appease the states and territories, the method of calculation of the fiscal contribution will not reduce the base by which future years' grants are to be determined, only the allocation over the three years of the agreement.

Notwithstanding this fiscal contribution for 1997-98 and that proposed for 1998-99, the Commonwealth has extended the real per capita funding guarantee until 1999-2000. Given the reneging by the Howard government of its pre-election commitment, which has been massively breached, to not cut grants to the states, many of the states are no doubt nervous about the likelihood of actually receiving the amount set out in the forward estimates.

In addition, the government will commence making the competition payments this financial year through this bill. Again, this is a significant Labor initiative under the national competition policy to share the benefits of increased competition fairly through the various levels of government. These competition payments are estimated to total $215 million in 1997-98, being equal to $200 million in 1994-95.

I will speak for a couple more minutes. But, given the time and enormous importance of this legislation, when my time expires I will circulate the remainder of my speech and ask that it be incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will read it with great interest.

—Thank you. The impact of the fiscal contribution contained within the bill has already been felt by people reliant on services provided by state and territory governments. New South Wales had to increase taxes last year to make up for the impact of cuts. The legislation passed by the New South Wales parliament was the appropriately titled `Howard and Costello Tax Amendment Bill'.
—It has helped their polls, hasn't it?

—Have a look at the polls in Tasmania, Senator Kemp. Victoria did not increase taxes but it had to defer the tax cuts that had been widely expected. So Victorians are still paying the highest state taxes. Have you had a look at your own polls lately, Senator Kemp? These $1.5 billion contributions have had a real impact on Australian families through either increased taxes or reduced services or both. It was an example of the Commonwealth forcing the states to do their dirty work. Understandably, the premiers and chief ministers objected to being ambushed by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister at the 1996 PC when their fiscal contribution was agreed to. This led to the interesting situation where the essentially conservative premiers actually told the public what they thought of the Treasurer—and were there some wing‐ding descriptions of your colleague, Senator Kemp. No agreement was possible on day one and there was a real prospect of the 1996 Premiers Conference having to be abandoned.
—Do you want to hear what your colleagues are saying about you?
—Nothing could beat Premier Kennett's comments about Mr Costello, nothing I have ever seen.
—Senator Sherry, I understand that you have to move some amendments.
—I do. I move:

BREAK.PARA: In respect of the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) the mismanagement of the economy, reflected in the continuing poor economic and jobs growth figures and an increase in the rate of long‐term unemployment since March 1996;
(b) deceiving the Australian people by promising to alter grants to the States and Territories on a revenue neutral basis, but actually imposing cuts of $1.5 billion on general revenue assistance;
(c) the impact that the $1.5 billion of fiscal contributions are having on the delivery of State and Territory government services; and

In respect of the remaining bills:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate notes that:
