The speech read as follows—
The final meeting to resolve the impasse was conducted without the Treasurer—the Prime Minister had to do it himself as the state and territory leaders obviously could not work with the Treasurer.

- The amount of time devoted to the PC meant that the subsequent COAG meeting was an absolute failure as well. Nothing of substance was resolved and as I said earlier the COAG process has been in a state of leaderless drift ever since.
. The 1997 PC involved less open warfare than the 1996 one. However, there was still contention over the size of the cuts to specific purpose payments (SPPs) that were to be paid in 1997-98.
‐ Here there was the incredible situation where the PM and the Treasurer gave conflicting advice about the size of the aggregate cuts in SPPs.
- Again, there was anger from the Premiers and Chief Ministers at this further show of bad faith.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commonwealth/State Financial Relations

BREAK.PARA: I wish to turn now to the bigger picture question of Commonwealth/State financial relations.
. I note in passing that the Commonwealth/State non-financial agenda has basically ground to a halt under the Howard Government.

- COAG has become an acute embarassment for the Government. Remember the grand plans of the new Government to fundamentally overhaul the delivery of housing services, of health services, of education services?
- The results have been non-existent, and indeed COAG hasn't met since 14 June 1996—with the next meeting apparently scheduled for October 1997.

. Commonwealth/State financial relations are a significant matter, but the intensity of the complaints by the state and territory leaders massively overemphasise the supposed financing problems faced by the states.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Vertical Fiscal Imbalance

BREAK.PARA: . As the Shadow Treasurer said in the House in debate on these bills, it is true that Australia has a relatively high degree of vertical fiscal imbalance (VFI) compared with other federations.
- The reasons for this imbalance are (i) constitutional—the Constitution reserves most goods taxing power to the Commonwealth.
- and (ii) political—the states and territories have deliberately eroded their tax bases over time.
But nobody has seriously questioned whether VFI is necessarily a bad thing?

. Firstly, it should be remembered that some level of VFI is necessary and desirable. The Commonwealth provides an equalisation component in the financial assistance grants to the states and territories as part of the normal functioning of government.

- Equalisation grants ensure that all state and territory governments have enough resources to provide a general level of services to their residents without having to impose disproportionate levels of taxation.

‐ Without an equalisation component, grants would be distributed on a per capita basis—severely disadvantaging the Northern Territory, South Australia and Tasmania and also detrimentally affecting Queensland.
‐ The Parliamentary Library has estimated that around $2.6 billion is the approximate figure of the equalisation component in the grants in the bill before us tonight for the 1997-98 financial year.

. The main argument for the removal of the degree of VFI is the general contention that it is better for sovereign governments to raise their own revenue as this leads to greater accountability between that government and its electors.

‐ Most people would not dispute such a motherhood statement. However, the real issue is, what is the actual cost of a state or territory being significantly reliant on financing from the central government?
. Common sense tells us that the actual cost is either negligible or possibly even negative. How can I come to such a conclusion?

- Assuming that the states would still have the same revenue needs, there are only two options of raising the revenue that is currently collected by the Commonwealth either (i) using the same revenue base that the Commonwealth uses or (ii) using a different base.

- If we assume, very generously, that the Commonwealth simply forgoes part of its revenue base and that the states enter that revenue base, it is unlikely that they will be able to match the efficiency of collection which a single entity (the Commonwealth) currently achieves.

PARA.TAB: Certainly it will be no more efficiently collected by multiple state revenue agencies than by the single Commonwealth entity.

BREAK.PARA: ‐ Alternatively, if a new form of revenue is tapped by the states then the collection and compliance costs will almost certainly be higher than from the foregone Commonwealth revenue base, and, more importantly, the economic effects of a new state tax (because of their more limited choice of tax bases) will probably be much more adverse than the Commonwealth revenue source it replaces.

. So measured in terms of the costs of collection, the costs of compliance and the economic efficiency losses associated with some state tax bases, it may be that VFI is actually beneficial to the nation—not the huge bogey that the states and territories always wish to make it.

. The recent assumption of the collection of the state and territory business franchise fees through the Commonwealth excise taxes provides an example of where there may actually be national collection efficiencies derived through the use of the Commonwealth as a central collection point, even though there will be complications in the calculation of the division of the monies back to the states and territories.
‐ Whilst it is obviously too early to tell at this stage, we may get some interesting data on this matter in the fullness of time when the permanent Commonwealth measures are operating.
. The third point to remember is that under the current arrangements, the major fiscal risks are borne by the Commonwealth. Commonwealth revenue is more cyclical than state revenue.
- Therefore in a major economic downturn the states are far better off under the current arrangements than under any genuine revenue sharing arrangement.
‐ In effect, the Commonwealth is the underwriter for the states and territories when the cycle turns downwards.
. As the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition have stated the Opposition is perfectly happy to have these issues considered and debated in the general context of tax reform.
‐ However, this issue should not be used as a cover for the GST. It has nothing to do with a GST and any such representation will be a misrepresentation.
‐ Indeed ironically if a GST were introduced as a replacement for some or all of the states' indirect tax bases, then by definition the level of VFI in Australia would massively increase.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Financial Grants to the States and Territories

BREAK.PARA: . The real issue for the states and territories has always been the future certainty of their revenue sources, not how the revenue sources are formally raised.

- This is why Labor entered into a three year financial assistance grants agreement with the states from the June 1990 Premiers' Conference where the value of the Financial Assistance Grants (FAGs) pool was maintained in real terms for the agreed three years.

‐ Then at the 1994 Premiers' Conference Labor extended the promise—increasing the FAGs not only by inflation but also by the increase in population. In addition, this commitment was made not just on a three year agreement but was made on a three year rolling basis. That is, each year at the PC a position would be reached on the next three years.
. Labor has honoured all of the agreements that it has made at Premiers' Conferences.
‐ This Government pretended prior to the election that it would honour the existing Commonwealth commitments but has instead reneged.
‐ $1.5 billion has been ripped off the states and terrritories which means that those most dependent upon state services are being hurt.
As usual, whilst Labor is decried as being too centralist, we have actually delivered far more to the states than this supposedly more federalist Government.

. Part of the temporary response to that decision was for the states and territories to request that the Commonwealth increase their existing tax bases—both wholesale sales tax and excise—to replace the revenue collected under state and territory business franchise fees.

‐ These requests were duly made, and the Treasurer then announced on August 6 increases from in: customs and excise duties on petroleum products of 8.1 cents per litre; customs and excise duties on tobacco of $167 per kg; and wholesale sales tax on alcoholic beverages of 15 per cent.
‐ In addition, the intention to impose a windfall gains tax on refunds of business franchise fees arising because of the High Court decision was also announced.

. As well as collecting the revenue on behalf of the other governments, the Commonwealth also has to ensure that the disbursement of these funds is equitable so that consumers and governments do not lose out.
- Of course we know that the Government mucked up the issue.
- It had not properly planned for the contingency of the High Court decision, even though its potential impact was widely known. This issue did not come out of the blue.

‐ Indeed, this issue had been looked at by the former Government back in 1993, which demonstrates that a fully thought through and agreed plan should have been developed prior to the High Court decision was handed down.
‐ Even after the agreement with the other governments was supposedly finalised chaos reigned—especially in the liquor and tobacco industries.

. Despite this poor management by the Treasurer, the Opposition, being very fiscally responsible, has not sought to dwell on this issue nor to grandstand nor cause Parliamentary difficulties with the passage of this legislation.
- Consistent with our practice to date, we will be supporting this important legislation and all of the Government amendments to be moved today.
. I seek an assurance from the Parliamentary Secretary that the four conditions that we have placed on our support for this package (and the related revenue package) have been met.

‐ These conditions are that the revenue and grants packages: have the agreement of the States and Territories; fairly distributes the revenue to the States and Territories; do not involve extra taxes being imposed on Australians; and are equitable in their impact on the businesses immediately affected.

. In the particular context of this bill, can the Parliamentary Secretary assure the House that the various petroleum, tobacco and alcohol shares contained within the amendments have been agreed to by all the affected jurisdictions?
. Are these revenue shares used in the calculation of the Revenue Replacement Payments to be altered each year? Or are they to remain constant?
. I will not delay the Senate further on this important issue, and I note that the other essential legislation to implement the revenue side of the Commonwealth's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is the annual reminder of just how ludicrous state and federal relations have become in this country. Under this act the Commonwealth will transfer $16.8 billion to the states in general revenue assistance. Combined with specific purpose payments and the compensation arrangements under the franchises bills packages that we will consider shortly, the Commonwealth now provides about 60 per cent of the running costs of the states. That level of fiscal imbalance between the Commonwealth and the states is excessive and needs to be reviewed, but such a review should not be limited to just a fairer share of revenue; it should also have a cold hard look at spending powers as well.

SPEECH.PARA: In some areas, such as health and TAFE, where most of the funding already comes from Canberra and the policy setting is also nationally driven, I think we should ask whether the states should hand them over completely, thereby saving the states around $8 billion a year. Senator Murray will expand on this in his comments on the franchise fees bills. The Democrats see some merit in a national taxation system, rather than breaking it into nine separate tax systems. But I also recognise that the current system is entirely unsatisfactory. It is unsatisfactory because the states can make cuts and blame Canberra and because Canberra can make cuts to the states grants knowing that it will be the states that bear the odium, not the Commonwealth.

The Hawke-Keating government worked out very early that states grants were an easy target for cutting spending in what was for Canberra a fairly painless way of extracting a few billion dollars. Grants fell in real terms each year from 1984 to 1991, falling from 18 per cent of Commonwealth outlays to just 12.6 per cent. The cuts in grants during the 1980s forced the states to shed around 12,000 jobs. Since then grants were largely retained in real per capita terms.

Mr Howard, as part of his federalism policy, promised to retain states grants in real per capita terms. That was a promise that his Liberal colleagues Mr Jeff Kennett, Richard Court, Dean Brown, Ray Groom and Rob Borbidge were hoping he would keep. But at last year's Premiers Conference they, like the other 18 million Australians, found that what Mr Howard regards as a promise and a core promise were very different. The genuine anger at last year's Premiers Conference and again this year exposed the agenda of Mr Howard and Mr Costello. A fiscal contribution of $1.5 billion over three years was agreed upon. That represents another 10,000 to 12,000 jobs lost.

BREAK.PARA: Then, at this year's Premiers Conference, having been assured by Mr Howard and Mr Costello, the Premiers were slugged again. This time it was TAFE, public housing, local government, public health, rail infrastructure and privatisation receipts that were raided. It is little wonder that the state premiers can find so little good to say about this government.

But I want to confine my comments to two aspects of this bill where I will be moving amendments in the committee stage. The first is the application of competition policy to the local government sector. The act before us makes available to the states a pool of $215 million in payments to promote competition policy. The Commonwealth will take into account the advice of the National Competition Council as to whether the states have made sufficient progress in implementing the competition principles agreements. That was all agreed at COAG and, even though the Democrats believe that competition policy is yet another hard‐right, ideological attack on the public provision of essential public services, at least both levels of governments agreed to it.

But competition policy has also been inflicted, without agreement and with only the minimum of consultation, on the local government sector. Right across Australia local government is being turned upside down in trying to come to terms with that. Local government workers are now losing contracts to private contractors from, in many cases, outside the area. When they lose the contract, the district loses employment and money flows out of the community.

Competition policy reform has for many rural and regional areas been a very significant force for centralisation. Local councils are no longer able to engage in `buy local' campaigns because that breaches competition policy. As the regulatory review processes crank up, locally determined by-laws will be reviewed, reducing the options available to communities to determine what they think are appropriate rules on town planning and community amenities if the National Competi tion Council regards them as potentially anti-competitive.

In Victoria all councils must put to competition virtually all their services. Forced competition policy introduced during the time when local government was controlled by state government appointees is also used to significantly reduce services and conditions of staff. It has also turned out to be very costly to administer and very uneven in terms of delivering cost savings.

Competition policy will be, and in some states is already, very intrusive into local government services. Yet, despite all that, there is no guarantee that local government will receive any payment from competition policy payments under this act because these payments are subject to agreement between just two levels of government. This is a very clear breach of coalition policy before the last election, which promised:
A coalition government will build an effective partnership between federal, state and local governments based on frequent and high level consultation.
The coalition promised to recognise the important role of local government in the national economy. It said it would:

. . . seek to resolve issues of long-term importance to local government, including the declining share of revenue allocated to local government and the best way local government can participate in the benefits of national competition policy.
It would also:
. . . monitor the impact of the Hilmer reforms on rural communities to ensure that they receive their fair share of the benefits.
And so on. Principle 7 of the competition principles agreement signed in 1995 makes it clear that the agreement applies to local government but it is up to each state government to determine how.

At this point only two of the six states in Australia—that is, Queensland and Western Australia—have agreements with local governments on how competition policy payments will be distributed between the two levels of government. The other four have not. If competition policy is to be seen as a partnership between all levels of government, then I think this legislation needs to be amended to bring local government into the loop. I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to add a condition with which the states must comply before receiving competition payments—the condition being that the state has reached agreement with representatives of local government in that state on how the competition payment will be shared. This is not a prescriptive provision. Clearly the application of competition policy at the local government level is different from state to state. What it does acknowledge is the importance of a real partnership and of the significant role that local government has played in implementing that policy.

The second amendment I will be moving is also a very important one. It will require the Treasurer, before he makes payment of any general revenue assistance to the states, to be satisfied that the state government has in place an independent state auditor‐general. For 97 years now every state has met such a criterion—and easily so. This has only become an issue at all in the last year—in relation to Victoria where the Premier has virtually declared war on our Auditor‐General. If the Kennett government is allowed to proceed with its proposal to nobble the Auditor‐General's office, it will be able to spend Commonwealth funds in any way. Essentially, it will be unaccountable and unchecked. The Auditor‐General's role will be reduced to a symbolic and powerless one.

The Kennett plans have been attacked by the present Auditor‐General Mr Baragwanath, former Auditors‐General, coalition backbenchers, the Speaker of the Victorian parliament, academics, audit professional bodies and public administration experts, not to mention many thousands of ordinary, worried Victorians.At its conference in Sydney earlier this year the Australasian Council of Public Accounts Committee recognised the crucially important role of an independent auditor‐general to underpin the Westminster system of parliamentary democracy. The council set out what it regarded as minimum conditions to establish the operational independence of the auditor‐general. Clearly Mr Kennett's plan in Victoria falls very far short of that standard.

The Howard government was elected with promises of improving financial accountability for public funds. It has beefed up the Audit Bill and the Financial Management and Accountability Bill of the previous governments. Those bills, to be considered by the Senate later this month, are welcomed by the Democrats, as is the charter of budget honesty. These are very worthy initiatives. But to allow $16.8 billion of grants to slip through to the states without proper auditing of the expenditure must be unacceptable, and it is inconsistent with the generally commendable stance of this government on financial accountability issues.

I will be moving an amendment to make it essential that the Treasurer, before he makes any grant to a state, be satisfied that moneys will be audited by an appropriate state auditor‐general. This amendment will ensure that Victoria cannot change the mandate of its auditor‐general without risking its federal grant. That is constitutionally valid, as the states have no right to financial assistance grants per se.

The amendment we have drafted was also drawn up based on advice from the Australasian Council of Auditors‐General. I hope for the Senate's support for this very important accountability measure, when we get to that committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purpose) Bill and the others with it have been given all haste and all assistance from the Senate for their passing but, despite that, quite clearly the issues that have been the cause of this package of bills have not been resolved by it.

SPEECH.PARA: In my opinion the major issues are those of the Commonwealth‐state relationship and the ability to raise revenue from various levels of government. The bandaid approach of this package does not even nearly approach what those issues are. The contingent issue of some importance is the nature of taxation and the balance of consumption based and income based taxes. Another issue is that of the relative powers and recognition of the various levels of government.

There is cooperation on this from the Senate because the issue is urgent, but there is a lack of argument because this is the simple thing—replacing state franchise taxes with their nearest equivalent excise and wholesale taxes. Basically you have done a quick fix, but there is a lot more to be debated. We believe that constitutional debate has been truncated.

There are some fundamental problems: they are the revenue powers between state and federal governments. These have developed through circumstance, over time, not necessarily in strict accordance with whatever was set out in the original constitution. I am not saying they are necessarily unconstitutional; I am saying these powers have been tacked on as needs be.

There is no power for national social standards—education, health and housing—so we have issues within the constitution which fall between the cracks. We have no inclusion of local government within the constitutional debate. Local government is within the constitutional framework by grace and favour of state and territory governments—or, in the case of the territories, by grace and favour of the Commonwealth. There are no uniform pollution standards on things like lead in petrol—nor is there any ability to ask for them. There is no bill of rights and there are no fundamental rights for individuals or communities. The recognition of the Magna Carta is hardly significant.

There are no rights for nature or for individuals—ecological sustainability as a citizenship right. That gives governments—law‐makers, state, federal and local—the right to take away the rights of the future. If you do not have ecological sustainability as a right of citizenship, people can put in laws which mean that the future will not be guaranteed for those people who want to be able to live in a healthy, sustainable environment.

These things need to be resolved by broad community debate. They are not going to be resolved within these chambers. They are not even going to be resolved within constitutional conventions and neither are they going to be resolved within closed rooms with the heads of governments already existing within the flawed constitutional structure. I believe that the lead‐up to the turn of the century is the ideal time to address these issues.

There are also obviously issues about the equitability of consumption taxes, whether or not our current forms of taxes are equitable and smart the way they are charged and the way they are collected, the means of collection and the complexity of taxes. We have got the issue of consumption taxes that are not and cannot be currently targeted in terms of their environmental impact or social impact.

We talked yesterday about the ability of the private sector to be able to demand that they can compete against government services despite the other issues and other values involved; their ability to demand that they can tender on what they consider to be an equal basis, on cost. However, we have a situation where there are many market imperfections within our system. We have a situation where the community are being asked to shoulder the burden of pollution, asked to shoulder the burden of future climate change, asked to shoulder the burden of dirty water or rivers that cannot be used for their original purpose and so on, or rivers drying up.

The community is being asked to shoulder that burden because of the activities of industry. That is a market imperfection. But we have left ourselves currently without the ability or the will to design our tax system so that those unfair costs are not being shouldered by members of the community who have not benefited from the revenue from those activities. So those are issues we ought to be talking about, and whether or not it is fairer to tax pollution rather than employment.

There is also the possibility of more targeted taxation. At times it may be as simple as replacing a tax on leaded petrol with a tax on lead additives to petrol. Using less lead will create an incentive for manufacturers as well as creating a differential price for consumers.

The debate could include such things as a carbon tax, which could effectively replace much of our petrol and other fuel taxes. We have got to think about these things, because often people say, `Oh, we can't think of things like carbon taxes,' but we have current tax regimes and excise regimes on things like petrol. Why not design those regimes so that they do reflect the ecological sustainability of the use of those particular resources and energy inputs? Why not utilise a smart tax system which has at least more than one dividend?

A carbon tax could effectively replace many of our other petrol taxes. It could discriminate against dirtier transport and energy production, as well as high pollution energy consumption generally. We estimate that a carbon tax of about 7c a litre, properly hypothecated, could be used to virtually attain our greenhouse obligations. That is a small amount of the 44c a litre people are now paying. We could be doing this; we could be thinking smarter about our tax regime.

Hypothecation includes equity measures such as housing and urban reconstruction, so that it replaces money now spent on similar programs without environmental targeting. You build in your hypothecation so that you have the ability to make access to transport more equitable, so that those people with the least resources in our community are not badly affected by environmental taxes and they have the ability to access roads, cycleways and public transport.

Hypothecation includes those things, if it is well done. It also can be directed in other socially desirable directions. There are options for minimising a carbon tax through minimising polluting transport practices. Many measures are possible as part of the equity principle for providing means of minimising transport needs without compromising quality of life. Many could indeed improve the quality of life. For those people who are getting the notes to say what the public directions are in relation to the smoky haze over many of the cities of Australia—now even Perth—you can see it as you go outside your house and you find that you are coughing because of the smoke in the air. You can imagine that there are things that can happen that can improve your quality of life on a winter night or getting in and out of an airport in haze and mist and so on. There are things that can improve people's health and quality of life which might also be good for the economy.

There are other kinds of consumption taxes. These could be taxes on packaging, which would go a long way towards eliminating overpackaging and the use of non‐recyclable materials. It will also reduce costs for things like tip construction and waste collection, removal and treatment. Part of the problem here is that the local governments, which are often left with looking after the mess that everybody else makes, are the ones that shoulder that burden. So obviously there needs to be that debate on how that burden of the costs of waste can be shared and can be rationalised with the levels of government which often are the ones which make the laws in regard to things like packaging and taxation.

We could also target more wealth oriented taxes. If we are going to target consumption it might be beneficial, but it would depend on how we target consumption and what kind of consumption we are targeting. There are many possibilities within the tax debate, and I think if we mean to have a debate on taxation we could and should consider the broadest possible framework.

The group of bills that we have been asked to consider today initially were the franchise fees windfall tax bills and associated sales tax and customs tariffs bills. On to that was tacked the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 almost at the last minute. I would like to foreshadow an amendment to the second reading of the franchise fees group of bills in relation to the need to widen this debate. We have what is considered by many people, including me, to be a very flawed process in relation to the Constitutional Convention, but it does seem to me that there is a unique opportunity for that Constitutional Convention to start looking at the wider issues that are brought up in such things as the court decision in relation to state taxes and charges.

It becomes hugely obvious that there is now an opportunity to talk about the constitution, the issues that are important to people, whether there are problems in the constitution, how we might as a community work out innovative and creative decisions appropriate to the next century, how we might talk about the realities of state, federal and local governments and, of course, issues such as human rights, the bill of rights and, potentially, the rights of citizens to ecological sustainability. Those kinds of issues should not be held out of the debate if we are going to look at changing the head of state.

I believe that the official ALP position on this issue is that the Constitutional Convention should deal only with the head of state, which is interesting because one of those three issues is supposed to be the form of the potential republic. However, I am not even sure whether they are carrying their own supporters with them on that issue. It may well be the official position of the Australian Republican Movement, and that is fine, but I am not even sure whether that is the position of the vast number of people in Australia who want Australia to move towards a change of the head of state. Personally, I do not see much point in simply changing the head of state given what I see as the problems that we ought to be addressing in our constitution. Simply changing the head of state does not help much in addressing those real issues.

Here we have an opportunity. This set of bills is a very good pointer to where we should be using that opportunity to widen that debate. It is not appropriate to limit that debate to those who are already within the political system. The second reading amendment that I have foreshadowed suggests that the forthcoming Constitutional Convention should develop mechanisms and a timetable to facilitate community debate on these issues.

Let us go out to the community and not be frighted to ask people about what they want and about the timetable for change. Instead of that, we will be coming up again and again trying to address the problems caused by our current taxation system—the vertical imbalance—and the enforced problems due to the changes wrought on local, state and federal governments as a result of such things as competition policy.

BREAK.PARA: There is a huge debate in relation to competition policy and revenue. Often those decisions are made on high, and this should not be the case. We should be talking about what we think is appropriate and where the revenue should be coming from. The debate should also be talking about what kinds of things the community thinks the government ought to be involved in when spending the revenue we collect. If we change the debate around, we should be looking, firstly, at what is an appropriate level of tax for those things which the community thinks are important. When we have discovered that, we can work out a fair way to collect it.

I have no problems with the ALP's second reading amendment, but I also urge the Senate, despite the indication I have received so far, to support the move to broaden that debate, to not just come back here again and again with bandaid solutions to what is obviously an ongoing problem with taxation and to start talking about it in a constitutional sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 and associated bills represent the Commonwealth's urgent response to the decision of the High Court on 5 August 1997 to overturn the power of the states to collect franchise fees on tobacco, alcohol and, by implication, petrol. It is the intention of the Australian Democrats to give you every assistance to pass this bill urgently today.

SPEECH.PARA: This decision has blown a huge hole in the revenue power of the states—a $5 billion revenue hole. This package of bills will increase the sales tax on alcohol and the excises on petrol and tobacco to plug that hole. The states will be reimbursed all additional revenue raised, with the responsibility then being on the states to reimburse the tax collection which is in excess of that which would have been collected under the former state laws. It is, altogether a very messy business.

This is because under section 99 of the constitution the Commonwealth cannot set different revenue rates for different states—quite rightly, too. This has obviously created a serious problem because in this case the rates of franchise fees differ markedly between states. This is particularly the case in terms of petrol franchise fees which range from zero in Queensland to 9.7c in Western Australia.

The Democrats will support these bills. It is a good thing to move towards uniform rates of taxation across the states in as many areas as possible, especially in terms of what are colloquially known as `sin taxes'. The tax competition between the states has been largely self‐defeating. Appropriate tax policy for the states is as much in need of debate and reform as is federal tax policy.

Let us examine some of the state taxation measures available. The states bartered away their right to collect inheritance taxes, making Australia one of the few countries in the world without any taxes on wealth. The states were given payroll tax powers in 1971 by the Commonwealth, but have already bartered away about half of the revenue base there by exempting about 85 per cent of businesses from that tax. That may be applauded by those who are against taxes on employment, but it is a big decision given the financial needs of the states. More recently, led as usual by Queensland, the states bartered down hundreds of millions of dollars of revenue on stock exchange transactions.

In my view, Queensland coming cap in hand to every premiers conference and arguing disadvantage rings a bit hollow when it refuses to raise sufficient revenue on goods like petrol. It would be far more environmentally and economically responsible to do so. And, contrary to all Queensland's rhetoric, Queensland's low taxes have not led to economic growth; other factors apply there. On a per capita basis, the higher taxing states of Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales have been leaving Queensland for dead. Not just that, Queensland's low tax status has also failed to lead to quality jobs, with the wages of Queensland workers well below those of other states. In our view, the move to uniform tax rates is welcome and will help iron out phoney state tax competitiveness.

BREAK.PARA: I should note that the Queensland government has foreshadowed that it will be reimbursing all its petrol franchise to keep Queensland petrol rates low. This, in our view, is an inappropriate action, but the Queensland cost of motoring picture is not at all straightforward. Queensland has its taxes on private vehicle use completely the wrong way around. It does not charge duty on petrol, so making petrol 8c to 9c cheaper than in other states, but Queensland boasts the highest annual motor vehicle registration fees. On a standard Ford Falcon, Queenslanders pay $314 a year for the right to drive. That is $174 a year more than Victorians, $113 a year more than New South Wales people and $200 a year more than Western Australians.

To put that into perspective, a Queensland driver has to drive over 18,500 kilometres a year more than a Western Australian driver to end up lower taxed, because of Queensland's high up‐front motor vehicle registration fees. Given that most drivers drive substantially fewer kilometres than 18,500 a year, most Queensland drivers end up paying more state taxes on motoring than do Western Australians, even though Western Australians have higher petrol taxes.

For many years the Democrats have been calling for up‐front motor vehicle registration fees to be replaced by higher petrol taxes. This is classic user pays: the more you drive, the more you burn fossil fuel and add to pollution and greenhouse gas emissions, the more you should pay. Instead, Queensland opted for a very high up‐front fee but no user pays.

I find myself in complete agreement with Jeff Kennett, who proposed that the states should use the opportunity of the High Court decision to move to more uniform tax rates on an averaging principle. Under the Kennett plan, Queensland would have agreed to a petrol excise but would have dropped its massive regressive up‐front flat‐rate motor vehicle taxes. This bill gives Queensland the opportunity and the impetus to go ahead and make such an environmentally and economi cally responsible restructuring of its tax system as regards petrol charges.

This set of bills also sets up a windfall tax collection mechanism to ensure that business is not able to take financial advantage of the High Court decision, to avoid paying state fees before the federal tax. It remains a matter for the states to ensure that there is a full reimbursement of any taxes that are also paid to the Commonwealth. All states but New South Wales have now put such mechanisms into place, and the Democrats will encourage New South Wales to follow suit.

I wish to make two other comments about the High Court decision. The first is about tax reform. The Democrats do not regard the High Court decision as making any significant contribution to the debate about whether or not Australia should have a GST. Alcohol, tobacco and petrol are taxed outside a VAT in virtually all OECD countries—that is, for social and environmental reasons, these items have always been taxed higher than other goods and services. That goes back to the sin tax or moral tax version, as they are often called.

Absolutely no‐one outside of the National Party and its secular arm, the National Farmers Federation, would advocate that excises should be replaced by a GST. Let us remember that, with these bills, excise collections in total are now over $18.5 billion. That is $4 billion more than the take from the entire wholesale sales tax system. That means that abolishing excises of this kind would add about six per cent to any proposed GST rate across all other goods and services. I can assure those of my colleagues who are in the National Party that I cannot see the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) agreeing to that. If anything, the High Court case has made the possibility of a GST replacing all the taxes listed in Fightback less likely rather than more likely.

The second point I want to make is about Commonwealth‐state relations in financial terms. The thing that the High Court decision does make absolutely essential is reform of Commonwealth‐state financial relations. As a result of the decision, over 60 per cent of state finance is now based on federal funds. That is a ridiculous position to be in. On the one hand, it reinforces the long‐held Democrats view that our nine governments are a costly anachronism that should be either put to death or be radically reduced as soon as possible. They really would have no viable role to play in our overgoverned national life if local and regional government were restructured to do the job. On the other hand, if we are to have states, let us have fewer rather than more. Their financial status has to be clarified and improved. The Prime Minister seems to be saying he is stuck with whingeing state premiers who get up his nose. They, in turn, say they are stuck with their financial reliance on Canberra and the annual scrap with the federal pit bull terriers, smug and otherwise.

We need to clean up the relationship to level up the taxation and spending powers. I do not believe that it needs to be a one‐way street with Canberra simply ceding taxing powers to the states. As I said earlier, the states have proven to be in many respects poor defenders of their revenue base and they have a historical habit of giving away the powers that they were given. Further, given the small size of the Australian markets, the general failure of competitive federalism and the pressures of foreign competition, there is a strong case for uniform taxation rates.

So I emphasise that the reform of federal‐state relations should look at both taxation and spending. I cannot see any reason why, for example, the states should not hand over the public hospital system to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth already funds the vast bulk of the system through Medicare. It sets the standards for public health through Medicare and the NHMRC. It would save around $300 million to $400 million a year in state bureaucracy costs just to hand the whole thing over, and cut federal‐state grants accordingly.

Aboriginal matters and industrial relations should be handed over to the Commonwealth. Once again, we were delighted with Jeff Kennett's proposal to move industrial relations across. That made a great deal of sense to us. Those kinds of things would even out the deficit a bit more. Then we should look at giving the states a more certain and long‐term funding base for the rest of their genuinely state orientated needs. Such a plan requires not just Commonwealth‐state agreement, but also cross‐party agreement for the necessary constitutional changes and for the necessary changes in our direction. For that reason, I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this bill, asking the government to set up a conference of federal, state and local government party leaders to reach a new consensus on reform. I urge senators to support my second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have traversed an interesting debate on the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 which is now before this chamber. I am able to provide some information that Senator Sherry sought on the revenue from the sales tax and excise. The explanatory memorandum for the sales tax bills indicates that $760 million is expected to be raised from the 15 percentage point increase in the sales tax on alcohol from 1997-98. The explanatory memorandum for the excise bills indicates that $5.56 billion per annum is be expected to be raised from the increase in excise on tobacco and petroleum products.

SPEECH.PARA: I am able to provide the Senate—I think this will be of interest to Senator Sherry—with some further details on the estimated revenue collected on the basis of equivalent full year figures for 1997-98. These numbers are therefore slightly different from those appearing in the explanatory memorandums. The estimates on a full year 1997-98 basis, based on safety net arrangements as announced on 5 August, are as follows: tobacco excise, $3.26 billion; petroleum excise, $2.48 billion; and increased sales tax on alcoholic products, $914 million. The total is in the order of the $6.65 billion. I think that provides the figures that Senator Sherry was seeking.

It is always a pity that Senator Sherry cannot resist the temptation to take the odd pot shot at the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the other chamber. I think he probably feels a bit safer taking pot shots over here. Every time the shadow Treasurer, Mr Evans, takes a pot shot, he seems to end up on the floor; and the same applies to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). But I think Senator Sherry feels, from the safety of the Senate chamber, that he can perhaps try to do what his colleagues fail to do.

Senator Sherry was a bit worried about chaos following this announcement. The only chaos that I am able to detect is the chaos on the Labor Party side in relation to tax reform. It is very difficult to find a Labor Party position in relation to tax reform. Every time someone—whether it be the shadow minister for Transport, Mr Tanner, or some of the Young Turks, or even the shadow Treasurer—puts their head up to make a view the Leader of the Opposition comes out the following day and chastises them and changes his mind successively. The nation recognises the chaos which exists in the Labor Party on taxation. We commiserate with Senator Sherry for having been dropped once again as shadow Treasurer. We thought he may have been able to make a contribution to resolving this chaos, but he seems to be adding to it.

In relation to the other comments which have been made, Senator Margetts traversed a very wide range of topics. I think Senator Margetts took us back to the Magna Carta at one stage and brought us forward to the Constitutional Convention and raised a variety of issues which she thought were important. Let me say that, unlike the Labor Party, Senator Margetts is purely prepared to enter the tax reform debate. I note her views, and it is not surprising that Senator Margetts would raise issues in relation to environ mental taxes. I think Senator Margetts recognised that there were some real problems with the current tax system—as did the Australian Democrat speakers. In their remarks both the Greens and the Democrats indicated that they saw particular problems with the tax system and raised some issues which they thought should be addressed. I must say that some of these issues go far beyond these bills. Nonetheless, we are interested to receive comments.

BREAK.PARA: My old friend Senator Murray mentioned—and he will correct me if I am wrong—putting the states to death. That is a very strange thing for a Democrat senator to say. Democrat senators do not win any seats in the lower house, Senator Murray. You actually win seats in the upper house as a result of state‐wide elections. It did seem to me, Senator Murray, that you are sawing off the branch that you are sitting on. I did think it was a strange remark to come from a Democrat senator. But Senator Murray raised a lot of issues in relation to tax reform and some of the anomalies that he felt were present in the current system and could not resist taking a swipe at a number of the states.

The bills before this chamber are very important. They are bills which we need to progress quickly. I note the many comments that have been made by senators. Some of the comments I thank senators for; other comments I totally and absolutely reject. But, having said that, we can debate some of the issues which the Democrats have raised in relation to the amendments they have foreshadowed in the committee stage when they come forward.

That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) in respect of the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 be agreed to.
