SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 4 (after line 27), after item 2, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2A At the end of section 9

PARA.TAB: Add:
(2) Financial assistance to which a State is entitled under this section in relation to a grant year is granted on the condition that the Treasurer is satisfied:

TAB.TAB: (a) that amounts paid to the State will be audited by the State Auditor‐General; and
(b) that the State Auditor‐General is not subject to any direction from any person in relation to any aspect of the audit, including the planning and conduct of, and reporting on, the audit.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is essentially designed to maintain the status quo in terms of safeguards in the auditing functions currently in place in the states. The Victorian Auditor-General recently found evidence that senior members of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet spent $300,000 on corporate credit cards and breached internal procedures in doing so. He found and published evidence of possible corruption in an ambulance services contract tendering process and he criticised the government for failing to demand $174 million more in licence fees from Crown Casino after allowing Crown an extra 150 gaming tables.

The reason I mention this is that the Victorian government responded to these criticisms by ordering a review of the Audit Act and it appointed a three‐person panel to conduct that review. For the Senate's information a member of that panel is a director of the Crown Casino and is also a former director of KPMG.

The review panel recommendations were that the Auditor-General should be removed from direct control over his department and that this department be made into a government enterprise called Audit Victoria. The Auditor-General would become one of a three‐member panel which would decide whether the privatised Audit Victoria or private accounting companies would be awarded contracts for the financial audit of all government departments. Of course, the Auditor-General can be outvoted by government appointed members, that is, the other two members of the panel. The Auditor-General would be made an officer of the parliament and the budget for his office would be allocated by parliament.

The government claims its legislation will strengthen the independence of the Auditor-General. It claims it was required to conduct this review under national competition policy—and that is the key here. It claims that the Auditor-General and Audit Victoria will be more efficient and save taxpayers' money. I challenge those claims.

The office of the Auditor-General already contracts out much of its work to private auditing firms, with contract audit fees for 1995‐96, for instance, amounting to about $5.9 million. That is out of a total of $17.7 million. It is imperative that the Auditor-General have the primary responsibility for the audit function. Efficiency reviews are very often prompted by information which is gleaned during that auditing of accounts. This opportunity would be very significantly diminished if the responsibility for the audit function was spread across a number of bodies.

The most fundamental issue is that the Auditor-General's office is not just any government instrumentality. It enjoys a unique role in our system of government because its principal purpose is to assist the parliament to hold the executive government to account. In my view, the costs of performing these functions cannot be reduced without undermining its reason for existing.
The Auditor-General argues that this attempt to nobble him is an ideological experiment. I will quote from something he wrote recently. He said:

I am more convinced than ever that the direction proposed by the review team will lead to a situation in which a future parliament, if confronted by either an oppressive or a corrupt government, would be relatively impotent and not privy to information which would allow it to call such a government to account. The team's model has been postulated in a report which is devoid of empirical evidence and is characterised by unsubstantiated assertions, textual inconsistencies, uncertainty as to the likely outcomes and recommendations based on minority views.

Thousands of Victorians have openly criticised the state government over this review—including the Law Institute of Victoria and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. In fact, the latter said that there is no way that the Auditor-General under this new arrangement could protect Audit Victoria and private auditors being subjected to commercial or political pressure. They said:

The independence of auditors‐general and their contributions to open, democratic government cannot be overemphasised. A hands‐off approach by government to the role of the Auditor-General is the only acceptable way that democratic processes can be safeguarded.
In 1995 the Democrats predicted that the public sector would be forced to restructure in far‐reaching and not necessarily positive ways. We said:
The Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 . . . will force public service agencies to reassess their role, their relationship to the public, and to realign their operations.

Operators of contracted out services, executives of corporatised and privatised services and companies competing with public services will not accept the same level of public accountability for service delivery and quality that government departments accept as appropriate for ensuring the public has adequate lines of redress.

I think that we are now realising some of that potential. I would argue that this agreement between the two levels of government very conveniently has been used as a vehicle for the sort of extreme ideological position being taken by, in this case, the Victorian coalition government. I would also argue that we have in Victoria a state government which is so arrogant that it dares to demolish yet another body which Victorians knew they could rely on—all in the name of competition.

Our amendment will see that the Victorian government is not able to put at risk Commonwealth money going to the states. It is a sensible safeguard and one which would ensure that competition policy reform is not used as an excuse for secrecy and an oppor tunity for corruption. A truly independent Auditor-General in each state is a guarantee of that safeguard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General has a central place in the accountability chain and has a fundamental watchdog role in the Australian system of government. The Auditor-General's office is responsible for the external audits of the financial affairs of the Victorian public sector, for the public sector in every state and every government, and for the performance audits which assess the economy, efficiency and effectiveness of the management of public sector resources in the state.

SPEECH.PARA: It therefore plays a key role in the accountability process of the government to the parliament, and ultimately to the taxpayers and the public of Victoria. There is no doubt that Senator Allison's amendment is directed at correcting an appalling assault, in our view, on the independence and the accountability of the Auditor-General in that state.

Last year the Kennett government initiated a review into the Victorian Audit Act 1994, in line with national competition policy rules. That an accountability agency should have been dealt with in this way was extraordinary, and the move rang alarm bells in all sectors of the community concerned with accountability. The report, which was handed down in late April, intends to considerably alter, to the detriment of the people of Victoria, the powers and the role of the auditor and threatens to materially weaken our system of responsible government.
The 1992 WA Inc. royal commission emphatically stated the importance of the Auditor-General in the chain of accountability. The royal commission said:

The office of Auditor-General provides a critical link in the accountability chain between the public sector, the parliament and the community. It alone subjects the practical conduct and operations of the public sector as a whole to regular, independent investigation and review. This function must be fully guaranteed and its discharge facilitated.

Again that royal commission in 1992, which was established in the wake of allegations of corruption and illegal and improper conduct in the affairs, investment decisions and business dealings of the Labor government of Western Australia, reported on the essential nature of the independence of the Auditor-General from the government and the executive. The royal commission said:

The Auditor-General is the parliament's principal informant on the performance of the administrative system. The parliament therefore has a special responsibility to ensure both that the independence and the effective resourcing of the Auditor-General are secured.

While the Victorian report proposes to enhance the independence of the auditor by making him or her an independent officer of the parliament—which would be welcomed if it were accompanied by the financial independence of the parliament—the extensive reduction of the auditor's powers with the audit program makes the increased independence farcical. The proposal that financial audits and performance audits be conducted by private auditing firms underestimates the scope of the Auditor‐General's tasks and its function as a fundamental accountability agency.

Government and other senators here may ask whether this is the appropriate place to put an amendment which would ensure that auditors-general in the states deal properly and are able to deal properly with funds given to them by the Commonwealth on behalf of the people of Australia. We see no other place to put it. We cannot lay it down in general principles. It has to be in an act which governs the transference of money from the Commonwealth to the states. We would urge senators to consider that, if they allow the erosion of that process of accountability, that erosion of the proper auditing function, within states they are allowing the potential for corruption and improper conduct to be advanced.

No‐one in this chamber has ever wanted that to happen. But it is our view that, if those changes occur, the potential for improper conduct will indeed be enhanced, and we believe the Commonwealth has a role and a responsibility to the people of Australia to make sure that the moneys given to every government in this country are properly looked after. I therefore strongly support and commend Senator Allison's amendment to senators.

I will close with a clarification. During my contribution to the second reading debate, Minister, you asked me about my view on the governments. I have the view that nine governments are far too many for 18 million people, and I think some of those governments need to be done away with. We need fewer governments in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones?
—I am not going to tell you that here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about this particular measure, and I would ask the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) whether or not he would agree with the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants—a well‐known radical body of persons in this country—who say, in their press release of 1 August this year, that competitive cunning and the survival of the fittest may suit a market economy but are entirely inappropriate for ensuring honest government. Also, according to the CPA's Director for Accounting and Auditing, Mr Colin Parker, competition policy as enshrined in the Hilmer report was never meant to be applied to entities such as the Auditor‐General's department, whose primary function was public service. I would be concerned to establish whether or not the government was in agreement with that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to establish whether or not the Commonwealth government was in agreement with the statements of the South Australian Liberal Premier, Mr John Olsen, and the Queensland National Premier, Mr Rob Borbidge, who both rejected the proposition that auditors‐general be subject to national competition policies. They have rejected the moves being taken in Victoria in regard to undermining the independence of the Auditor‐General.

I would be concerned to know, Minister, whether or not you share that view of the governments of Queensland and South Australia or whether you share the view of your Victorian colleagues in the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party. I would also be interested to know whether or not you share the view of the New Zealand Auditor‐General, who has in fact undermined the claim by the Victorian Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett, that the reforms relating to the Auditor‐General in the state of Victoria were in fact modelled on the New Zealand example.

The New Zealand Auditor‐General was reported on 27 July 1997 as saying, `I would be uncomfortable with and would not accept such a model being forced on me.' I would ask, Minister, whether or not the Commonwealth shares that view and whether or not it believes it is appropriate that in the state of Victoria such action is being taken to undermine what is, of course, an essential part of the Westminster tradition within this case.

I would be also concerned, Minister, to establish whether or not you were concerned about the level and extent of the attempts by the Victorian government to undermine public accountability of its public officials in that state. I would be concerned to know whether or not you supported the sackings of judges and quasi‐judicial officers that have occurred in this state; whether or not you were supportive of the way in which the Kennett government hounded statutory appointees from office and the way in which it delayed democratic elections in local government; whether or not you were supportive of the way in which it forced out of office the Commissioner of Equal Opportunity and the Director of Public Prosecutions in that state, and the way in which it sought to and succeeded in weakening the parliamentary committee system in this state.

I would be concerned to know whether or not this government actually supported the actions taken in Victoria to silence critics within the education system, to prevent teachers making public comment on important issues in regard to eduction, and to prevent doctors making public comment on the hospital system in the state of Victoria. I would be concerned to know whether or not this government supported the actions taken by the Victorian government to remove from various acts of parliament in the state of Victoria on some hundred occasions the right of appeal to the Supreme Court.

Of course, I would be concerned to know whether or not Minister Kemp supported the general attacks upon the democratic rights and freedoms in this state which saw the Auditor‐General, the last bastion of independent thought in that state, brought to heel in the manner in which this Premier sought to do.

Let us recall some of the reports that the Auditor‐General in Victoria drew to public attention. He drew to public attention the blatant corruption that occurs in that state between the various agencies of government, the links with big business and the manner in which the legislative process had been subverted by the Liberal Party in the state of Victoria. We have seen that, for instance, in the case of the casino licence. We have seen misuse of the community support fund through the casino and misuse of political advertising. We have seen the corrupt practices that have taken place in regard to the granting of the Leeds Media contract and the actions taken with land developers to secure school sites in the state of Victoria, to secure the profits for speculators. That is now a longstanding practice in that state, with its having occurred over the last four years. We have also seen the abuse of child protection.

Of course, we have seen the corrupt practices that have been exposed in regard to the ambulance contracts in that state. We have seen the public hospital system completely destroyed by the cutbacks that have been made in that state, and the corrupt practices that have taken place in regard to the administration of the health portfolio in that state. I would be concerned to know whether or not Minister Kemp supported those actions.

I would also be concerned to know whether or not it was the case that this government acknowledged that no other state in the Commonwealth was pursuing these sorts of policies. No other government in this country is prepared to adopt the actions that the Kennett government is prepared to adopt to subvert the democratic process and undermine the fundamental principles on which government throughout the rest of the country is undertaken. What we have here is a funda mental principle, the independence of the office of the Auditor-General, being quite seriously attacked in the state of Victoria. It is quite clear that what we see before us are actions being taken by the state of Victoria which I think really put at risk some pretty basic principles about the freedoms and the rights of citizens in this country. Minister, give us some reasons why we should not support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendment. This amendment really potentially poses a serious threat to the funding arrangements for the states. The financial assistance to be paid to the states under this bill is untied and is being provided in accordance with agreements reached at the Premiers Conference and the safety net arrangements which are vital to protecting states' interests. It is entirely inappropriate to seek any change to any part of these arrangements by placing restrictions on payments which form a large part of the states' revenues. I think the states would naturally oppose an imposition on these grants as a matter of principle and we will certainly not be supporting the amendment that you have moved. In relation to Senator Carr's wide, rambling speech, which I think I have heard about 40 times in this chamber—
—You've learned nothing, though.
—Senator, I know this will be difficult for you to understand, but one of the reasons why the Liberal Party is so dominant in our great state of Victoria—
—Because it's got heaps of dough from the casino; heaps of dough coming out of the casino.
—Just wait, Senator Carr.
—It's like a great cash box for the Liberal Party.

—You have had a chance to throw a few stones, so just wait, Senator Carr. One of the reasons why this party is so dominant in our great state is the performance of the previous government, the so-called guilty party. Who was the senior adviser to the guilty party? None other than Senator Kim Carr. It is not me that is being critical of you. It is your former Premier. Your former Premier, John Cain, blew the whistle on you and revealed what a disaster your—
—A senior adviser to John Cain? He'd be pleased to hear that.

—I will get the book and make an adjournment speech on it if you like, if you want to really provoke me. You do not want me to say that? Okay, I will not. I refer people to John Cain's book. If you look for `Kim Carr' in the index, you will see the damage that Kim Carr wrought in Victoria. That of course added to the issue of the guilty party and led to the incredible Liberal triumph in that state. Senator Carr, it ill becomes you to get up and complain about this government; it really does. Deep in our hearts, Senator Carr—
—Minister, address your comments through the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. Deep in our hearts we know that one of the people we can be thankful for is you, Kim Carr. You are one of those people. For you to get up and rant and rave about the Kennett government is a joke. I accept none of the assumptions that you have made in your speech. I have learnt a couple of things as a minister. When you get up and read quotes, I want to see all the quotes. I am well used to the selective nature of the way you read out press releases. So, Senator Carr, we accept nothing of what you have said. You have rambled on as usual—
—One hundred laws haven't been changed? Corruption doesn't exist? What about corruption?
—with this particular obsession that you have.
—Minister, I ask you to address your comments through the chair rather than directly to Senator Carr.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. Senator Carr, I understand that you feel bitter that your period in government in Victoria was such a disaster and has led to a government in that state which is widely respected.
—So corrupt.

—We noticed with the casino inquiry how the Labor Party backed out at a rate of knots. Let us not forget that, Senator Carr. You tried to get up a casino inquiry. Your own party would not appoint you to it and then the Labor Party backed off at the rate of knots. Nothing was sustained; there was no evidence. You come in here, the old cowards' castle, and yell and scream and abuse people. You are entitled to that. But I always remember the Robert Ray principle: 10 yards to courage. You can walk outside, make those comments and see how you go. It is as simple and as straightforward as that, Senator.
—It doesn't change the truth, does it?

—You had your chance with your inquiry and you failed to put up. Therefore, decency would require you to accept defeat on this issue. If you want to pursue it, as I say, it is 10 yards to courage; the old Ray principle, 10 yards to courage. Go out the door, make the same comments and slander and abuse people; but it does not wash, Senator. It has not helped you get on the front bench. We know why you are not on the front bench.
—He is on the front bench.
—Is he a shadow minister?
—He is a parliamentary secretary. We know why you are on the front bench.
—Senator Carr, we know why you are not a shadow minister, they know why you are not a shadow minister, but I wish someone would tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor is very seriously concerned by and my colleague Senator Carr has very eloquently and correctly outlined the appalling situation that exists in Victoria with the Auditor-General. Senator Carr knows in much more detail than I do, because I come from Tasmania and he is a Victorian senator, the level of corruption in Victoria. It is not an issue I intend to go into, as a Tasmanian senator. As well as I know Senator Carr, I was not aware that he was an economic adviser in the former state Labor government. But I do know that he was a very effective adviser in the area of education and training policy.
—He's done Amanda over every day in the chamber.

—That is right, and her junior minister, Dr Kemp, in the other place; your brother, Senator Kemp. We all know that the Kemp brothers are ambitious. We all know the role you had in contributing to former Senator Short's demise, Senator Kemp. We all know the role you had. You have now got his job, after ruthlessly pushing him aside.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are talking about advisers, I mention someone I went to university with. He was a member of the Liberal Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Still is.

—Still is; he is very active. He is a person whom I have a regard for because of his integrity and honesty. We do not agree on a lot of economic issues but I do respect his integrity and honesty. I am talking about the previous Kennett government adviser and economist Saul Eslake. He is also a friend of Senator Eric Abetz. We were contemporaries at university. He said in respect of this Auditor-General issue:

SPEECH.PARA: It ought, in my view, be beyond argument that the final decision as to who conducts an audit must be taken by the Auditor-General.

I am sure you know Mr Eslake. I can tell by the smile on your face. Mr Eslake is one of a number of leading people who cannot possibly be considered partisan Labor: Associate Professor of Law at the University of Melbourne Geoff Lindell, University of Melbourne economist Dr Neville Norman and that great socialist organisation, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. I have a full press release here. I could read the whole thing out, Senator Kemp, if you are concerned about accuracy and me misquoting it, but I will read just one paragraph because of time:

BREAK.PARA: According to the CPA's director of accounting and audit, Mr Colin Parker, competition policy as enshrined by the Hilmer report was never meant to be applied to entities such as the Auditor-General's Department, whose primary function was public service.

And if it is, why doesn't the Commonwealth government initiate changes to the Auditor-General's Act in respect of competition policy? I would be surprised if I saw that one come forward. We are very concerned about the situation in Victoria with the Auditor-General. For two reasons we will not be supporting the amendment that has been foreshadowed. One is that this legislation is extremely urgent. We need to get it through by 12.45 p.m.. We are talking about very serious consequences for the revenue of all states if it is not passed quickly and urgently. We believe it is inappropriate to tack on a measure like this to a piece of revenue legislation. We may consider it in respect of the Auditor-General's bill that will come before the Senate. That would be a more appropriate place to consider—to consider, I might emphasise—this sort of approach. But it is very difficult in this type of legislation to be tacking on provisions about state auditors-general. I have concerns about Queensland and the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —And South Australia.

—South Australia, yes. I accept the seriousness of the problem in Victoria, but it is not just Victoria. We all remember the Bjelke-Petersen years. I say this seriously to the Democrats and the Greens: why not consider this issue in the context of the Auditor-General's bill which we will be receiving shortly? Why not be examining and perhaps imposing regimes on the states in respect of all their auditing procedures? I am not committing the Labor Party to that—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Allison interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You may smile, but if we are serious about the issues associated with state auditors-general surely it is an issue we should look at in a total state and territory context. Victoria might be rotten in this regard but I am sure that some of the things I have seen in the Northern Territory, Queensland and South Australia need examining as well. So I am concerned that the Green and Democrat amendment does not go far enough in that regard.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Kemp, you did give us the revenue full year effect—thank you for that—regarding tobacco, petroleum and alcohol. It comes to about $6.65 billion. We do know the states lost $5 billion. That is a difference of $1.65 billion, obviously to be refunded.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in a full year.

—In a full year. Will there be any monitoring of the way the states go about this? Will there be a report back to parliament at some appropriate time by one of the parliamentary or Senate committees about the way in which this issue is handled? There is some distrust of the refund process. It would assist us if you could explain what sort of mechanism there is going to be regarding the ongoing surveillance reporting procedures and the way this whole measure is going to operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the minister attacked me during the last division on the basis that a division was called for wasting time yet we have had the baiting, if you like, of the ALP in this debate, which has wasted more time than the four minutes it took to get a vote on an important issue. However, I will be quick.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of states grants being more and more untied automatically would indicate that it is more necessary now than it ever was to make sure that those funds are properly, responsibly and independently audited. If ever there is an argument that that should be done it is when the grants are of an untied nature. I find it extraordinarily hypocritical of people to come in and say that without providing the funding for the sufficient training of ATSIC officers to do all the auditing that is required by government—there is an expectation that it is done on every last dollar of ATSIC funding, which is fine—you can provide untied grants to state and territory governments and not demand specific auditing requirements.

That is important when you think of specific issues such as Aboriginal spending. We have very clear examples there of allocation of funds—lumps of money given by the federal government to state and territory governments—on the basis of such things as the people in their state and territory in remote and regional areas and the number of people who might need special assistance with health or education, including indigenous Australians. And yet there is no auditing to see whether or not the funds allocated in general for those purposes are actually spent for those purposes. I find the hypocrisy of that absolutely unbelievable. So I indicate that I will support the Democrats' amendments on this issue, and I will look forward to hearing the debate on the bills relating to the Auditor‐General, to see whether or not a similar amendment is supported then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to some of Senator Kemp's comments.
—Provocative comments.

—Yes. Victoria is a state that is becoming more and more corrupt by the day, and the corruption stems from the top. I wholeheartedly agree with the sentiments of this amendment and congratulate Senator Allison for bringing it before the Senate for debate.

SPEECH.PARA: You have a situation where the Premier of Victoria has systematically closed down any scrutiny of government. You have a Victorian parliament that barely sits—40 days a year he bothers to let it sit! That is contempt for democratic process.
You have a Premier who has directed his ministers not to appear on the ABC's 7.30 Report. Nobody is allowed to go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —No questions asked.

—No‐one is allowed to ask any questions. Today Tonight tried to do a story about some of the Premier's antics. What happened? All the journalists involved and all the people involved behind the scenes—the producers—are no longer with Today Tonight . Today Tonight even tried to make it up to the Premier by trying to get him to come on the show on a weekly basis to endorse the program. It is extraordinary but true.

BREAK.PARA: Recently we have seen the Premier at it again. There have been reports of his weekly phone calls to the management of the Age—the board of directors—to sack Guthrie: `It's a Labor Party rag. We want a new editor in charge of the Age.' He phoned and phoned, and in the end they caved in.

We have seen the DPP muzzled and destroyed by none other than that independent individual who has now been appointed to the Constitutional Convention—Greg Craven. He did the job on the DPP for Jeff Kennett. He made sure that the DPP did not cite Kennett on contempt in the Elliott matters—one of your favourites, Senator Kemp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Address your remarks through the chair, Senator Conroy, and do not direct them directly to senators opposite.
—I appreciate the advice. I heard, Senator Kemp, through you, Mr Deputy President—
—The corruption.
—What about the corruption involved with the casino process? If you want to ask one question of your mate Lloyd, give him a ring, Senator, and say, `Sea World.' See what reaction you get.

BREAK.PARA: We have had senior police forced to sign contracts which have taken away their genuine independence—contracts which say that they are not allowed to comment on the resources they are given or on policy. We now have a situation with the Auditor‐General where there is a running campaign by the Premier to close the final independent institution that has some capacity to scrutinise the Victorian government.

But at last some members of the Liberal Party in Victoria have stood up—and not on an issue to do with paint ball, where they almost rolled the Premier. These are the big issues in Victoria—the Premier almost loses on paint ball weekend war games. But the backbenchers actually stood up and started to say, `Just a minute, we're a bit uncomfortable here. The Auditor‐General is an independent authority and should not be gutted in this way.' We have had the President of the Victorian Legislative Council and the Speaker of the Victorian parliament expressing their concerns about what the Premier is up to. We have had backbenchers threatening to resign from the party in Victoria and being stood over by the Premier. That is the sort of government we have in Victoria, and that is why the sentiments of this amendment deserve support from everybody in the chamber.

I would have to agree with Senator Sherry that the more appropriate place for this debate is during debate on another bill, but I thank the Democrats and Senator Allison for giving the Senate the opportunity to discuss these issues. We hope that we will get a further opportunity during debate on another bill to continue this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a couple of the remarks that were made during the debate. Senator Kemp says that this is a threat to the agreements between the federal government and the states, but I suggest that all states, aside from Victoria, would welcome this very much.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Senate's attention to the recent review in Western Australia of their Auditor‐General's functions. It said: `The parliament should appropriate resources for the Auditor‐General to audit as he thinks fit and take a role in determining the budget of the office separate to the executive.' In New South Wales, much the same thing happened. Their review said: `All possible measures should be taken to strengthen the independence of the Auditor‐General from central government.' The former Commonwealth Auditor‐General, John Taylor, and the former state ombudsman, Norm Geschke vigorously opposed these changes. I could give you a very long list of people who are similarly opposed and appalled.

It does not affect the agreements with the states; in fact, all states would currently fall in line with such a provision. What we are saying is that we want to remove a threat, not threaten anything which is existing. We want to maintain the status quo. So I think it is quite wrong of the government to suggest that this would be in any way a threat to anybody.

BREAK.PARA: More than anything else, I am disappointed with the response of the ALP. Senator Conroy tells us that every day there is more and more corruption in the Victorian state parliament, that they have closed down scrutiny, but these words ring hollow in the Senate. Most of what he says is irrelevant anyway to today's debate. I have to say, too, that I think there will be a number of people in the ALP in Victoria who will be very disappointed that the ALP in the Senate has shown such weakness.

This is a relevant place in which to introduce this kind of safeguard. I will certainly be looking forward to the role that the ALP will play when we come to the Auditor‐General's bill but, as far as I can see, this is not an appropriate place to deal with the question of the Victorian Auditor‐General. I would be happy if someone would correct me on that, but from my reading of the situation that would be totally inappropriate.

I have shared platforms with a number of people from the ALP in the past few months in the many public meetings that have been held in Victoria about the Auditor‐General, and it will come as some surprise to the audiences who have turned up in their hundreds, and their thousands in some cases, to learn that the ALP is not willing to take this very small step which would put in place those safeguards that it has supposedly been calling for.

It is all very well for Senator Conroy to talk about the sentiment of the amendment. We are not here to talk about sentiments, though; we are talking about a substantial amendment which will do what Senators Carr, Conroy and Sherry have been saying they would like to see in place. But they are too afraid or too unwilling—I am not sure what the reason is. They make many excuses for not actually taking that step. I have to say that I am sorely disappointed in their response.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

What I would like is some sort of report given to the parliament about the way in which the legislation—which will be passed, as you know—operates and its effect and the outcomes. We would like a report to parliament on this.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one other matter that has been drawn to my attention to do with liquor wholesaling and retailing.

SPEECH.PARA: Just before I get in to the detail of this, because it is a complex matter, Senator Allison referred to the approach of Labor. As I said earlier, we have serious concerns about the Auditor‐General and proposals in Victoria for change, but we have similar concerns about state expenditure in respect of some other states. It seems to me that, if the Senate has a role in that process at all, you do need to examine the Auditor‐General arrangements in all states, whether they are satisfactory or unsatisfactory. If we come to the conclusion that they are unsatisfactory, not just in Victoria but in a number of other states or territories, it requires a comprehensive approach. I do not think there is any sense in attempting to fix up one problem in Victoria that I cert ainly think exists in a number of states and territories.

It needs to be done in a measured way. This may be a very good issue for a Senate reference. I think it would be very worthwhile. It there were then subsequent amendments in the Senate demanding greater transparency and accountability in the states through the Auditor‐General's arrangements, the appropriate mechanism to deal with that is the Auditor‐General legislation.

I have a question for Senator Kemp. We have had drawn to our attention a problem in relation to liquor wholesaling and retailing. I illustrate it by way of an example. I understand there is a group called the Davids group, and it is associated with Australian Liquor Marketers Pty Ltd—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, we are dealing with the states grants amendment bill. I think the matter you are raising may be on the other bills, and I think we should discuss it under those general bills.
—Okay. I am sure the minister's advisers are aware of this particular problem—
—Our advisers will give you some advice.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 5 (after line 4), at the end of section 10, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) The Treasurer must deduct an amount under subsection (1) if the State has not reached an agreement with the body representing local government authorities in that State on the manner in which the amount of financial assistance grant is to be shared between the State and local government authorities in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told in 1995 that the national competition policy would have to involve local government if it was to penetrate into every level of government activity. The federal government took the stick and carrot approach and put in place incentives to make that happen. One of those incentives is a reward or a bonus of $250 million, which is intended to be shared by the states for their competitive achievements and to help promote further competition endeavours.

The Democrats have said many times that competition does not necessarily lead to better outcomes. We do not hold the same view as the major parties that the marketplace has all the answers. We think that there is a very significant role for public services and for public servants. We also think that it is important that the decisions about how and by whom services are delivered should be made by weighing up all the advantages and disadvantages. We do not accept that the private for profit models are always applicable and we do not accept that the public sector is inherently inefficient, needing only a bit of competition to get it to lift its game.

However, having said all that, competition policy is now a reality. In states such as Victoria, competition policy has been compulsorily imposed on every council in the state. By law, councils must contract out 50 per cent of their total expenditure. Because total expenditure includes everything from interest on bank loans to depreciation to executive salaries, and because all of it must be counted in the equation, the effect is to force councils to contract out around 80 per cent or more of their actual services. In many councils the figure is much higher than that. This is particularly so in the more remote councils where that amount can be over 100 per cent.

Whilst Mr Kennett's commissioners controlled all of local government in the state with the exception of Queenscliff Council, they saw to it that services would not be excluded from the process at all. So maternal and child health services, meals on wheels, parks and gardens, planning and libraries all went out to tender. Even the most economic rationalist country in the world—Thatcher's Britain—drew the line at libraries and maternal and child health services. In the first round, the majority of in‐house teams actually won their tenders but not before services had been reduced and salaries and conditions were lost.

The cost to local government in real dollars has been very high. Spending on consultancies to draw up specifications, creating a new bureaucratic level within councils to administer contracts, and dividing councils into so‐called `client' and `provider' organisations has been very high. For a medium sized council such as that in Ballarat, the cost is around a million dollars a year just to put in that bureaucracy. In other councils, the promised savings from contracting out have not eventuated. The council to which I pay my rates budgeted for a $2 million saving but it turned out to be a cost of $2 million, and it is $4 million worse off than it expected. By and large, the state government has kept the lid on the very variable successes of this brave new world of competition policy in local government. Councils have been told to put up and shut up or to run the risk of, again, being sacked just as Darebin council was a few weeks ago.

The point I want to make here is that the implementation of competition policy has not been all beer and skittles. It has often been very painful, and it has been very costly. I have been to countless small towns that have had the stuffing knocked out of their economies because their particular council has gone altogether from their midst through amalgamation, and with it has gone the handful of jobs that made the difference between sustainability and otherwise. When you combine the huge job losses in local government at the grassroots level with the job losses of the downsizing experts in the areas of banking and state and federal government agencies, the pain is very deeply felt indeed. Contracts are won by big and even bigger businesses, and the towns lose jobs in favour of regions and then the regions lose out again to capital cities.

The downside of competition is the very real fact that competitors aim to rid themselves of competition, and it tends to be an opportunity not for small business but rather for bigger business and for cities. As for local government, very often there is no going back. It is very doubtful that a council would ever be able to re‐enter the garbage collection business or maternal and child health services field down the track. Those trucks and health centres have been sold off very often at bargain basement prices, and the council's being able to again afford expensive infrastructure is very unlikely.

The Democrats believe that the federal government should recognise not just the difficulties and the costs of entering competition policy reform but also the risks and the ongoing costs, and they are, of course, social as well as monetary ones in many cases. It should show more than a passing interest in how its competition reforms are progressing at the local level, and it should insist that the states do not trample on councils by using only that stick approach, as Victoria has already done.

I recommend that the Senate acquaint itself with the agreement that was drawn up earlier this year between the Queensland state government, the Local Government Association of Queensland and the Brisbane City Council. It is entitled National competition policy: financial incentive package for local governments. This document affirms the commitment for two levels of government to work together in a cooperative manner. It says:

The Government recognises that local government is a separate and autonomous sphere of government and each respective council is ultimately responsible for the introduction of competition reforms at a local government level . . .

It is worth noting that this agreement specifically rejects the notion of compulsion on local governments to introduce competitive tendering or to privatise any of their activities. The financial arrangement in this document is as follows:

The Government proposes to set aside an amount of $150M of its "bonus" competition payments . . . from the Commonwealth for allocation amongst those local governments which implement NCP reforms. This amount to be indexed annually.

So this $150 million in Queensland will be used for training and assistance to local government to conduct reviews and to act as an incentive. I think I can guarantee that competition policy reform in Queensland will be implemented in a way that is far more sensible, far more sensitive to local needs and, at the end of the day, much more lasting than it has been in Victoria.

The amendment that I have put today insists that state governments put in place agreements, such as this one in Queensland, with their local government organisations. Western Australia, as I understand it, has also entered into arrangements for agreeing on something similar. This is Commonwealth money, and it is an opportunity for the federal government to put into action some of its rhetoric on local government and, for once, to show that it is willing to embrace a meaningful partnership.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Last night I missed a division in the Senate. The reason was that I was attending a function in the Great Hall. While the message came through, the beeper did not beep while I was in there. Further more, when I inquired this morning about why there were no bells ringing in the Great Hall, I was informed that the bells were turned off.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring this matter to the attention of the Senate and, first of all, request that something be done about making sure the bells are left on at all venues throughout the parliament while either or both houses are sitting. Secondly, in talking to other senators, it appears that in the Great Hall there is often a problem in picking up the messages coming through. I wonder whether there is a technical problem in that area. If so, something should be done about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Gibson. I will certainly refer that to the President and see what the appropriate action should be to rectify the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Yesterday in discussions with Senator Faulkner, I undertook to provide the Senate with a briefing on the contract let by my department with South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd under the training for employment program. I indicated yesterday that I hoped to come back to the estimates committee or the Senate with the fullest possible answers because I am determined to get to the bottom of this issue. I am not in a position to do that today. I will come back with more information when the picture is clearer. Today I will address all of the outstanding matters raised by Senator O'Brien in the Senate last week.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter needs to be considered in two parts. The first relates to the likely outcomes under the contract. Let me put on the record the picture as I am advised at this point. In summary, some 290 trainees will soon complete the onshore component of the training intended under this contract. The contract was extended on 20 August for a few weeks from 29 August to 12 September to enable one element of the training to be delivered. The Commonwealth will pay no additional mon eys to either South Pacific Cruise Lines or William Angliss as a result of that extension.

I understand that those offered employment by the company will be flying to Singapore at no additional cost to the Commonwealth. There is a final training component funded under the contract which must be completed on board the ship. The trainees, at that stage, will be employees of South Pacific Cruise Lines and no longer eligible for formal training assistance. I am not in a position to say at this point whether South Pacific Cruise Lines will complete the ship‐based training.

The arrangements made with the company and with William Angliss 2000, the principal training provider, have already resulted in a substantial number of formally case managed or long-term unemployed job seekers receiving accredited training and in all likelihood the opportunity to secure a job that may not otherwise have come their way. Indeed, if anything, the likelihood of success is stronger now than when the original arrangements were entered into, because the department has received assurances from the training provider to assist with the placement of those who successfully complete the course should they not be offered a job by South Pacific Cruise Lines.

This assurance was first given on 16 June this year and reconfirmed to the department on 28 August. Clearly, I have serious concerns about the process which I will address shortly. However, the trainees have had substantial training and are in a good position to obtain employment in the tourism industry even if employment with South Pacific Cruise Lines does not eventuate.

The second part of this matter concerns the process which led to the letting of the contract. The original proposal emanated from William Angliss 2000 in late January 1977. William Angliss 2000 is a reputable training provider with experience in delivering under contracts with DEETYA. The details of the training arrangements, including the unit cost, were settled between the department and William Angliss. South Pacific Cruise Lines was a participant in these processes since they were the intended employer once the proposed training had been provided.

BREAK.PARA: Towards the end of negotiations that began in January I am advised that South Pacific Cruise Lines proposed, and DEETYA and William Angliss agreed, that they should be the principal to the contract. The principal explanation provided for this request to date is that it would assist to lock in the links with the potential employer and that, from the company's perspective, it would help SPCL with their prospectus. I am not entirely satisfied with that explanation.

William Angliss's agreement was conditional on them remaining the training subcontractor and project manager. I understand that on 16 May a contract was signed between the department and SPCL covering the period 23 June to 29 August. The full amount of the contract was $2,794,799.

Under the arrangements that were agreed, 80 per cent of the contract sum was provided to South Pacific Cruise Lines as an advance payment. I understand that all but $700,000 of this sum has now been paid by South Pacific Cruise Lines to William Angliss. This $700,000 is not yet due for payment. The advance payment was made at a time when there was evidence of the bona fides of the parties involved in that a substantial training program had been designed and the process for the selection of trainees was well advanced.
By 5 June, the date of the advance payment, some 200 of the eventual 340 commencing trainees had been selected. That exercise was completed by 16 June, in time for the training to start on the 23rd.

It is not lost on me, as it is no doubt not lost on senators, that at that point those associated with South Pacific Cruise Lines could have pocketed the advance and disappeared. That is a serious process issue. The fact that South Pacific Cruise Lines did not take that course of action, and that we are now in a position where the vast bulk of the training has been delivered, perhaps points to a positive outcome, despite the shortcomings of the process. The remaining 20 per cent of the contract sum is only payable in the event that 70 per cent of the commencing trainees are employed for a period of at least six weeks following the completion of the training.

I believe that the decision to make so large an advance payment—amounting to some $2.2 million—entails an unacceptable risk for a contract of that size, when the principals and their financial credentials are unknown. I am informed that it reflected a judgment by the DEETYA officers concerned that the payment would both assist in securing the employment outcomes and assist the company in launching its proposed prospectus. I note for the information of senators that, to date, no prospectus has been issued.

Let me make my position on that point very clear: I do not believe that it is the role of government training programs to be making a payment to a company in order to improve the appearance of a potential prospectus. Advance payments are permitted under the program guidelines, but are intended to be applied more restrictively than was the case on this occasion. The department is revising the guidelines of this program to prevent future advance payments of this size being made, unless the financial risk has been appropriately assessed.

No financial checks were made at this time regarding South Pacific Cruise Lines—a company which had been in existence only since December 1996—or of its principals. This is clearly inexcusable, not to mention being inconsistent with the relevant guidelines. I understand, however, that the officers concerned relied heavily on the security afforded by the involvement of William Angliss, which is well known to the department, in forming their judgments.

The officers involved were also conscious of the Queensland government's clear support for the establishment of a cruise ship industry to be based in that state and the potential benefits of securing employment for potential trainees. Nonetheless, the officers concerned agree that they should have been more rigorous in the application of the guidelines.

The department reviewed the arrangements in light of adverse media reports around mid‐June. This included some financial checks to confirm that the moneys advanced under the contract were being expended in accordance with the contract.

The conclusion at that time was that there was no breach by SPCL that would justify termination of the contract—and, indeed, there has been no breach to date—and that termination on other grounds would lead to possible claims for damages by the company and certain damage to the employment prospects of a large number of unemployed people. Indeed, the trainees had been selected and training was commencing on 23 June; and William Angliss had given the department an assurance that it would assist with the placement of trainees not offered a place by South Pacific Cruise Lines at the conclusion of the training. Nevertheless, it was decided to monitor the performance of the contract closely.

It was around this time that the matter was raised in the Courier‐Mail. As a result, my office made inquiries of the department's Queensland central area office and on 12 June received a brief report from, and prepared in, that office concerning the arrangements. My office soon after requested a further brief from the national office. Some information was provided informally and as material for question time.

I now have a preliminary report on this matter, and this statement is largely based on the contents of that report. Senators and, indeed, I, have also questioned the average cost per trainee. I understand from the investigations which have been undertaken to date by the department that there are substantial gaps in the documentary record regarding the progress of negotiations and the justification for the unit price finally agreed. Because investigations are still proceeding, I am simply unable to answer questions on these aspects as fully as I would like at this stage.

The secretary of DEETYA has arranged for an experienced auditor and an experienced investigator to be in Queensland at present to make further inquiries of departmental officers involved, as well as representatives of William Angliss and, as appropriate, South Pacific Cruise Lines. Until those inquiries have been completed there is little more that I can say about that element of the process. It is, however, clearly unsatisfactory that the documentary record is so unclear.

I will report further in light of these inquiries at a time that is mutually convenient. I do, of course, agree that should the estimates committee wish to reconvene we will provide all the relevant information and, in that event, timing of mutual convenience and the availability of sufficient relevant information will be important. I am sure that senators will want to address a number of questions to departmental officers at that stage.

It is clear that the processes that were followed were simply unacceptable. The secretary will take these matters up further with the relevant officers once the facts have been more fully established. Allegations regarding the alleged fundraising activities of South Pacific Cruise Lines with US based interests—casinos et al.—go beyond the specific interests of my portfolio and the investigative capacity of my department.

In concluding these remarks let me assure the Senate that my understanding is that, at this point, no Commonwealth funds have been lost, nor has the originally contracted sum been exceeded. There is some further outstanding training required under the contract which is yet to be delivered. In the event that the outstanding training is not delivered—which is not to suggest that I have formed a view that it will not be; it is just in the event that the outstanding training is not delivered—the Commonwealth will either make a claim against South Pacific Cruise Lines to recover that portion or seek to withhold the outstanding 20 per cent payment, as appropriate. By all accounts the hospitality training is complete and the remainder is on the way to completion. Back in June, action was taken to strengthen the level of assurance provided to the Commonwealth, notably because of William Angliss's undertaking to assist with the placement of those trainees or any trainees who did not secure employment with SPCL.

I would repeat: this information is as I am advised at this point. If there is any change that needs to be made I will, of course, advise the Senate. I repeat that I will, in any event, come back when the picture is clearer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is obviously a matter of great significance and serious concern to the opposition and opposition senators. I thank the minister for at least providing a preliminary explanation of the events surrounding the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs's contracting with South Pacific Cruise Lines for training under the employment program.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons that opposition senators have been questioning the minister on this issue I think have now become very clear indeed. We have a situation where the minister has just reported to the parliament that, in relation to the contracting with South Pacific Cruise Lines, no financial checks were made by the department at the time these arrangements were undertaken. The minister has reinforced our concerns about that by indicating to the Senate that this is a company which had been in existence only since December 1996. Also, the minister has informed the Senate that the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs failed to make any checks in relation to the principals of South Pacific Cruise Lines.
Let me quote the words that the minister has used in the chamber this afternoon on this matter:
This is clearly inexcusable, not to mention being inconsistent with the relevant guidelines.
I am concerned that the minister would not be providing such a report to the parliament except for the insistence of opposition senators on this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.

—I take the interjection from the minister, who says that is not true. The reason the minister is in here is that she has been forced in here as a result of debate in this chamber yesterday. I find that a most extraordinary comment from you, minister. On reflection, even you might consider your statement to be outlandish in these circumstances. There are significant issues here that will require close parliamentary scrutiny and that will require answers from the minister and from the government.

BREAK.PARA: According to the minister's statement, the issue was apparently raised by the minister's office in June. That had not been made clear when the estimates committee dealt with this particular matter on 19 August. The minister's office and the minister became involved as a result of the issue being raised in the Courier‐Mail. The minister reports to us that her office made inquiries of the department's Queensland central area office and that on 12 June she received a report from, and prepared in, that office concerning these particular matters. I was surprised to hear that because that information has not previously been made available. Certainly, the involvement of the minister and the minister's office was not made clear during the hearings of the Senate estimates committee. I request that the minister provide to the Senate today the report that was made available to her and received on 12 June.

I also note that the minister has indicated that she received a further brief from the national office. She has indicated to us that there was some additional information provided informally and as material for question time. I assume `informally' would mean that this is not written material. The minister nods, and I accept that that is the case. I assume the material for question time that she referred to in her statement is likely to have been a question time brief or a possible parliamentary question or the like. The minister indicates that that is the case.

As far as the formal brief, described in the minister's statement as `a further brief from national office', is concerned, that ought to be provided to the Senate and provided today. I would also request that the minister provide the preliminary report on this matter. I do note that the statement that she has made to the Senate has been largely based on the contents of that report. In these circumstances, that ought to be made available to the Senate.

One of the things I canvassed with the minister yesterday was the possible need for the estimates committee to reconvene on this particular matter. I note that the minister has indicated that she would agree to a reconvening of the estimates committee. That is an important acknowledgment on her part.

The issue that the minister raised about timing of mutual convenience is important, but I think it is reinforced very much by the fact that she has indicated to the Senate today that the secretary to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has made arrangements for both, as I understand, an experienced auditor and an experienced investigator, although I am not entirely clear whether they are one and the same person. The minister has just indicated that they are not. So both an auditor and an investigator will be in Queensland making further inquiries with, one assumes, departmental officers as well as others from outside the department about these particular issues.

It does strikes me that, for us to ensure that these matters are properly canvassed at the forum of a Senate estimates committee, it would be sensible that those particular investigations and inquiries were concluded before we undertake that particular process of reconvening the estimates committee.

I do think it is important that we hear from the minister today—I hope when I sit down—about what she believes is a likely reporting date in relation to both the auditor and the investigator. I think that is essential information for the Senate to have available as we make some assessments about how this might proceed.

I want to stress the seriousness of this issue. In the minister's own words, it is clear that the processes that were followed were simply unacceptable. That of course is of great significance not only in this particular case but I think it brings into question a whole range of internal processes in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs under the stewardship of Senator Vanstone. Those are matters that the opposition intends to progress.

I think that any reasonable person, having heard the qualified partial explanation of Senator Vanstone, would have major concerns not only about the issue of the South Pacific Cruise Line's contract with the department for this training but also I think there will be a need for the parliament and the community to be satisfied that arrangements are in place at a departmental level to ensure that this sort of circumstance never happens again. Any minister worth his or her salt would be in the business of ensuring that we do not have a repeat of this particular circumstance. We will be interested to hear in the future what the minister plans to do to ensure that there is no repeat of this particular circumstance.

There are many questions that remain unanswered by the minister's statement. The opposition accepts, however, that there are some matters that are better progressed at an estimates committee and accepts the point that was made in the chamber yesterday by Senator Vanstone that, even with the best will in the world, there may be some matters that she was unable to complete a report and investigation on prior to the end of this parliamentary sitting period. I did accept that yesterday and I accept now that that is the case.

I want to say this: we have fundamental concerns with what occurred after this had been brought to the attention of the minister's office. We want to know what this minister did, how she did it and what exercise of her ministerial responsibilities occurred after 12 June through to the period of the estimates committee, which was the first opportunity that opposition senators had to take this matter further. I can assure the minister that we will be progressing those matters.

Here we have a situation where serious concerns were raised not only in the media but also in the state parliament of Queensland about this issue. At no time were senators informed by the minister as she responded to questions at the estimates committee on 19 August that her office had received a report on this particular matter that had been generated by her office as a result of the press article which appeared in the Courier‐Mail.

The minister has indicated that she has concerns about this. We have very serious concerns about this. We have very serious concerns about not only what occurred at the level of your department, minister, but about what has happened at the level of your office and how you undertook the management of this issue after it came to your attention on 12 June. Those are issues that we intend to progress. I ask at this stage that the material that you referred to that is available be made available to senators. I request of you that that be made available as soon as possible. Obviously, this is close at hand and ought to be provided literally within minutes. I would appreciate you tabling that information in the chamber today as soon as you can.

I would think it appropriate, Minister, if you indicated to us what the time lines are of the investigations that are being undertaken. I think it is important that we hear from you your intentions in relation to making those reports of the auditor and the investigator available for scrutiny by members of the estimates committee. Obviously, it is essential for us to understand as we look further into this very serious issue in relation to the administration of your portfolio when this material will be made available to those of us who have a close interest in it.

I think, Minister, that there are some very significant issues here in relation to the administration of your department. I hope that you will take these requests seriously. I think that is absolutely essential because of the importance of the matters that have been raised and the nature of some of the comments that you have made in the statement that you have presented to the Senate.

I acknowledge that you have indicated that you treat these matters with a fair degree of seriousness. I think that those concerns are very much echoed on this side of the chamber. When a minister deals with an issue like this in the terms that you have, indicating that you believe that they are clearly inexcusable, not to mention being inconsistent with relevant guidelines, let me assure you that we want to get to the bottom of it and we want to get to the bottom of what you did about it at the time, and we intend to do so.

Minister, if you could respond in relation to the reports of the auditor and the investigator and the time lines that you are envisaging so that we can work out a mutually agreed time for the reconvening of the estimates committee and if you can indicate to the Senate that you will make those reports that you have referred to in your statement available to the Senate, that would be of some assistance to those who are taking an interest in the matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—With respect to the investigations taking place, I am advised by my office that the secretary has advised that they should be complete at the end of next week. I have not yet had a chance to discuss with the secretary why that time frame is appropriate. Even if a shorter time frame could be arranged, I do not think that I could give you an undertaking to give you the reports since I do not know what is going to be in them. It is quite obvious that, without knowing the content and what subsequent activities might have to be undertaken—I do not say that I assume they will be, but I do not know—it would not be appropriate to make those reports public. I can say that, to the extent that it is appropriate to make them public, I will, but I cannot give you an unqualified commitment until I know what is in them. I think you would understand that.
—No, I do not understand it. Why? Can you explain why?
—I think it is perfectly obvious, Senator.
—It is not so obvious.

—I will explain, since it is apparently not obvious. I will put it on the record. If those reports indicated that further investigations were required, it is obviously the case that if any further investigations were being undertaken or likely to be undertaken, it is not always the case that it is appropriate that that be made public. That can sometimes prejudice an investigation. It does not always. If there were further investigations to be made—I am not inferring here that I think there will be—and those investigations were to be prejudiced, I would not think it appropriate to release that report. If that was not obvious to you, it is now.
—It is a matter of opinion.
—The senator indicates by way of interjection that it is a matter of opinion.
—Well, most things are.
—Most things are—
—What about the reports that you have now on your desk?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am happy to continue responding to Senator Faulkner through you but it is difficult if Senator Faulkner assumes that he is an interrogator extraordinaire and entitled to constantly interject. I am seeking your assistance in that respect.
—I am certainly going to protect you, Minister, if you need that protection. Please continue.
—What protection? We are not throwing the bombs yet.
—I appreciate that, Senator.
—`Yet', I said.

—Yes, I appreciate that too. Senator Faulkner also asks whether he can have the other bits of advice that my office has. I am inclined to say yes, but I do want the opportunity to go back and briefly reconsider that. There is a precedent to be set when an opposition or people other than the government say, `Well, we'd like to see whatever advice you have.' I can indicate that I will come back to Senator Faulkner very promptly with an answer with respect to that. With respect to the investigations of the auditor and the investigator, I simply cannot say and I will not say until I have seen the reports for the reasons that I have outlined.

BREAK.PARA: I briefly add that I indicated during Senator Faulkner's remarks that I disagreed with one proposition that he put. Basically the proposition was that, but for the opposition, the Senate would not have been told something or, for that matter, anything. I do think that that is a misrepresentation. I will make it clear why I think that is the case. I made it abundantly clear at the estimates that I was concerned about this matter and that I wanted to get to the bottom of it. I have subsequently indicated on each occasion that inquiries are under way and that I would report when I had all the relevant information.

Senator Faulkner is entitled to say, `I'd like to have it bit by bit,' just as I am entitled to say that I think it would be preferable to come back and give a full and complete account. Nonetheless, due to the interest and quite genuine concern, certainly as to the process issues, raised by Senator Faulkner, I agreed with him yesterday that I would come in today to give such information as I could. I do not think the content of those remarks—which is the truth of the matter—was properly conveyed in the remarks that Senator Faulkner made earlier.

Additionally, I want to underline that when process is not followed, that is important. I repeat that I am determined to get to the bottom of this matter, and I will. I am not an opera fan, except for a couple of pieces, but if anybody associated with this has not heard Pavarotti's Nessun' dorma, it will probably be ringing in their ears by the time we arrive at the end of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —None shall sleep.
—Yes; none shall sleep. We will get to the bottom of this matter.

BREAK.PARA: Nonetheless, I simply want to highlight that thus far, the training has been delivered; thus far, as I am advised, there has not been a breach; thus far, Commonwealth money has not been lost; thus far the long‐term unemployed and people who had previously been case managed—the mix of people—on this project have got what was indicated they were going to get. Unlike the commencement to this matter, they have additional commitments from William Angliss—which they did not have in the very beginning—that, should they not find employment with SPCL, William Angliss will assist in them finding employment, for which they have received accredited training, elsewhere in the tourism industry. As I indicated to Senator Faulkner yesterday, that means, perhaps more by luck than by design, this project may in fact work. None of that, of course, takes away from the inappropriate process issues, which we do need to get to the bottom of.

TITLE.XREF: TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SEARCH AND RESCUE SERVICE) BILL 1997

I congratulate you on your long service and the comradeship you have given me within the Labor Party over nearly two decades. I wish you well in your retirement.
