PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.37 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Does the minister recall the grossly misleading claim that she made in the chamber on Monday that the introduction of the youth allowance would not force young people to stay at school? Have you been given the correct information yet by Senator Vanstone that there are currently some 32,000 people who are unemployed, below the age of 18, in receipt of the youth training allowance and who would be affected by the change? Has Senator Vanstone advised the minister that her department told the Senate estimates committee hearings that the potential effect of the youth allowance on increasing numbers of students remaining in education once the youth allowance has been fully implemented is estimated at some 27,000 young people? Why did the minister mislead the Senate again?
—Senator Carr, there is an imputation at the end of that question which I think should be withdrawn.
—What was the imputation?
—The inference of the word `again'.
—Why did you mislead the Senate, minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I did not mislead the Senate. I think it would be really good for us to take Senator Carr to a retraining school, because he is obviously very confused. When I was talking about a common youth allowance not requiring young people to stay in school, I was dealing with the allegation which is being peddled around the country by a number of Labor members and senators in relation to the under‐18‐year‐olds.

ANSWER.PARA: If you will recall, Madam President, the common youth allowance, except in certain special circumstances, will not be available to under‐18‐year‐olds who are not in some form of training or education. The reason for that is that they are three times as likely to be unemployed as people who go on for a further couple of years of education or training and we do not want our young people to become permanently unemployed.

I would have thought that the Labor Party would have had the same view as to the goals that we want for our young people and the sort of society we want. We want skilled workers and people who have had the opportunity to undertake as much vocational training, for example, as we possibly can that will equip them to get jobs in Australia.

It is disappointing that then Senator Carr, in some part of his question, talks about this furphy that we are requiring young people to stay at school. We are saying that training of any kind is important, whether it is through TAFEs, industry traineeships, school‐based traineeships, vocational training in the schools or apprenticeships. There are a variety of ways that young people in the 16‐ to 18‐year‐old range can acquire the skills that we are trying to encourage. He then goes on to talk about 32,000 young people over 18 being affected by the change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under.
—You said `over'; that was my hearing.
—You are deaf.
—If I am deaf, Senator Carr, it might be something to do with the occupational health and safety problem that I have with you bellowing in front of me all day and every day.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps this is an appropriate time to just simply go through what the figures are that are provided by my department about the youth allowance. There are approximately 560,000 young people who will be covered by the youth allowance; 378,000 of them will receive the same money as they currently do; 137,000 of them will receive more money than they currently do; 33,600 will receive a reduced amount; 12,800 unemployed people aged 18 to 20 with parental incomes between $41,000 and $58,000 will not be eligible for payment; students gain from the availability of rent assistance up to a maximum of $74.80 a fortnight on top of what they currently get; and all the under‐18‐year olds who have to live away from home gain from increased rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mainly rural.

—Mainly of course people from regional and rural Australia who were so badly neglected under the previous government. All youth allowees will benefit from a simplified income support system which provides incentives to remain in education or training and which has flexibility enough to cater for a variety of activities undertaken by young people in their transition from school to employment.

ANSWER.PARA: I have organisations like ACOSS, the Youth Coalition, the Welfare Rights Association, the Smith Family and other welfare organisations coming to me and saying, `This is a really good initiative. We have long supported going in this direction. The previous government did not accept our proposals, but we are glad that you have and it is the right way to go for young people.' If you want to attack that and also tell the families in rural Australia that you are not going to help them be eligible for rent assistance, then you just make it clear now. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, the minister does not understand the issues here and I presume that she has not read her own cabinet submission. I point out item number 5 under `Issues' which clearly states that up to 27,000 additional students will be returning to school under your estimates. I ask: is it the case that the minister is simply uninformed on these matters? When Dr Kemp presented the DEETYA cabinet submission with its proposal to help those thousands of extra young people who are going to stay on at school as of January next year, the minister was in fact on holidays and missed the special cabinet meeting to tackle unemployment.

—First of all, we do not have just a special meeting on unemployment. We have unemployment as an issue which is confronted by cabinet on a number of occasions and I have been there for most of them. I do not know what the implications are of Senator Carr mentioning the 27,000 young people. He seems to once again—
—You have no money to back it up; that is the implication.
—Order! Senator Carr, you have asked the question and Senator Newman should be allowed to answer it.

—He seems to once again be focusing on school as if there is something dirty about having young people stay in education. He is also refusing to acknowledge that not all those young people will stay in school, as I have just said. There will be a variety of means.
—Where is the money?

—Dr Kemp has been undertaking major changes in the area of vocational education, both in cooperation with the states and also in the measures he has taken individually. Therefore, the question of increased places for TAFE and increased vocational education which will mean that young people will have that opportunity. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the minister aware of a claim made by Noel Pearson, the Chairman of the Cape York Land Council, that the $200 million Alcan bauxite mine's negotiated native title agreement in Queensland could not have taken place under the government's proposed legislation to amend the Native Title Act? Could the minister please inform the Senate whether Mr Pearson's claim is correct? Does the proposed legislation take away the Aboriginal right to negotiate, as Mr Pearson has said? Does it mean, as Mr Pearson has said, that we will be going back to the law of the jungle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferris for her question. The Native Title Act clearly has not worked. It was one of the great failures of the previous Labor government. Of all people, Mr Pearson knows that. Much of what he said yesterday on radio is nothing but arrant nonsense.

ANSWER.PARA: The Native Title Act being unworkable, compounded by Wik, is not just this government's view. It is the view of all thinking Australians, pastoralists, mining companies and, I might say, Bill Hayden and apparently the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, and shadow minister Stephen Smith.

Recently I attended the diggers and dealers conference in Kalgoorlie with Senator Crane. Notwithstanding the fall in the gold price, it was clearly pointed out by AMEC, which represents small miners and prospectors, that the biggest problems by far were Wik and the Native Title Act. However, they pointed out that Mr Beazley and Mr Smith had recently visited the area and had recognised the problem and that they—the AMEC group—were confident the Labor Party would support the coalition's 10‐point plan. Time will tell.

In regard to the Alcan proposal, let me say this: the government very much welcomes the agreement regarding the development of the Ely deposit, which is adjacent to Weipa, in Far North Queensland. The government supports the use of voluntary binding agreements relating to native title issues. The current Native Title Act does not provide sufficient flexibility to allow a full range of agreements with native title claimants. The government proposes that amendments to the Native Title Act will greatly increase the capacity for agreements to be made with valid native title claimants to resolve native title issues outside the courts.

The government does welcome Mr Pearson's support for our proposals regarding native title agreements. The statutory right to negotiate remains essentially for mining development on vacant crown land. The statutory right to negotiate will continue to enable valid native title claimants to negotiate over proposed mining projects on all vacant crown land—which, I point out, constitutes 36 per cent of Australia. In relation to land covered by pastoral leases, valid native title claimants will be guaranteed the same procedural rights as pastoralists in relation to any proposed mining development on a pastoral lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pastoralists have no rights.

—What an inane interjection. The way it works for pastoral leases and graziers is that mining companies initially will negotiate direct with the grazier. In 99.9 per cent of cases they come to a satisfactory resolution. When that cannot occur, the matter goes to arbitration. I know that in my own state it is decided by either a land court or a mining warden's court. That is the system.

ANSWER.PARA: Fairness and equity demand that pastoralists and native title claimants be treated equally with respect to mining projects on pastoral leases. It must be borne in mind that, in most cases, the crown has ownership of minerals. What you are generally talking about in regard to compensation, whether for pastoralists or native title claimants, is compensation that occurs because of—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister please explain the response from Australians to the government's proposed native title legislation?
—Would you like to run through a list?

—I think Senator Collins would like to answer that question. He interjected, `Would you like to run through a list?' I think that that is a pretty fair answer to the question. What has happened is that the government has approached this in a way that preserves the Mabo decision.
—Have you lost your notes? You need some help!
—Order! Senator Bolkus! He does not need help from you. He is answering Senator Ferris's question.

—He does not like it because the decision taken by this government clearly has been seen by the majority of Australians as fair and equitable. What I mean by fair and equitable is to all Australians, including Aborigines. Not only will it make the process much simpler and create more certainty for investment in this country but it will be better for Aboriginals also.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, in the Senate on 1 September you stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Under a union dominated award system women came off second best.
On what evidence do you make this assumption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people sitting around me have been unkind enough to say that it is self-evident. But, Senator, I would not want you to be hurt by this—you might have a glass jaw like some of your male colleagues have. It is interesting you should ask that question. I spent a considerable period just a very few short years ago at the Clyde Cameron College at Albury-Wodonga meeting with women shop stewards—delegates from all around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It was very clear in the discussion that followed my speech to them that they had had a stomach full, shall we say, of the male dominated trade union movement, which they quite clearly enunciated was some of the cause of the lack of female friendly awards and female friendly workplaces. They felt very under‐represented in negotiations that took place with employers and certainly in respect of applications that were made for awards.

I am not speaking just off my own accord. I happen to have here—it is very timely you should have asked me this question, Senator—an extract from an interview with Professor Helen Hughes, Emeritus Professor at ANU, by Richard Glover on 2BL yesterday. She was talking about the trips to Fiji being offered by the trade union movement as their last desperate attempt to try to attract new members or perhaps to keep the ones they have. She said:
Firstly, I don't think it will deliver an increase in membership. And secondly, if it does it's for the wrong reasons.
She said it was a stupid way to go. She said:
. . . it's not as if the trade union membership has fallen to 33 percent. In the private sector, it's down to 24 percent—
and then the interviewer pointed out that it seemed to be propped up in the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. The question was about the minister's claim that women came off second best under the award system. So far the minister has not said one thing about the award system and has not given one fact or one statistic or one piece of evidence to back up her claim. She is rattling on about some article or some interview yesterday about union membership. Could you ask her to please actually get back to the question that was asked?
—Senator Newman is clearly answering the question from the senator as she understands it.
—The problem is, Madam President, those opposite do not like the answer—not that I am not giving them the answer. Let me make sure they understand. Professor Hughes said:

ANSWER.PARA: The last recession was very much due to trade union policies, as well as government policies—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a farce. You're a disgrace!
—Order! Senator Cook, withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw `farce'.
—No; `disgrace'.
—I withdraw.

—You cannot even withdraw with dignity, can you? Professor Hughes said that the union movement are not concerned with real wage increases and they are not concerned with flexibility in industrial relations, and that is part of the complaint that women have about the movement. She says she is upset because she thinks `a strong trade union movement is essential to a healthy democratic country'. She said:

ANSWER.PARA: And I think the trade union movement, particularly for women, I think, women aren't joining and they aren't joining for good reason.

That is my answer to you as well. I endorse Professor Hughes's comments 100 per cent. In a democracy we need a trade union movement that is strong, vigorous and concerned about all its members. If it were like that, it would be retaining its members and it would have more female members. But women have walked with their feet even faster than men. We are pretty smart and we usually get there before some of the blokes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that the ratio of women's to men's earnings during the 1980s increased from 87.4 per cent when Labor came into power to 90.1 per cent and the ratio of overaward earnings also increased from 44 per cent to 61 per cent, all under what you claimed was a union dominated award system? I ask the minister to confirm whether in Women shaping and sharing the future , published by the Office of the Status of Women in 1993, it states clearly:

BREAK.PARA: Centralised wage fixing is seen as having helped women and other low paid workers, as all workers received wage increases, not just those with industrial strength—mainly male workers.
Will you rebuke your staff for not drawing this to your attention? Also, can you explain why you misled the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there was another allegation of my having misled the Senate. They devalue the currency by these continual suggestions. The boys have been crying wolf and now it is the girls crying wolf. If OSW was saying that sort of thing in 1993, Senator, you might look to see who the government of the day was and what its commitment was.

ANSWER.PARA: I am afraid that this is a new world. There are new opportunities for workers. Women are enjoying the opportunities. You lost the election, and there is a new regime which is benefiting women and giving them flexibility with their working and family lives.

I would be very happy to get the details that you have asked for, but you should be very concerned to follow what has happened, as I understand it, in New Zealand in the time that they have had workplace agreements. The rate of women's wages—

TALK.START.PARA: —Has gone down.
—Has not gone done, Senator, I was advised by the New Zealand government. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. What initiatives has the government taken to promote greater economic independence for indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Eggleston for the question. Madam President, you will recall that Senator Eggleston was the Mayor of Port Hedland, one of the most dynamically developing areas in Western Australia. He was head of a regional development organisation there. As well, with his medical practice he was involved in the management and treatment of many Aboriginal patients and is well aware of the import ance of economic development for Aboriginal people.

ANSWER.PARA: This government has adopted a very different attitude from the previous government in relation to indigenous affairs.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor government threw money at the problem, Senator Faulkner, as you know, and did little to actually improve conditions for indigenous Australians. I think all of us in the Senate would agree.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice Senator Bob Collins nodding his head. He agrees with me, I am sure, that the indigenous people of this country are the most disadvantaged in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asking for a second opinion on that.
—I know you agree with that, Senator Collins; but you were in power for 13 years.
—You would not have a clue.

—We will be there for 13 years and longer, Senator Carr. Labor's legacy for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia was that they locked them into welfare dependency. In 13 years $16,000 million was spent, and indigenous Australians were left as the most disadvantaged people in this nation. By throwing money without any concern for outcomes, Labor left indigenous Australians `in the position of administering their own poverty and misery'. Senators will be interested to learn that that quote comes from an outstanding Canadian indigenous leader I recently had the honour of meeting. Grand Chief Matthew Coone Come of the Cree nation, speaking on economic development, said, to quote him fully:

ANSWER.PARA: If government merely hands over the funds to us, we are just put in the position of administering our own poverty and misery.

My recent visit to Canada was very enlightening and confirmed completely the direction this government is taking in indigenous affairs. The indigenous community in Canada, with active encouragement from the government, has enthusiastically and successfully embraced business opportunities. The message was very clear: the philosophical shift in indigenous affairs from dependency to self-reliance through greater economic independence is the right approach, and that is the approach we are taking. We have developed it by doing something Labor never did.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—By actually asking indigenous Australians how they would like to shape their future, Senator Collins. You did it in Victoria River the other day and your vote went down 29 per cent. That is how much your campaigning did for the Labor Party in the Northern Territory. We have developed it by asking indigenous Australians. They actually want to throw off the shackles of welfare dependency encouraged by Labor. They want to create their own jobs, their own business and their own economic basis to sustain communities. We will work with the indigenous people to achieve this goal.

ANSWER.PARA: The government, in partnership with ATSIC, has set up a $120 million four-year indigenous business incentive program. There will be opportunity and support for joint venturing and a greater focus on long-term viability. There is also provision for grants to individuals and partnerships.

Next week Senator Vanstone and I will be attending a conference in Darwin on economic development for indigenous Australians. The conference hosted by ATSIC and DEETYA, in conjunction with the OECD, sets out to draw lessons and inspiration from Australian and overseas experience. The conference is the outcome of an OECD study tour of indigenous communities in 1995. It will focus on key issues such as indigenous education and training that will help to achieve this goal of economic independence for indigenous communities. If Labor would only listen to the indigenous community and face the fact that they got it horribly wrong, they might even find that they can support the direction we are taking. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, do you agree that a 17-year-old who has finished school, who does not want to go to university or TAFE, who is conscientiously looking for work and who is surviving on $72.50 a week is taking advantage of `a comfortable hammock slung across two palm trees swaying gently in the breeze?' Do you agree that the solution to Australia's so-called dependency crisis is to adopt the US approach and set time limits on the receipt of welfare payments? Minister, do you agree that for Social Security customers there is insufficient incentive to get part-time work or temporary work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the concerns of most Australians in seeing young unemployed people seeking work when there are not enough jobs to choose from, as my generation very fortunately had when we finished our education.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If anybody on the other side wants to interject on that statement, I would remind them that the problem of chronic youth unemployment that Australia is now facing is the result of 13 years of Labour government, which did not do what was needed. So let us not have any hypocritical wringing of hands on the other side of the chamber. Everybody in Australia knows what we inherited in the way of youth unemployment.
—They have no credibility.

—There is no credibility at all. I am sure nobody would accept the statement that welfare dependency is good for anybody, young or old. Measures that can be taken to prevent welfare dependency are important. I point out to you, for example, a measure which we have already announced whereby we will help sole parents and parents on parenting allowance to have access to—
—Do you know how to answer the question?

—You will get the answer that I want to give you, because you are ill informed. Single parents and partnered parents who have children at home are going to be offered the JET scheme at the stage when their youngest child goes into primary school and again when their youngest child goes into secondary school, because those are stages in a family's life when parents frequently look around to see what will happen to them in the next phase of their family's life. That is a very important measure which will help to prevent welfare dependency, particularly for women who have been at home raring children, who are losing confidence in their ability to access work and whose skills are becoming rusty. We do not believe in welfare dependency and I do not believe it is good for the individual or for the society.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I believe that we must introduce measures which increase incentives in the system, and we have tried to do that already. There are a number of measures which are encouraging people to try hard for work. At this stage I would like to give recognition to the measures that were introduced by the previous government in 1995 which did encourage part-time work. Those measures did encourage people to take up what work there was and income testing was adjusted accordingly. I think that was a very good measure which has resulted in more people taking up—

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't seem to be interjecting now!

—No, they are not interjecting now. They would like to hear a bit of praise. Of all the things they did in social security, that happens to be one good thing. But, when it comes to people getting entitlements that they are not entitled to, those opposite were not prepared to move at all. We are now saving $19 million a week from people who were not entitled to payments. It is important, when you look at this issue of incentives and at people being long-term welfare dependants, that we also make sure that those who would wish to be welfare dependent who should not be welfare dependent are also taken into account.

—Given Senator Newman's apparent endorsement of the views that were expressed in the question and noting that they are just a sample of views from Senator Synon's first speech yesterday, could the minister assure the Senate that her office or her department did not provide Senator Synon with any material or direction as to the content of her speech?

—I wonder whether the women senators opposite would regard that as being patronising in the extreme, coming from one of their male senators to one of our female senators—a real put-down. Is Senator Faulkner suggesting that Senator Synon is not capable of preparing her own material and making her own speeches? Let me remind the opposition that Senator Synon, having described the system that we inherited, said: `Yet this is the system after 13 years of Labor neglect'. That is what she said. Just remember: our welfare system is targeted to those who are most in need, not just the unemployed but the elderly, the disabled, the sick, the homeless, lone parents and families—and so it should be.

—I take a point of order, Madam President. It was a very clear question to Senator Newman. I asked her if she could assure us that she and her department did not have any involvement in developing the material, the direction or the content of that speech. It is quite clear. Even Senator Newman might be able to answer it if you directed her to do so, Madam President.
—I did think she had dealt with that, but if she has anything further—
—I did not help Senator Synon with her speech. I still think that you are being very patronising in assuming that she needed help.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, the proposed common youth allowance treats some unemployed 16- to 20-year-old adult Australians as children because they will be dependent on their parents for financial support. Minister, will you seek adjustment to other family programs to accommodate this radical shift in social policy? For instance, will child support laws be changed so that non-custodial parents are required to assist custodial parents supporting jobless 18- to 20-year-olds? Will the family tax rebate be extended to include 18- to 20-year-olds as dependants? Will family payments be extended to include 16- to 20-year-olds as dependants? Will you ensure that the government is consistent in its treatment of young people?

—I understand that Senator Woodley has publicly expressed his belief that the common youth allowance is the way to go for young people. I would not want to exaggerate his support. I am sure that he has things that he would like to see done differently. But it is not a matter which I can advance his exploration of here. I seem to recall that this was a matter that he raised, or somebody raised, in the estimates committee hearings after the budget. I have nothing extra that can be added at this time. So I am sorry; I cannot help him.

—Thanks, Minister. Yes, the Democrats are supportive of a common youth allowance if it is fair. We believe we have a long way to go yet. Minister, do you believe that people are not adults until they turn 21? That is the nub of what we are trying to get at. If you do believe that people are not adults until they become 21, then there are a lot of other issues, such as the age of consent, joining the armed forces and voting, which I ask you to give us your ideas about to help us understand your policy regarding when people become adults.

—Obviously, people are adults when they are able to vote and a whole lot of other criteria, but this is not a question of being adult. This is a question of being financially independent. If students up to the age of 25 are financially dependent on their families then they are parentally means tested in the help that they can get. So we do not believe it is unfair or inequitable for young people up to the age of 20 who are seeking unemployment assistance from the taxpayer to be regarded as financially dependent on their parents. As I think you have been told before, students may be dependent upon their parents for, say, five years or so. But social security statistics show that 18- to 20-year-olds who are unemployed on average are unemployed for five months. Even if you said they were unemployed for a year, the commitment by the families is much less than the commitment they need to give to students—(Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Agency Agreement

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I ask: why is the Department of Veterans Affairs through its new agency agreement spending $12,000 to promote tax avoidance by its senior officers by `the production and printing of guidelines and providing information sessions for staff'? How does the minister justify spending $12,000 to encourage SES officers, many of whom earn over $100,000, to avoid income tax, the new 15 per cent superannuation tax and the new Medicare levy surcharge for high income earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a question that came from a former administration that spent $10,000 on balloons—hot air—when they were in government. It is a strange thing, the questions we get today.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday Senator Sherry asked me a question about the agreement and whether I would be able to provide a copy of the agreement for the Senate. I have asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to provide a copy of that, together with a response. I was preparing to table that after question time. I am happy to table it now. If there are further questions you would like to ask after you get a copy of that, I will be happy to get further information from the minister responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. It is a little hard to know whether what the minister is tabling is going to answer my question, but I am interested—in the light of the Treasurer's statement on Tuesday that the government takes such measures as are required to prevent legitimate taxation liabilities being avoided—to know whether the minister will now seek to ensure that no taxpayers' money is spent to promote tax avoidance by SES officers in either the Department of Veterans' Affairs or the minister's own Department of Social Security.
—As I have already said, if there is material that is not answered in there, I will get it for you, if I can.

—My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I refer the minister to the announcement by Mr McGauran of the decision to construct a replacement research reactor at Lucas Heights and also to the fact that a major research reactor review was undertaken in 1993. That concluded that a decision to proceed with a new reactor should be subject to the resolution of questions in relation to a high level waste site, the value of spallation technology as an alternative to a reactor, the ability of cyclotrons to produce radioisotopes for medical purposes, the importance of neutron scattering research and the issue of whether a research reactor is important for Australia's national interest. I ask, what has changed since 1993 to justify such a large investment in nuclear technology, particularly in the light of the fact that an examination of the annual reports of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and ANSTO indicate that in current day dollars the investment by Australian taxpayers in nuclear technology has resulted in a loss of approximately $2.5 billion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Margetts for providing me with notice of this matter. Through you, Madam President, to Senator Margetts, the research reactor review which you mention was an advisory body which reported to the previous government in 1993. The recommendations in its report are just that—recommendations.

ANSWER.PARA: The review said that it recognised that the government might want to make a positive decision about a new reactor, for the same reasons and in the same way as it does for defence and other national interest issues. It also said that there was no need to make a final decision back in 1993 and it set out a number of conditions which it considered, if satisfied, would make it appropriate for a positive decision to be made on a new reactor after about five years. I note that Senator Schacht released a press statement to that effect in November 1993—that the government put off its decision for five years as a result of the review.

In its response to the report, the previous government said that, while it broadly accepted the review's findings, it did not accept them all. The conditions in the report by the review are not essential requirements for a decision by the government, as was recognised by the review itself. Nevertheless, the government has followed up the conditions set out in the review, and the present position is as follows.

In relation to the high level waste site, the previous government did not accept that a high level waste site should be established and nor does the present government. Rather, the government has decided on a strategy to clear existing spent fuel holdings and those that will arise in the remaining life of the reactor. This strategy involves the repatriation of the spent fuel to the countries of origin—namely the United States and the United Kingdom. A decision on management of spent fuel from the new reactor is not needed for another 10 to 15 years, because there will be no spent fuel ready for disposition until then. A decision towards the end of this time and based on the technologies available then would be appropriate.

In relation to spallation neutron sources, unlike a multi‐purpose research reactor, a spallation neutron source could provide only a limited capability for bulk radioisotope production and it could not provide for Australia's requirements for neutron beam science or for commercial irradiations. ANSTO has advised that a spallation source and associated facilities would cost more than $600 million. The review that Senator Margetts mentioned said that, if a spallation source were to be chosen, a small reactor would also be necessary.

In relation to the cyclotron radioisotope production, significant technical problems remain unresolved with proposals to use cyclotrons for the commercial production of technetium. There are no plans to do so anywhere in the world. The United States Department of Energy concluded in 1996 that the utilisation of cyclotrons for the commercial production of technetium‐99m will be neither technically feasible nor economically viable in the foreseeable future. The government understands that research to prove the concept has been scaled back because results did not meet expectations.

The technical proponent of cyclotrons for the production of technetium‐99m is Dr Lagunas‐Solar of the University of California, Davis. That university's chemistry and agriculture Internet home page said on 29 July this year:
The production of molybedenum‐99—
the precursor of technetium‐99m—
is based solely on reactor methods and no viable alternative has been developed.

In relation to neutron scattering in Australian science, some 24 research groups from Australian universities use the neutron scattering facilities on the HIFAR reactor for a range of research projects. I can provide the remainder of this answer, should Senator Margetts ask a supplementary. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. The minister has not indicated exactly what research on cyclotrons has been undertaken on behalf of the Australian government. If ANSTO has a $600 million report in relation to spallation technology, is that publicly available? There are a number of issues that have been mentioned there. If those issues are available in point form or if they have clearly been looked at by the government, is that available to the public? Could the minister clarify the fact that the nuclear fuel does not go to the other country forever; it is only transformed and comes back to Australia? Australia is going to get that spent fuel back to look after—forever in any real terms.

—In relation to the last part of Senator Margetts's question, I can say that the only spent fuel rods that will be returning to Australia are those from the United Kingdom; they will not be returning from the United States. In relation to the cyclotron radioisotope production, I think I referred to that in relation to the US studies, and Australia is taking note of those US studies.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to the other part of the initial question, you referred to the national interest. Might I say that, for a start, Access Economics has valued the contribution of the HIFAR reactor to Australia's economy in the sum of $100 million. As well as that, over 400,000 diagnostic processes are provided via nuclear medicine from Lucas Heights, most importantly in relation to child medicine.
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw, the Westmead Children's Hospital in Sydney I think treats over 9,000 patients, half of whom suffer life threatening diseases, a third of which relate to child cancers. This is the sort of national interest that this national reactor provides. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Newman. I refer the minister to the federal government's plan to sell hundreds of hectares of surplus defence land around the Sydney Harbour foreshore. Is it a fact that the Carr government has stated that it will not grant development approval for the land unless significant portions are handed over to the New South Wales government for public open space? Is it a fact that the funds from the sale and development of the land have been earmarked for relocation costs of the defence establishments concerned? What will be the financial shortfall if the Carr government proceeds with its plans to prevent the sale of land to developers? What negotiations have occurred between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales state government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say how sorry we will be to see Senator Childs leave this place. The quality level will diminish somewhat and we are afraid for the future with your going. If you would care to review your decision, it might be timely for the sake of the Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: Over many years I have seen New South Wales governments of various hues grandstand and argue about defence property around Sydney Harbour. I know that in the case of the land that has been listed for sale around Sydney Harbour that there is a great deal of misinformation that is in the public domain. For example, on the proportion of land that would be considered as available for developers, as I understand it, some of the claims that are being made would suggest that the whole of the defence land would be available for development, and that is just not so.

So, while I cannot give you an answer today on the detail of that, I would be very happy to send you a copy and certainly to provide the information to the Senate. I know that some of the response from the current state government, for example in an area like Tresco, which is a heritage building, has been described by the Minister for Defence as grandstanding. I would not want to categorise all of their concerns as that, but certainly in the past the record of New South Wales governments dealing with Commonwealth governments of various hues over these issues has been that the fire and brimstone is in the public arena and the negotiations continue privately. I am not party to that, and I will certainly see what information, if any, can be obtained for you as to the specifics of your question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the minister representing the Minister for Small Business. I refer to concerns raised regarding the impact of wholesale sales tax on different types of retailers, where higher sales tax is paid by independent retailers compared to large chains with distribution arms, like Coles and Woolworths. With grocery chains now controlling 75 per cent of the national grocery market and a prediction by Woolworths managing director that the two major chains would jointly have 70 per cent of the market share by the year 2000, this puts small business below critical survival level. This dominant position is further strengthened by a sales tax advantage of $120 million a year, with an average independent at a $12,000 a year disadvantage.

QUESTION.PARA: Would the government investigate the competitive position of small business in light of the sales tax regime presently delivering to chains with their own distribution arms an unfair competitive edge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Minister for Small Business, Mr Reith, has recently met with representatives of the National Association of Retail Grocers of Australia and representatives of the independent wholesalers. The government is very much aware of their concerns and Mr Reith has asked them for further information. When the industry provides that material, the minister will be in a position to take further decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is important to appreciate that this is an issue that this government, unlike our predecessors, is prepared to tackle. Indeed, on 13 August the Prime Minister announced that a task force would be established within the government to prepare a framework of options for a reform of the tax system. That is a very important committee. It is just another one of those too hard issues as far as the Labor Party was concerned, but we are fortunate indeed that Senator Brian Gibson will be chairing that committee.

Senator Gibson, of course, has impeccable credentials because he comes from the real world, and he stands in stark contrast to those on the other side. If you had a royal commission into the union movement, they would be fighting each other and falling all over the place to get into it. But on virtually every other issue they are absolutely stark naked; they do not understand the first principles. We are indeed fortunate that Senator Gibson and, I am sure, a number of his colleagues—particularly Senator Ferguson, who is an ex officio member of that committee and once again has some very relevant real life experience in the area—will be able to make a very useful contribution to that committee's work.

One of the principles that will guide the work of the task force is that consideration should be given to a broad based indirect tax to replace some or all of the existing indirect taxes, and in evaluating the options for tax reform an important consideration for the government will be to ensure that Australia's tax system does not disadvantage smaller businesses and is conducive to growth and employment in this important sector of the economy.

Can I simply assure Senator Boswell that the Liberal Party and the National Party are, as almost always, in great harmony on the need to address the concerns of small business and to actually do something that the Labor Party comprehensively failed to do over all those years. Once we get Senator Gibson's expert advice and then report back to Minister Reith I am quite sure we will be very well placed to keep Senator Boswell and all others with genuine concerns on this issue very happy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Minister, do you recall the coalition's bitter criticism when the former Labor Treasurer Paul Keating moved his family home to Canberra but claimed Sydney as his home base? Can you confirm that a National Party cabinet minister from northern NSW and a Liberal cabinet minister from Tasmania have adopted this practice as well? How do you reconcile this hypocrisy?
—Thank you for the question, Senator. As I do in these cases, I will seek a response for you.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are these home base designations subliminal or actual?
—Senator Conroy is not known for his sense of humour and I think that that probably proves it.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. I refer the minister to recent reports that not all of the $500 million raised through the Medicare levy for the gun buyback scheme will be spent. I understand that there may well be a last minute rush to hand in weapons and I understand too that there will be an audit at the end of the scheme. Will the government commit itself to putting any funds left unspent at the end of the scheme into programs and services which assist the victims of crime? If not, will the government commit itself to directing those unspent funds towards some other public purpose, such as improving public hospitals or community health services?

—This question is very similar to a question that was put to me by Senator Hogg the other day. The government simply is not in a position to assess whether there will be any surplus of funds left over. If there are funds left over then that will have to be a decision made when and if that occasion arises. Other than that I do not think I can assist you any further.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I understand that you cannot be precise as to the figure. We are just trying to establish that if there were an amount left over would you consider as a government applying it to a public purpose such as those I have outlined?

—I take Senator Murray's question in a constructive way. I will take his concerns to the Attorney-General and take them up with him. The government cannot engage in a hypothetical question as to what might happen and what it might do in a given circumstance. I take the question in a constructive way and it is something I will take up with the Attorney‐General.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, I refer to media reports that the Prime Minister has recently rebuked frontbenchers for not doing enough for backbenchers. Is it a fact that one backbencher has been waiting 12 months for a response from a minister while another has written to a minister 25 times but has not yet received a reply? Isn't it true that the Prime Minister's Guide on the key elements of ministerial responsibility states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . correspondence should be handled expeditiously and, where a timely reply is not possible, an interim acknowledgment giving reasons for the delay should be sent.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. The minister will be aware that ideological opponents of allowing universities to admit full fee paying Australian undergraduate students from next year have attacked this as catering to the rich and thick. Is the minister aware that the TER for admission to the study of law via the Legal Practitioners Admission Board in NSW is 50, whereas the admission scores for law schools at universities such as the University of New South Wales and the University of Sydney are over 95? What implications does this have for those who would prevent Australian students from funding their own education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for this very important question. I am aware that the New South Wales Legal Practitioners Admissions Board accepts into its diploma of law course HSC graduates with a TER of 50 and a 60 per cent pass in two‐unit general English. That is in very marked contrast to the 95‐plus TER scores that students need to secure themselves a place in a university law course. Completion of the diploma of law through the Legal Practitioners Admissions Board qualifies its graduates to practise as solicitors, to proceed to the bar exam and to therefore practise side by side with university graduates. By all accounts, it is a very rigorous course of study.

ANSWER.PARA: The Legal Practitioners Admissions Board and its predecessors, the solicitors admissions board and the barristers admissions board, have produced many talented and well‐respected lawyers. Many graduates have gone on to become great contributors to Australian society.
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I see Senator Forshaw nodding—I do not know if that includes him. Take the Minister for Finance, John Fahey. He is a graduate of the solicitors admissions board, as is, of course, Justice Michael McHugh, who now sits on the bench of the High Court of Australia. He is a product of the former barristers admissions board examinations. Now he holds one of the highest legal offices in the land, and all of this without a degree from a university and without having to say, `I have got a 95 TER score' to get in.

ANSWER.PARA: These two examples clearly show that a person's ability to excel in their chosen field has very little to do with an artificial supply and demand mechanism such as the TER score. Unfortunately, for those misguided ideologues who believe in the TER as a single measure of assessing one's suitability for a place at university, the success of people such as John Fahey, Justice McHugh and others ought to blow their argument right out of the water.

Shadow education minister Mark Latham is one of the misguided. He argues that the TER is a good system that rewards students who work hard. As we all know, he shamefully argues that people who are willing to pay to invest in themselves are the dumb rich. Of course, Mark Latham has to believe in the infallibility of the TER. He has to have faith in those two decimal points as an infallible index of merit—not to would completely undermine his logic for rationing publicly funded places in universities and for labelling people as `dumb rich'.

Would he be prepared to argue in front of the High Court and a judge that you are not worthy of a place in a university law course if you fall below the TER cut‐off? I think not. Is he prepared to argue that anyone who might want to pay the full cost of a place in a law course and who does not quite make that precious TER is just plain dumb? Why does he keep implying that? Frankly, I do not think it is an argument he could sustain.

Madam President, Senator Tierney's question serves only to highlight that the TER on its own is not an appropriate mechanism for admission to university, and it certainly highlights that it does not indicate that you are dumb if you do not get the TER that the admissions board requires for you to enter that university course. It clearly underlines that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, following that excellent answer, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Social Security (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked by Senator Mackay today.

In answer to my question, what could Senator Newman come up with? Well, she once went to a meeting of women shop stewards at Clyde Cameron College and they were all talking about the male dominated union movement. They must have fainted with shock at the sight of her—that is the first thing. Madam Deputy President, let me tell you that I was at a meeting yesterday of women shop stewards at the ACTU Congress who were talking about what this government has done to women—and they were almost in tears.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not singing her praises.

—They were certainly not singing Senator Newman's praises. They were not singing the praises of anybody on the other side of the chamber, because what this government has done in relation to women is appalling. This is not just political rhetoric; this is real. It is statistical proof; it is real.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that Senator Newman came up with was something about trips to Fiji and unions fighting for survival and so on. Not once during her answer did she give any evidence at all, other than some anecdotal rubbish about once going to Clyde Cameron College, about how women came off second best under the award system. Why didn't she give any evidence of that? Because she has not got any evidence—that is why. She does not have any evidence.

I might say that, if Senator Newman went today to a meeting of women shop stewards similar to the one she went to in Clyde Cameron College, I doubt that she would get out alive, given what the women were saying yesterday. These women are not what that lot on the other side call the union elites. These are not national secretaries. These are not national presidents. These are organisers. These are shop stewards. These are workplace delegates—people on the ground—and what they are talking about is that women are now worse off than ever before, not just in the area of industrial relations. We could go through this, but it is a bit of a litany and it might take a lot longer than I have got. We have got cuts to legal aid; we have got cuts to aged care; we have got the outrageous cuts to child care—absolutely outrageous; and we have got a decrease in women's participation in the labour force—women are dropping out; they just cannot get jobs. Why are they dropping out? Could it have something to do with cuts to child care? Probably. Could it have something to do with the fact that, when women are going out and attempting to find jobs, most of those jobs are casual? We have got a casualisation of the work force.

In relation to industrial relations, let us come to one of the major features of the new industrial relations legislation and that is the Australian workplace agreements. Everybody here probably knows a bit about the Australian workplace agreements. We know they exist and we know that some people are signing them. We know that some employers are using them. But we do not know much else. We do not what is in them. We do not know whether in fact they result in a diminution of wages or not. We do not know whether conditions are being affected. Why don't we know this? After all, every single decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is published and is public knowledge. Why don't we know this? Because this government will not give us that information. This government is withholding that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to keep it a secret.

—That is right, Senator Cook. Why do they want to keep it a secret? Because what is in those agreements is appalling. We have women and young people going to see employers to try to get a job—because the unemployment situation is disastrous, with record high unemployment, record high youth unemployment—and signing an AWA not knowing what is in it and what their rights are.

SPEECH.PARA: CEDAW saw this and absolutely canned this government for a number of initiatives, including industrial relations initiatives. What did the Office of the Status of Women do? Pru Goward came along and said, `We're monitoring it.' Senator Newman may not even be aware of that because she was not even at estimates. Poor old Senator Hill had to come in to do Senator Newman's job for her.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was being well looked after. I thought it was being very well managed.

—I think you probably did a better job than Senator Newman would have. But when is Senator Newman going to have the courage to actually front her own estimates committee and front the implications of her government's policy? It is outrageous that she was not there. I hope she will be there next time. What is this government doing about the absolutely damning report of the UN with regard to industrial relations, amongst others thing? They are monitoring it; they are having a bit of a look at it! (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to take note of Senator Newman's response to the question by Senator Mackay. I have a particular interest in this question because it relates to a question that I asked of Senator Newman on Monday where, apart from what Senator Mackay has already referred to, Senator Newman said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought a female senator, of all senators, would have been concerned to see that women workers in particular had more choice than before. Under a union dominated award system women came second best.

I really do not know where Senator Newman gets her evidence. We still do not know where she gets her evidence after today's answer to the question because she gave no evidence. It was a bit like her answer yesterday where she could not even bring herself to mention the word `sport' once in relation to a question on women in sport. Not once could she find it in her vocabulary or within her resources to refer to sport in answer to a question which quite clearly asked for information about the Prime Minister's women in sport awards. So her record seems to be getting even worse. We got not one piece of what you could, in any sense, regard as evidence.

Senators that were involved in the inquiry into Workplace Relations Bill would have a much clearer idea of what evidence exists out there in that sense. We heard a considerable amount of evidence, both Australian and international, on the effect of decentralisation of an industrial relations system on women workers and on other disadvantaged groups—evidence upon evidence. It is internationally recognised that women do not do better under a decentralised system. Yet Senator Newman still feels she can come forward and parrot ideas like: women will have choice and flexibility.

I do not know when Liberal women will ever understand—it does not seem that they will ever understand—that flexibility without protection means nothing. There is no such thing as free choice in a fully decentralised environment. Choice without those protections will leave women even more disadvantaged. They have no real choice. For Senator Newman to have made that response in relation to a legitimate question about sick leave entitlements and a potential burden on the social security system was utterly ridiculous. It deserves ridicule. It is an ongoing trend, unfortunately, that Senator Newman is continuing with.

It is similar to her response on the issue of consultation. She says that she is talking to people, but the problem is she is not listening. The women in the trade union movement that would have met with her in Albury-Wodonga at the university, which does not exist anymore, would have said, `Sure, she was here but she did not understand anything we said.' Senator Newman talks about there being a decline of union representation. I am sorry, Senator Newman—and this relates to a question raised yesterday as well—but I come from a union which represents predominantly women workers and it is growing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since you left.

—It was growing while I was there as well, Senator; it has grown significantly. But if you are suggesting that women getting into parliament is going to lead to a decline in the trade union movement, I do not know what kind of ridiculous arguments you are going to try to run next.

SPEECH.PARA: I know you are struggling. I know you are having a hard time with this reform agenda. I know it is particularly difficult for some of the women on the back bench. I know it has been hard for senators such as Senator Payne to deal with some of these issues—it is getting very `Payneful'. Some other senators are perhaps not having as much pain. Yesterday's first speech, as we noticed today in question time, was very interesting.

I do not know what is going to happen to women in Victoria if that is the view taken towards welfare and women's access to social wage entitlements and their access to other areas of protection which assist many women in areas such as those in which I work. The number of women in the retail industry that are on part‐pensions or other welfare entitlements would have been disgusted to hear the types of views that were put forward about social wage measures, about women's rights to expect some support in our society.

It disheartens me to hear that in this day and age those sorts of views are being put forward with such a lack of sophistication. They belong in the 1960s. They belong with Senator Newman in the 1960s, not with women in the 1990s and not with the responsibilities that you should be representing here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel compelled to enter into this debate.
—Where is Senator Newman?

—She is probably doing more important work. I have rarely heard such nonsense as what I have heard in this place in the last few minutes. As I recall, the average incomes of women in our society are lower than men and have always been lower than men. They were so under a centralised system and they were so under the decentralised system that the ALP introduced. We have had yet a further revision of policy today because this party opposite is in fact calling for a return to the centralised system of wage fixing. I did know that that was the ALP policy. Wasn't it the ALP that brought in enterprise bargaining in this country? Have they now abandoned that? Are they now calling for a return to centralised wage fixing? Are they demonstrating that they are further out of date than we realised?

SPEECH.PARA: Women will have better opportunities under a decentralised system because they will be able to take advantage of Australian workplace agreements, and they will be able to negotiate with employers terms and conditions that suit their particular circumstances. They will be given greater freedom to do that for their benefit than they have ever had before. That greater freedom is the advantage of working under this system of industrial relations, as opposed to the previous system. The other important thing is that the new system does have in‐built safeguards and in‐built protections. That is what this Labor Party is refusing to acknowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?

—You know what they are in relation to wages. You know what promises were made before the election and what promises were kept. Rather than being afraid of the future, the Labor Party should be embracing the opportunities that come from change, embracing the opportunities that come from opening up the economy: lower interest rates, more opportunities for women and more benefits for women. They ought to be embracing the next phase of change that has followed from their enterprise bargaining and the decentralisation that they introduced into the system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that it is disappointing to hear the arguments that have been put today. Senator Mackay, if we are talking about equality of opportunity, it is disappointing to note that, when promotions were made on your side and two women were given the jobs, they were that of parliamentary secre tary. Why couldn't some of the old chaps who have had a fair go and who have been found wanting stand aside to give you a real chance? Then we would see a touch of equality within the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that Senator Hill has not been doing his homework again. He does his best to try to represent Senator Newman, who should be in the chamber. Senator Hill, are you not aware that the United Nations `noted with concern that the legislation on industrial relations providing for the negotiation of individual contracts between employer and employee may have a disproportionately negative impact on women'?

SPEECH.PARA: This is not what the Labor Party is saying, although we have said the same thing; this is from the United Nations. It was very critical of the Australian government report in July. We have heard nothing of that from the minister. She is not game to come into this chamber and talk about this report because it was so critical. The report continues:

Part‐time and casual workers, of which women formed a disproportionate share, are usually in a weaker position than other workers to negotiate favourable working agreements, in particular with regard to benefits. The reservation to the Convention with regard to paid maternity leave, and Australia's non-notification of ILO Convention 103, remained a concern for women workers with family responsibilities.

If Senator Hill is so determined to speak up in relation to this matter, I wonder whether he will ensure that this government adopts the recommendation made by the United Nations: that is, that an evaluation should be conducted of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 assessing its impact upon women of different age groups with different educational levels and in different occupational groups.

Minister, will the government be adopting this recommendation? Apparently not. The government should also assess whether the act leads to increased or decreased part-time and casual work and its impact on women workers' benefits and on workers with family responsibilities, particularly the ability of women to obtain child-care leave. A similar evaluation assessment was recommended for Australia's new child-care benefits scheme. Minister, you will find out in New York that everybody is rather concerned about this government's record in relation to women. Furthermore, I will express grave reservations and concern about the direction of this government in failing to live up to its obligations. It has signed the convention; it has to meet its obligations, and it is not doing to.

Finally, I seek leave to table the round table report of the non-government organisations that met with Minister Newman and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) last week. Yesterday the minister said that the women's organisation said that issues are on the agenda, they are being addressed by government and they are getting a good hearing. I claim that the minister has misled the Senate. This document proves to me, on my interpretation at least, that non-government women's organisations are not overwhelmingly happy at all. For example, the report states:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted, but I would like to make the point that I find it rather unusual that Senator Reynolds, who was not here during question time, can actually come in and participate in the debate on answers to questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I would like to make a personal explanation. I was here at question time. In fact, I was here early for question time. I did leave the chamber during part of question time, but I was certainly here long enough to hear from the minister. I suggest that the government whip withdraw the statement that I was not here during question time, because I was here for the majority of question time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Just commenting on the same matter, I will introduce my remarks by saying that I was industrial relations minister for Australia between the years 1990 and 1993. The question addressed to Senator Newman today was about the gender gap in wages: the difference between the aggregate rate of wage paid to women in the employed work force compared with that paid to men. Senator Newman ducked that question. She talked about everything else but—and well she might. I want to take this opportunity just to get some of the facts straight on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of women's wages in the Australian work force is interesting and it is certainly one that the conservative side of politics should not talk about. Up to the election of the Whitlam government in 1972, the difference between women's wages and men's wages in Australia was that women got about 62 per cent of the wage that men got.

Before the election of the Whitlam government, an equal pay case was taken in the federal Industrial Relations Commission—the arbitration court, as it then was—and the then conservative government opposed the concept of equal pay for equal work. That is to say, where women did exactly the same work as men, they opposed the proposition that women should get exactly the same pay as men. The then government fought that case tooth and nail.

When the Whitlam government came to power, the government then supported that case, and it succeeded. We had enshrined in Australian industrial law for the first time that women should get the same wage as men if they do the same work as men, a principle that I thought ought to have been recognised as a basic human right. But the gender gap was about 76 per cent in favour of men when the Whitlam government was elected. When the Whitlam government left office in 1975, the gender gap had closed to about 85 per cent. That was a great reforming government; it brought women's wages closer to men's wages.

BREAK.PARA: When the Fraser government came to office, the gender gap widened. Under a conservative government, women started to fall back in terms of the rate of wage they got compared with that of men, and it went back to something like about 70 per cent. When we came to government in 1983, the gap began to close again—and these are indicative figures, not precisely accurate figures; I can get those accurate figures later, but these are figures that do illustrate the point—and it closed to something like 93 per cent of the male rate. They are the facts.

What is now happening in the work force, under a conservative government again, is that the gender gap is widening—and it is widening because of the introduction of individual work contracts under the industrial relations law of this nation. I find it absolutely mind blowing that anyone can think that a migrant worker employed by a large company can negotiate her wages with a major employer on an equal basis. I find it absolutely amazing that a shop assistant can be thought of as being able to negotiate her wages with her employer, being a major supermarket chain, on an equal basis; or that a junior worker has the same bargaining clout, acumen and knowledge of all the precedents to enable them to negotiate their wages with a major employer on exactly the same basis.

But, as that is the system we now have in play, it is not surprising that, with this inequality of power in the negotiating situation, people are exploited with their wages being pushed down. That is the record of this government. Most of all, women workers are vulnerable to that, and women workers' wages are falling under this government. They are the circumstances, and I just wanted to put them on the record to get the facts right.

Senator Newman was wrong in saying that women workers in New Zealand have done better. They have not. The system of individual work contracts was introduced into New Zealand well before it was introduced into Australia. As a consequence, female wages in New Zealand have declined in comparison with the level of male wages in New Zealand. This is because, again, women are vulnerable in the workplace, they do not have the bargaining clout, and they have been exploited.

I think it is about time we got these facts recognised. The government might wish to explain them in other ways. But these are the facts. You cannot hide from them, you cannot run from them and you cannot pretend that they do not exist. The truth is that women workers out there—and many of their male colleagues know this to be the case because they live it daily, they experience it in the workplace every day—feel insecure about their employment future. They know that through their wages they are being exploited and they are uncertain about where they are heading. That is the legacy this government is giving women of Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor Party members on the other side seem to forget, when talking about union membership and about allowing and opening up employment opportunities for people to negotiate contracts with choices that, as Senator Hill mentioned, they were the ones who initiated enterprise bargaining. Mind you, when Mr Howard mentioned it many years before, you would have thought the earth was about to fall in.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that those opposite never talk about some of the bad aspects of compulsory unionism, some of the aspects that have really affected women. I will just remind them about something that politicised me. It occurred when there was a general strike at Monash University where I was working at the time.

The woman who was working, cleaning, in our halls of residence came to me at the end of that strike. She was desperately upset, she was distraught, and I asked her what the matter was. She said, `I hope you didn't see me picketing at 5.00 a.m. in the morning.' I said, No, I didn't happen to see you picketing.' And she said, `I didn't want to picket, I didn't want to strike. But I was rung up and told that, if I didn't picket and if I didn't strike, my kids wouldn't get home from school.' Those opposite forget to tell us that those are the sorts of bullyboy tactics that went on—and many of the people who were victims of those bullyboy tactics were women.

BREAK.PARA: One of the things that politicised me when I was a young person was my mother being forced to join a union when she did not want to. She came home in tears because she had an employer who was tremendous, an employer who gave her all the flexibility she needed in her employment—and she was made to join a union against her will. If you want to know what politicised me in my youth, that would have had to have been one of the major things.

Women, in many cases—not always, but in many cases—have been bullied by the union movement into picketing, into striking, when they did not want to. So do not come in here and tell me that everything on the union side is rosy, and that it is all good and proper if you have a central wage fixing system and compulsory unionism. It is not a bed of roses, and it is not a bed of roses for women.

I can give you example after example; I have just given you two examples. The one that absolutely floored me was the woman in the halls of residence who was terrified that her kids would not get home from school. Whether it was just an idle threat or not, she did not know. You can stand up here and be holy Joes, but the boot is on the other foot in a number of cases with respect to the behaviour of the union movement towards women. As for Senator Reynolds getting up here and talking about the United Nations report—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's here.

—I know it is there, but you did not actually talk about the fact that the committee made favourable comments on many aspects of the Australian report, including focusing on and addressing domestic violence in the women's safety survey, and also that there was a comprehensive action plan to implement the Beijing platform for action. There was some criticism that came out in the press, but the criticism from a limited number of NGOs and from the press was much more extensive than and out of proportion to the press release that the United Nations committee put out. Senator Reynolds knows that.

BREAK.PARA: I hope when Senator Reynolds goes to the United Nations—and I hope we will maintain the friendship during that time—that she does not undermine Australia while she is there and go around talking about the CEDAW report because there are a lot of positive things that are happening. I would suggest that Senator Reynolds not get focused over there because we might fall out. We might have an awful falling out if Senator Reynolds goes over there and just talks about this report because there were some positive aspects of the report, and Senator Reynolds knows that. There were a limited number of NGOs involved in bagging the government on that report, but we know that some of them have not got used to the fact that the government has changed. Some people will feel that maybe their views are not being heard as strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially workers whose wages and conditions have been cut.
—There were a lot of groups when Labor was in power who did not feel that they were being listened to either.
—They had decent wages and conditions.

—Senator Carr goes on about the workers. Senator Carr, you tell me about those workers in Victoria who were bullied by the unions. Tell me about the metalworkers in Victoria who were bullied by the union. I can line them up for you. It is not all a bed of roses in the union movement.

BREAK.PARA: To get up and say that the centralised wage fixing system is the best for women is just nonsense. What women want is choice. They want flexibility. They want flexibility of hours. You started out on the pathway towards enterprise bargaining. We have set protections in place. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
