DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Presiding Officers' response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories entitled A right to protest . With the concurrence of the Senate I propose that the response be incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
Speaker of the House of Representatives President of the Senate

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response of the Presiding Officers to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories entitled "A Right to Protest"

BREAK.PARA: The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, the Hon W Smith MP, invited us to comment on the report "A Right to Protest" tabled recently by Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. Our response was to be considered in the compilation of a government response to the report.
We consider it appropriate that our response be made directly to the Senate and the House of Representatives .

We agree with the committee's view that the right to protest is a basic tenet of Australian society and that this right carries with it certain obligations in relation to public order and public safety.

A protest about national issues will frequently focus on the national capital and particularly on Parliament House. In view of this, the powers conferred on the Presiding Officers by the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 for the "control and management" of the parliamentary precincts must be recognised as paramount in managing protests at Parliament House. For that purpose, we have issued "Guidelines for Protests, Demonstrations and Public Assemblies within the Parliamentary Precincts" (copy attached). The guidelines define an area within the precincts in which protests may be conducted, indicate what activities are permitted as part of any protest activity and define the role of police and security staff in managing protests.
We make the following comments in relation to the specific recommendations (in bold) made by the committee:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1. a permit not be required in order to protest on national land, subject to recommendation 3 dealing with protest structures;

BREAK.PARA: 2. a broad legislative scheme for non-compulsory prior notification of protests, based on the Queensland Peaceful Assembly Act 1992, not be introduced, but instead a cooperative approach to protest management be encouraged by:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) identifying in a community liaison section of the Australian Federal Police a contact officer for coordination of protests on national land who would provide a contact and information point for protest organisers and who would be responsible for liaising with other relevant authorities when a protest is planned for national land; and

(b) producing and making available a public information booklet on protesting in the national capital which would encourage prior notification of protests to a protest coordination officer of the Australian Federal Police and which would provide relevant information and advice on the conduct of protests in the national capital, focusing on national land.

BREAK.PARA: These recommendations are supported. As has been noted, there are guidelines for the management of protest activity in the precincts and generally protest groups work well with the Parliament House Security Controller.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 3. a permit system be introduced for the management of protest structures on national land so that a permit is required from the National Capital Authority for a structure placed on national land as part of or in association with a protest, but a permit not be required where the structure:
(a) is of a size which would have minimal impact on the land and is used to facilitate the protest, such as sound systems and small stages; and
(b) is erected and removed on the same day during daylight hours;

4. relevant legislative amendments be introduced to recognise protests as an appropriate use of national land and to enable the National Capital Authority to issue permits for the erection of protest structures;

5. the term `structure' be defined broadly to ensure that the myriad fixtures, edifices, constructions, vehicles, machinery and fixed display materials which could be used in association with a protest, including tents used for camping, come within the terms of the permit system;

6. in determining an application for a permit to erect a protest structure on national land, including the duration of a permit, the National Capital Authority be required to give due consideration to:
(a) the public's right to peaceful assembly on national land;
(b) issues regarding equality of access to national land;

(c) public interest considerations which may require certain limitations to be placed on the erection of structures, including public order, public health and safety, national security, the rights of other persons, and the proper functioning of the Parliament and other national institutions, including their ceremonial functions; and

(d) any specific requirements relating to the parliamentary precincts as determined by the Parliament's Presiding Officers, including existing requirements set down in their guidelines for protests in the parliamentary precincts;

7. guidelines on the erection of protest structures on national land, covering issues such as location, duration and public health and safety considerations, be developed by the National Capital Authority and be included in the information booklet proposed at recommendation 2;

8. on the basis of advice from the National Capital Authority or the Presiding Officers in relation to the parliamentary precincts, the Australian Federal Police be empowered to remove any protest structure on national land for which a permit is required under the system proposed at recommendation 3 but for which a permit has not been issued;

BREAK.PARA: A permit system currently operates in relation to works on national land which has been applied to the erection of structures associated with protest activity. These arrangements are administered by the National Capital Authority (NCA). There is provision for unauthorised structures to be removed and impounded. Under the "Guidelines for Protests, Demonstrations and Public Assemblies within the Parliamentary Precincts", permission must be obtained to erect structures in parliamentary precincts. A memorandum of understanding is being developed between the Minister responsible for the NCA and the Presiding Officers to ensure consistency of approach in dealing with protest activity including the erection of structures in the precincts and those areas in the Parliamentary Zone adjacent to the precincts.

In evidence before the committee, the NCA saw merit in having a specific permit system related to approval of structures or other activities (such as camping) associated with protest activity on national land. However, this proposal is vulnerable to arguments about the definition of a `protest' as opposed to other forms of public assembly. The NCA's proposal for a permit system is supported with the caveat that it apply to all activities and not only protests.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 9. the Unlawful Assemblies Ordinance 1937 be repealed;

BREAK.PARA: The Unlawful Assemblies Ordinance 1937 makes it an offence for more than 20 people to protest within 90 metres of Parliament House. We understand that the Ordinance has not been invoked for many years and its repeal is supported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 10. the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department, in consultation with the Australian Capital Territory Attorney-General's Department, review the existing laws which can apply to protests on national land to ensure that they are written in plain English and define clearly the powers which are available to relevant authorities in dealing with protests;

BREAK.PARA: The review of existing legislation in relation to protests on national land is supported. Clarity of the powers of the authorities involved in managing protests was an issue raised by the then Presiding Officers in their submission to the inquiry. This review should be conducted in consultation with the Presiding Officers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11. building on the memorandum of understanding established between the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Protective Service, clearly documented procedures for coordination of protests be developed between all relevant authorities involved with the management of protests on national land.

BREAK.PARA: The Parliament already has clear procedures in place in relation to the coordination and management of demonstrations in the parliamentary precincts, including the respective roles of the Presiding Officers, the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Protective Service.
Bob Halverson OBE MP Margaret Reid
4 September 1997
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
Speaker of the House of Representatives President of the Senate
Guidelines for Protests, Demonstrations and Public Assemblies within the Parliamentary Precincts

1. These Guidelines are issued pursuant to section 6 (1) of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 which provides that the precincts of the Parliament are under the control and management of the Presiding Officers.

2. In these Guidelines "protest", "demonstration" or "assembly" means one or more persons who meet or engage in a public activity for the purpose or on the pretext of making known a grievance or discussing public affairs.

3. Protests, demonstrations or public assemblies by persons or groups shall only be permitted in the authorised area within the Parliamentary Precincts. The authorised area is defined as that area bounded by the east and west lanes of Federation Mall and Parliament Drive as identified by flagpoles to the east and west and bollards or other defined barriers to the south. The defined area is shown at Attachment 1.

4. Participants in any protest, demonstration or assembly which may assemble within the authorised area of the Parliamentary Precincts shall arrive and depart the authorised area in an orderly manner without causing obstruction to traffic within the Parliamentary Precincts.
5. Participants shall not obstruct access to Parliament House by members of the general public and those persons entering or leaving the building in the normal course of their business.
6. Participants shall conduct themselves and assemble in such order as to avoid any breach of the peace.

7. Sound amplification may be permitted within the authorised area but shall be directed away from the Parliament building and shall not be permitted during ceremonial occasions or in any form which may disrupt the business of the Parliament.
8. Structures of any kind shall not be erected or placed within the Parliamentary Precincts without the permission of the appropriate authorities.

9. Vehicles including aircraft shall not be used as part of a protest, demonstration or assembly except for a vehicle authorised for use as a stage by the Parliament House Security Controller. No approval will be given for a stage to remain in the authorised area overnight.
10. Persons shall not camp within the Parliamentary Precincts.

11. Signs or banners shall not be erected with the precincts of the Parliament or attached to or hung from any built structure within the Parliamentary Precincts. Handheld signs or banners may be permitted.

PARA.TAB: Persons shall not wilfully mark by means of chalk, paint or any other material the land or built surfaces within the Parliamentary Precincts.

BREAK.PARA: 13. Food and beverages shall not be prepared or sold within the external precincts of the Parliament. Participants in protests, demonstrations or public assemblies shall not consume alcohol within the authorised area for the duration of the event.
14. Participants shall observe any lawful instructions given by Parliamentary Security, Australian Federal Police or Australian Protective Service officers.

15. Parliamentary Security Officers, members of the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Protective Service shall ensure that persons or groups intending to conduct a protest, demonstration or assembly shall not do so other than in the authorised area. Any persons entering an area other than the authorised area shall, where necessary, be moved within or removed from the Parliamentary Precincts. Non-compliance with Parliamentary Security, Australian Federal Police or Australian Protective Service directions may result in arrest.

16. Any breach of these Guidelines may be the subject of police investigation and subsequent action pursuant to relevant legislation. Section 15 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 provides for the application of laws of the Australian Capital Territory within the Parliamentary Precincts.
BOB HALVERSON OBE MP
MARGARET REID

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997 (No. 3)
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997, which is now before the chamber, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. I will outline the changes of substance.

The amendments contained in schedule two of this bill abolish the Canadian margin of preference on certain petrochemical products of chapter 39 of the customs tariff. These changes took effect from the first of January 1997.

Concerns have been expressed for some time regarding the overall balance of benefits under the Canada‐Australia Trade Agreement, CANATA. CANATA provides for the exchange of tariff preferences on a range of products traded between the two countries.

Most significantly, in 1995 Canada proposed the extension to several of its developing country trading partners preferential tariff treatment for raw sugar which would have been equivalent to that enjoyed by Australia under CANATA. Because of the significance of sugar in our overall exports to Canada (accounting for 20 per cent in 1995), such a decision would have had the impact of substantially eroding the overall value of CANATA preferences to Australia and shifting the balance of benefits under the agreement decisively in favour of Canada.
In addition, elements of the Australian manufacturing community have also registered some concern at the benefits accruing to Canadian exporters under CANATA.

Following consideration of these and other related issues, the trade minister advised the Canadian minister for international trade in 1995 of Australia's intention to remove CANATA preferential rates of duty from Canadian imports of certain petrochemical products, specifically polystyrene, polyvinyl chloride and polyvinyl esters.

Following a review of the situation by the incoming government and action by Canada to extend preferences on raw sugar, the minister for trade and the minister for industry, science and tourism decided to implement the withdrawal of the preferences on these petrochemical products. Trade in these products is currently at relatively low levels (amounting to only $1.6 million in 1995‐96). Moreover, the phase in the general rate of duty on the first of July 1996 to 5 per cent has meant that the possible impact on downstream users will be minimised.

Schedule three of this bill accords developing country preferences, under the Australian System of Tariff Preferences, ASTP, to imports from the territories administered by the Palestinian authority. This action was operative from the tenth of march 1997.

Honourable members will be aware of the middle east peace process started in Madrid in October 1991 and the Oslo declaration of principles whereby Israel is transferring to the palestinian council, powers and responsibilities for certain areas formerly administered by the Israeli Military Government. The Australian government fully supports the peace process and the implementation of these agreements.

The extension of ASTP concessions to the palestinian territories will assist their economy to transform itself to an exporter of products made in newly established industrial enterprises. It will also enhance bilateral trade with Australia.

Schedule four of this bill will operate from the first of July 1997. It contains amendments which will abolish customs duty on imported sugar and certain sugar by‐products and implements Australia's tariff obligations under the Information Technology Agreement, ITA.

In respect to the changes of duty on sugar, on the fourth of March this year, my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Honourable John Anderson MP, announced that the recommendations of the joint industry and government sugar industry review working party had been accepted by the Commonwealth government. These recommendations provide an integral package of reforms designed to promote a sustainable and internationally competitive sugar industry and for the removal of the customs rate of duty of $55 per tonne from sugar and certain sugar by‐products.
The recommendations have also been endorsed by the Queensland government and have the unani mous support of industry leaders on the working party.
The recommendations in regard to customs tariff rates of duty are implemented in this schedule.

In respect of the ITA, in Singapore, on the thirteenth of December 1996, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Honourable Tim Fischer MP signed on behalf of Australia the ministerial declaration on trade in information technology products—the information technology agreement.

Ita represents a package of sectoral liberalisation which, in combination with the agreement on basic telecommunications, establishes the trading framework which will underpin the continuing rapid growth of global information and communications infrastructure. The agreement seeks the elimination of tariffs on technology and telecommunications products by the year 2000.

When negotiations were completed on the twenty‐sixth of March this year, the ita had forty‐one member countries including our major APEC trading partners, the European union, other European countries and India. The signatories account for 92 percent of the $750 billion in world trade in these products. Each participant agreed to undertake the necessary domestic procedures to meet their commitments for the ita to come into force on the first of July 1997.

During the negotiations, australia made clear its requirements for an acceptable and balanced package of liberalisation being achieved and for the participation by a core of our regional trading partners. We ensured that the emerging asian markets participated in the agreement and that their participation was on a similar basis to that of Australia.
Australia stands to gain substantially from the ita. The agreement will provide australian industry with increased export opportunities to help redress the $6.9 billion trade deficit in this sector.

Australia could not have secured the market liberisation achieved under the ITA through direct bilateral negotiations. Working through APEC and the WTO allowed Australia, in coalition with other major economies, to bring our key regional trading partners to the ita negotiating table.

Schedule four of this bill also contains amendments to reinstate the intended tariff assistance on surgical drapes and clarify our international tariff obligations in regard to certain types of lamps and power supply units for computers.

The remainder of the amendments in schedules one and five are of an administrative nature. In the main they close‐up national seven and eight digit tariff splits which were created in the nineteen eighties to apply different rates of duty to certain textile goods. As the tariff phasing regime means the rates of duty will be the same from the first of July 1998, this opportunity has been taken to close‐up the tariff subheadings, where possible.
I commend the bill.
STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE (SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT) BILL 1997
Madam President, this bill introduces a statutory exemption for the Austudy and Abstudy schemes from the operation of the marital status discrimination provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.

At present the Austudy and Abstudy schemes discriminate on the basis of marital status in two key ways. Firstly, there are differences in the way legally married students are treated as compared to students in de facto relationships. Secondly, there are differences in the way legally married students are treated in comparison to single students.

A number of these differences go to the broader issue of the assumptions of dependency that underpin Commonwealth allowances generally. Rates of allowance and the income and assets tests, including those applied to receipt of rent assistance, are based on the assumptions, which also underpin other Commonwealth allowances, that a person with a partner has access to the financial means of their partner to meet their combined costs, and a single person who is independent of parental assistance does not have the opportunity to share costs for accommodation and other living expenses.

In addition to these broader issues, a number of the problems which Austudy and Abstudy has in relation to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 are specific to the schemes. Unlike the social security situation, the recognition of de facto relationships in the Austudy context would generally result in increased eligibility for benefits. In the social security context, beneficiaries actually have a financial disincentive for establishing de facto relationships, as their combined eligibility is reduced as a result.

In Austudy, a person who is married is considered to be independent for purposes of the scheme, and is eligible for a higher rate of Austudy than the rate payable to a student who is considered to be dependent. If de facto relationships are treated the same as marriage, that is as a ground for independent status, there would be financial incentives for establishing the existence of a de facto relationship so that the student is eligible for a higher rate of Austudy. This would make it difficult for the scheme administrators to verify the legitimacy of de facto relationships.
Abstudy experiences similar problems under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in relation to living allowances, income testing and eligibility for rent assistance.

The Austudy and Abstudy schemes, initially, had a legislative exemption from the operation of those provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 proscribing discrimination on the ground of marital status. The Austudy and Abstudy schemes currently have an administrative exemption from the human rights and equal opportunity commission in relation to the marital status provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. The administrative exemption expires on 31 December 1997.

Non‐legislative options for dealing with this issue have been explored, however, these would have serious social or financial repercussions. Failure to take the action proposed would mean that complaints could be made under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 once the existing administrative exemption has expired. It is therefore necessary that this amending legislation be in place by 1 January 1998.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.
Ordered that these bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Carr, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes, with concern:
(a) the severe deterioration in the relationship between the Howard Government and the States resulting from actions and policies of the Howard Government;
(b) the worsening relationship between the Prime Minister and State Premiers;
(c) the unreasonable demands of the Howard Government that the States and Territories fund Commonwealth initiatives; and
(d) attempts by the Howard Government to implement cost shifting arrangements to the States and Territories over a range of program areas such as aged care, health and education.

This motion obviously expresses concern about the government's mismanagement of an absolutely essential part of our national economy—that is, federal-state relations. Unfortunately, this issue has attracted media attention for all the wrong reasons. Headlines such as `Howard attacks Kennett on high taxes' and `Kennett talks down federal feud' are appearing in the media with monotonous regularity.

BREAK.PARA: Originally it was my intention to incorporate many of these media references into my comments today, but I ended up having to incorporate them into my notes because what I had would have made a thick pile, and I decided that in the chamber I would probably get lost in the maze. For the media are now highlighting time and time again what appears to be a complete breakdown in federal-state relations at a time when such relations are absolutely crucial, particularly given the High Court's recent decision to prohibit the states from raising revenue through franchise fees.

The government has put in place measures to enable the states and territories to retrieve the approximately $5 billion per annum in revenue that they raised through these measures. Let us hope that these measures produce a more stable long-term solution to the problem than might have been expected after we witnessed the absolute shambles of the initial federal response to the problem.

We ask: why has the relationship between the states and the federal government reached such a low point? My contention in moving this motion is that, as with its lack of leadership on the economy, and most particularly jobs and growth, the government, through its arrogance and incompetence, has completely mismanaged federal-state relations.

I would like to examine the first two points of the motion together—that is, the deterioration in Commonwealth-state relations resulting from actions and policy of the Commonwealth government and the worsening relations between the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the state premiers.

A recent article in the Courier‐Mail contained a title which adequately sums up the frustration and despair of the states—`States of confusion'. It is fair to say that federal-state relations got off on a fairly rocky road right from the very start. You would think, with all but one of the premiers in the country being Liberal, that relations would have been more smooth. But not for this government. You would have thought that a government whose ideology is to favour states rights and which has an ideology of devolution could do more than just simply devolve costs. That is all that has been happening, and that is what the premiers have been complaining about.

The previous Labor government had initiated major federal-state reforms through the COAG process. Reforms were made in areas such as health, disability services, electricity supply, gas supply and competition policy. COAG had been established to resolve the often overlapping and conflicting Commonwealth‐state roles and responsibilities in the critical areas of service delivery, such as health and aged care. For example, it is estimated that the duplication between the Commonwealth, state and local governments in the health care system is costing taxpayers up to $1.5 billion per year. But it has all been stalled.

These reforms under Labor were conducted cooperatively and for the most part in good spirit, notwithstanding the occasional tensions which arose and premiers from different parties. But this government has made a hash of its relations with the states from day one. In the first year of office it decided to cut $1.5 billion in revenue to the states over the three years starting from 1996-97. This was the so-called fiscal contribution.

But on top of that fiscal contribution—whatever your arguments for that may have been—it undertook a range of funding cuts in a number of sensitive service areas. It announced cuts of $120 million over three years to legal aid, Senator O'Brien. After adjustments, negotiations with the states and public protests—all listed throughout the media—the cuts are now closer to $75 million. It also decided to cut $80 million in funding from the state public hospitals system over a four-year period from the 1996-97 budget. Victorian hospitals have certainly suffered from this measure.

Major roads were not a priority either. The government, in its first budget, decided to trim an additional $622 million off the national highways scheme funding over a four‐year period. For good measure, on top of all of this, $400 million was cut from nursing home care with the additional introduction of means‐tested up‐front entry fees for nursing homes. Anyone listening to Senator Newman would think it was a little fairytale, but we know and the public know that this means people our age now will have to sell their family home to get a nursing home bed.

Getting back to the original point, how are these measures supposed to facilitate federal‐state relations? It is not surprising that we are hearing the stories we are. The states had to respond to these federal government initiatives by closing hospitals and hospital beds, cutting access to legal aid and reducing public housing. Not only did the government savagely cut funds to the states in critical areas, but they also stalled on processing major reform agendas which had been initiated under the previous Labor government and would have saved money. They would have saved duplication and they would have allowed some of these sensitive service areas to continue—such as the dental scheme.

COAG meetings to proceed these reforms were delayed and are still being delayed. COAG has not met since June of last year. As a result, it is not surprising that the states are confused and concerned. They are asking questions—questions such as: what is happening to Medicare? They remember that the federal government is supposed to negotiate an agreement with the states by 1 July 1998. But where is the evidence of any progress in such an essential service area? Why are health ministers still unaware, at this close stage, of what level of funding may be available for funding public hospitals in 1998?

After Minister Wooldridge met his state counterparts last month, the New South Wales health minister, Dr Refshauge, was scathing about the talks, the seventh in the last 14 months on the Medicare agreement. It was reported:
`The meeting has been a dismal failure,' he said. `We have been asking what is the amount of money that is going to be put into public hospitals?'

Obviously we have been getting no response. But Dr Refshauge and the other health ministers can take heart. At least now they know that the Medicare agreement will be called the `Australian health care agreement'. We have a title—after 14 meetings!

There is a belief by state ministers that COAG has been killed off by the Howard government as a reform vehicle. This has caused concern to the states because COAG is quite clearly the best mechanism to achieve reform. We have learnt that from progress to date. Anyway, what hope is there for the reform process when there are differences between key ministers such as Dr Wooldridge and the Treasurer, Mr Costello? It is problematic. Last November, Dr Wooldridge pointed to the problems for the reform when he said of Mr Costello:
What do you expect when you have a Treasurer who believes that aged care is simply a matter of buying a pair of incontinence pads.
You guys talk about yourselves that way!

Mr Costello certainly has done his best to foster federal‐state relations. One of Mr Costello's more notable efforts at building federal‐state relations was an attempt in 1996 to remove, without any prior consultation, the wholesale sales tax exemptions which applied to state governments. In fact, Mr Costello has been so successful at building relations that his purported political ally, coalition Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, was quoted in a Courier‐Mail article on 12 August 1997 as claiming:
As usual, Mr Costello is not being much help. He can't help himself; it's a personality problem.
Who wants enemies when you have friends like that!

Mr Howard's lack of leadership in this area has been stunningly obvious. Instead of speaking individually with the premiers, he resorts to attacking them. He attacks the conservative state premiers of Victoria, Western Australia and Queensland in, of all places, coalition party room meetings, accusing them of shunning the national interest. Mr Borbidge took Mr Howard's attack so seriously that he subsequently claimed in parliament that internal party research showed that his government was travelling a lot better than the Howard administration.

This reference to internal party research had followed an article in the Bulletin where Mr Borbidge's press secretary, Mr Frank Jackson, had written to Laurie Oakes threatening to release highly reputable research if Mr Howard continued to attack the Queensland Premier. We are getting along very well, guys! This is at a time when the Howard office is negotiating with the premiers a special summit on tax reform. I would like to be a fly on the wall.

Mr Howard has not been forgotten by South Australia. The Premier of South Australia, Mr John Olsen, demonstrated his dissatisfaction with Mr Howard at a Rotary Club function in Melbourne in April, where he accused the Howard government of `lacking vision in its economic policies' and `working in a policy vacuum'. We know that they have been saying that in respect of other areas, such as industry policy, for some time.

The essence of the deteriorating relationship between the federal government and the states is the unwillingness of the federal government to confront urgent issues that need attention. They react only when a crisis occurs, such as the High Court decision. Given that the High Court decision had the capacity to wipe out 16 per cent of state revenues immediately, it was amazing that there was no contingency plan—it was, `We were just hanging around waiting for it to happen. We had no idea of what they were going to do about it. We're not really in government. Who knows what leadership really is!' Why, immediately after the decision was handed down, were the federal and state governments frantically scrambling around trying to find a solution to a $5 billion disaster like passengers on the Titanic seeking lifeboats?

The Howard government's determination that states and territories fund Commonwealth initiatives is another major problem. Initiatives such as the government's TAFE funding plan are abhorred by the states. Again, the government has managed to enrage conservative state and territory governments with its TAFE measures.

This time the government, through the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), is guaranteeing that it will maintain the Commonwealth's contribution to TAFE funding, worth $4.5 billion over five years at current real levels, but only if the states fund the growth of up to 500,000 places over five years out of efficiency sav ings. In return, the Commonwealth will not impose any future cuts over a five-year period.

The efficiency dividend was, according to Minister Kemp, identified in a report by the Australian National Training Authority entitled Funding growth in VET places under a new ANTA agreement. However, an inspection of the report reveals that the authority sees the attainment of this efficiency dividend as problematic, like relations between states and the federal government. Additionally, the document goes on to undermine the entire basis of Dr Kemp's proposals to the states by admitting that `a reliable estimate of real efficiency possibilities as opposed to notional possibilities requires access to detailed information on state-territory system budgets that is not available'.

In response, the Victorian minister for training, Mr Honeywood, claimed that the TAFE funding plan may lead to the dismantling of the system and the introduction of university style fees. Mr Honeywood also claimed that the federal plan was `viewed by the states as a way of forcing them to deliver up to 40 per cent more TAFE places with no extra funds from the Commonwealth'. He questioned whether the aim was to dismantle the TAFE system by squeezing it to produce impossible efficiencies while—and listen to this—encouraging private providers to take over training, which may well be the real agenda, and you have a conservative state complaining about it.

Mr Honeywood has also labelled Dr Kemp as a total centralist who is trying to force the states to sign an agreement which would represent the biggest cost shift since Federation—devolution of costs. In fact relations between Dr Kemp and Mr Honeywood are so bad that Mr Honeywood has called for the responsibility for the TAFE sector to be taken away from Dr Kemp. Perhaps we should give it to Senator Vanstone—give her a bit of a boost, a bit of a promotion; it would not hurt her at the moment.

The atmosphere of crisis was further exacerbated as late as yesterday when Dr Kemp called on Mr Honeywood to guarantee state funding for the TAFE sector for five years. This was explained quite rationally by Mr Honeywood as an impossibility, as the Victorian government was unable to lock in funding for five years when the state budget was prepared annually and could not anticipate demand level for a sector over the time frame proposed. Dr Kemp's sensitive response was this explanation to the state:
Failure to provide a stable funding base leaves a cloud of uncertainty over the future of TAFE colleges.

What about all these young unemployed people who are now going to be in the vocational training sector because they cannot get any assistance in any other way? It is obvious that they are going to have problems getting access to training as well because it has been devolved to the states and they do not have the funds. The coalition's announcement this week of 220,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships over the next two years has also brought a scathing response from Mr Honeywood, who claimed that the new apprenticeship scheme was so poorly designed that it might force the government into setting up a HECS scheme for TAFE colleges. Mr Honeywood said that the Victorian government would have to find up to $54 million to fund new TAFE places created by the scheme—the state government, not the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth announces measures, but the states have to fund them; that seems to be the new style. However, Mr Honeywood was pessimistic about finding the funding. He said:
I won't (find the money). The Premier and our Government have a policy of not filling a financial hole that's been left by the Commonwealth.

Federal-state relations is one of the most important elements of government in Australia. Under the Howard government this relationship is a shambles. It is a shambles because of the lack of leadership by the Prime Minister and his senior ministers. A new senator from the coalition came in yesterday and she was beaming with praise in relation to her state Premier. But what did we hear about the Prime Minister? Nothing. That is where the leadership is in her mind, at the state level, and we have nothing at the Commonwealth level.

Just as the Prime Minister has offered no leadership to the country in a whole range of areas, such as economic policy, jobs and jobs growth—I have already referred to industry policy, and the promotion and defence of our multicultural community—he has shown a total lack of leadership in building a positive relationship between the Commonwealth and our states and territories. Ordinary Australian citizens are the ones that lose out again and the ideology is not even met from the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also in this general business debate on Senator Carr's motion on Commonwealth-state relations. The motion starts by Senator Carr saying, `That the Senate notes with concern'. If Senator Carr is so concerned about this issue, where is he? Senator Carr is not opposite. I look down the list of speakers in vain; there is no Senator Carr. I wonder whether this motion is in order. If Senator Carr is moving a motion that he is incredibly concerned about this matter, where is he? He is so concerned that he does not even bother to turn up.
—I'll bring him back if you want.
—Do; please bring him back.
—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like to bring to the Senate's attention the fact that I moved this motion on behalf of Senator Carr and it is indeed in order.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you for that contribution, Senator Collins. I know that you did say that, but my point is still valid. If Senator Carr was so concerned about this matter, one would have thought that surely he would have turned up. But the nub of Senator Collins's very wide ranging speech that sort of wandered everywhere was about the budget savings in relation to states and that there was $1½ billion less for states. Of course you will recall, Senator Collins, the whole reason for that in the budget context of the times was the $10 billion Beazley black hole that we all faced.

SPEECH.PARA: What are you suggesting, Senator Collins? That perhaps in repairing this budget deficit the states take no role in that at all? Surely the states have other means to raise money. I point to New South Wales, my state. Apart from an absolute windfall the state government is now getting in its finances from the real estate market and the stamp duties that come from that, it is proposing to flog off the $26 billion electricity industry. The New South Wales government, for one, is going to be awash with money and, with the excellent reforms to the Victorian economy, I am sure the Victorian government will be as well. That was the nub of Senator Collins's arguments in the earlier part of the debate.

Senator Jacinta Collins went on to discuss how this government was not getting on particularly well with the states and territories. I feel that is a bit rich on a number of counts. At the Northern Territory election on the weekend we had an absolutely romp home victory, totally devastating the Labor Party in the Northern Territory. It does not seem that the territorians are that concerned about the issue she has raised today. They seem very comfortable not only with their territory government but also with the federal government.

The other point that she raised related to getting a better balance between the state and federal governments in terms of who is doing what and in their relationships. I am amazed that she is showing such concern about the states, given the Labor Party's track record and attitude towards the states in our federation. We only have to go back to that great Labor icon Gough Whitlam to find out Labor's attitude to the states. It wants to abolish them. That keeps coming out time and again in Labor rhetoric. That great centralist Gough Whitlam was saying this 25 years ago, but we have some more recent examples. Bob Hawke, a former Prime Minister and Labor leader, had plenty to say about that in his `20-20 Vision' speech in 1993:

I assert now that Australia would be much better off without the level of state government. All my experience as leader of this country for nearly nine years reinforces without qualification my argument.
Mr Hawke went even further, to advocate the elimination of the states:
I would like to see the debate extend to the abolition of one tier of government, the dismantling of the states.
Former Labor Premier Neville Wran leaves no-one in any doubt about his thoughts on the federal system. His words are brief but certainly unmask federal Labor on this issue:
State governments . . . we'd be better off without them.

I now want to focus on some of the specific claims that have been made about state-federal relations. I am going to focus on the claims made in relation to education. Senator Collins raised a number of issues in that area. My colleague Senator Synon will be talking about health issues, Senator Troeth will be talking about family services and Senator Ferris will be talking particularly about Labor's relationship with the states, I suspect some of the minor states. We have an interesting contribution at the end from Senator McGauran.

I will focus initially on the ALP's flawed claims about cost shifting arrangements between the state and federal governments in the area of education. This is where I am incredibly surprised, again, that Senator Carr is not here for this debate, having given notice of a motion—because I know this is one of his pet areas of interest. He keeps making these assertions through various committees and in the chamber at various times. I want to point out that what he has been saying is arrant nonsense, using figures from official figures to show that this is the case.

Government schools will receive over the next four years another $2.3 billion. Commonwealth funding per student will increase by about 17 per cent in government schools and by about 14 per cent in non-government schools over these four years in an era of incredibly low inflation. So there will be real gains. Even though, as I mentioned before, there were enormous budget difficulties repairing the Beazley black hole, this government has made a major commitment to education and to schools by providing those increased amounts for the public schools and for the private schools.

There is a focus in all of that on a number of key areas where we have to repair Labor's neglect over its 13 years. In that money the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr David Kemp, has promised another $160 million for literacy, $156 million for students with special learning difficulties, $54 million for language studies and $187 million over four years to expand vocational education and training in the secondary school system, an area which was greatly neglected by the Labor government.

I want to take particular issue with the ALP's false assertion that the Howard government is shifting these costs from the Commonwealth to the states. I want to talk, in particular, about another one of Senator Carr's favourite topics—what a great pity he is not here—the enrolment benchmark adjustment figure. He does a lot of voodoo economics on that but disguises the reality of what is happening.

In this country we have a very gradual drift from the public to the private system. Labor has been very alarmist about that and says that, as students shift, a disproportionate shift in funding will follow. That has been disproved by the figures.

For a start, the actual shift in numbers of students is quite small. The figures are out for the first year, and they reveal that the net number of new schools, over the increase in Labor's last year, was seven—across the whole of Australia. For every state and territory, that is about one new school above what was happening each year under Labor. Big deal! What was the scare campaign all about towards the end of last year? There is not a great deal of shift from the public to the private sector, and it has slowed down. Even the projections we have laid down will probably prove to be too high.

But, under this enrolment benchmark adjustment, when students do shift from the public to the private system, only half the $3,400 in funding for that student follows them to the private schools. The private schools might claim that that is a bit unfair. Why should they not get all $3,400? They get $1,700, and $1,700 stays with the state system, even though the state system does not have the student any more. This is one of the reasons that states like New South Wales are screaming about this one—what they used to do was pocket the money. They used to put it back into consolidated revenue. They used to put the lot back—all $3,400. Under this arrangement they can probably still pocket the $1,700—which, as I mentioned, they keep even though the pupil has gone—but what we would certainly encourage them to do is to spend it on pupils in the schools.

The second area in education that I want to briefly focus on relates to the Australian National Training Authority and what we are doing in that area. Again, the minister has made a very generous offer to the states. He has promised that the Commonwealth will maintain funding at the 1998 level for the following five years—this is a federal government offer for vocational education and training of $4.5 billion.

In this government we have a major focus on vocational education and training. If you look at the record of the last Labor government, over 13 years you had a situation where, under the so‐called Working Nation program, which was directed at the long‐term unemployed, 70 per cent of those people never got a job, and so they wasted an enormous amount of money on training that led nowhere.

What we are going to be doing is focusing on training that will lead to jobs, particularly for youth. The level of youth unemployment when Labor left office was 34 per cent, and we have that legacy to contend with. That is why the minister has created the new apprenticeship system and has promised to deliver another 200,000 places in that scheme. I had the honour to be at the launch of that scheme last week. It is a new approach which will be more flexible, will be delivered in a way which is more in accord with what employers are doing and will cover a very wide range of areas—not just traditional trades. It will cover tourism, hospitality, sport, on‐line services and electronic commerce as well as these other measures.

BREAK.PARA: In the education areas—both schools and apprenticeships—that I have dealt with, what I have said has proved that the sort of cost shifting claims made by the Labor Party are blatantly false and that this government has a real commitment in those areas to supporting what are the major responsibilities of the states by providing proper funding for those measures. I have dealt with education, and when my colleagues speak they will deal with a number of other areas which will prove what a nonsense this motion is. What a pity Senator Carr was not here to hear what I had to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought the article in yesterday's Age under the heading `Media laws backdown prompts ridicule' would have given a note of concern to Senator Tierney when he put forward his proposition. I will be very interested to hear the comments of Senator Synon about the obviously poisonous relationship between Premier Kennett and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his government.
—You will be waiting a long time.

—I am very keen to hear that, because it seems to me to be an integral part of this debate. Mr Kennett is quoted in the article—and I am sure it is not a false quote. The passage I refer to says Mr Jeff Kennett:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . opted for sarcasm to taunt his Liberal Party colleagues.
"I don't want to be subject to another party‐room lashing . . . " Mr Kennett said

The Premier of Victoria—and party colleague of the Prime Minister and of other members of the coalition who are going to speak in this debate—considers that his criticisms of this government will only lead to another party room lashing by the Prime Minister. What a wicked sense of humour Mr Kennett has.

In looking through the clippings and comments that have been made about this government by state and territory governments, the only state and territory leaders I can find who have a kind word for this government or this Prime Minister are those who are either involved in or about to be involved in an election campaign—and only when they are in receipt of some pork‐barrelling promise or poll‐driven development decision or go‐ahead promise. Is it surprising that we see the Northern Territory government or the South Australian government smiling and saying, `Thank you for the promise of some federal money just before our election campaigns'?

In that context they are hardly likely to say that the Darwin to Alice Springs railway promise is the sort of pie in the sky promise which, frankly, it seems to be. That is not just me talking. The Western Australian government representative on transport has the same view, talking about a pie in the sky promise which is basically for an election campaign. We cannot take that seriously.

But we have had numerous examples of conflict between this government and the states on issues not just of funding but also of social policy, the role of the states and the involvement of the Commonwealth in preventing the states from exercising their proper roles. Let us look at the recent heroin trials issue. All state and territory health ministers had agreed to a process, and that agreement involved the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge). The process was not only agreed; it was agreed after a lengthy discussion period.

The situation was that, after the government's own minister had agreed to this, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) decided that he was going to roll it in cabinet. Was he criticised for this? Of course he was. He was criticised by Mr Kennett and he was criticised by Kate Carnell here in the ACT. He acted after an agreement was reached. What a way to deal with state and territory governments: to sit down with them, to negotiate with them over many months, to agree with a process, through your health minister, and then to roll them, to say, `I have got a way of undermining this. We did agree but I am going to change it. After we have agreed, I am going to roll this agreement. I am going to use an ability I have to effectively block this, even though I have agreed with it.' What a way to deal with the relations between the states and territories and the Commonwealth.

BREAK.PARA: Many will say in relation to the euthanasia debate that this was a private member's bill, but I do not think there can be any doubt that the Northern Territory government blamed the Howard government and the Prime Minister for an attitude that its legislation could be overridden. There is no doubt that that is the view; that is the publicly expressed view of Mr Stone, the Chief Minister. There was also comment on that issue in relation to the federal government's position from Mr Kennett. Again, the states and territories that I have mentioned considered that their rights were being overridden by this government—a government that professed to support states rights.

We have had an attack on the legal aid funding system by this government, effectively saying to the states, `We are going to withdraw from the arrangement that has been in place for many years. We are going to set up a new arrangement, and we are not really interested in what you have to say.' I was interested to see the comments made by Mr Foss, the Western Australian Attorney‐General, in relation to what he described as the attitude of Mr Williams, the Attorney‐General. He said, in a letter to Mr Williams which was reproduced in the West Australian:
You have created a crisis by your unilateral decision . . . I would have thought the duty was on you to fix the mess you have caused.
I understand you don't like the States criticising your decision and warn that you may retaliate in kind. You apparently don't like the truth, and you seem to forget that you started all of this.

The terminology of that exchange between a state minister of a Liberal government in Western Australia, in fact a state minister from his own state—Mr Williams represents a Western Australian electorate—and the coalition government at a Commonwealth level reflects an absolute crisis in the relationship between the two ministers, and that, frankly, depicts the relationship between that federal minister and other state and territory ministers on the issue of legal aid. I frankly say that it depicts the level of relationship between this government and the state and territory governments, which are predominantly governments of the same political persuasion as this federal government.

We have seen attacks on Family Court funding, and there has been a lot of concern in my state, the state of Tasmania, about closure of family courts in breach of undertakings given before the election. What have we seen there? We have seen a reduction in the level of service to the state of Tasmania which is out of proportion to the level of population serviced, say, in Sydney. No proper consideration has been given to this by this government.

We have the example with the superannuation surcharge, or tax—we know it is a tax, not a surcharge. This government was seeking to impose this tax on the states and have them administer it for their employees. The states quite rightly said, `You do not have the capacity to impose that on us.' That is another issue of conflict between the states and the federal government.

We have had many attacks on this federal government by state governments, particularly the South Australian government and the Victorian government, on the issue of car tariffs. Finally, those attacks and the attacks of the Australian Labor Party on this government led to this government's absolute backflip on the issue of car tariffs. They had to run up the white flag and say, `We can't sustain our ideological position on this. We are going to change policy.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't think you had a view on it. You don't have one on anything else.
—We are keen to see, Senator Macdonald, how quickly the white flag is run up on the question of textiles, clothing and footwear—
—What is your policy on that?

—You know what our policy is. Premier Kennett's position on this is absolutely clear. He has no time for any position other than the freeze on tariffs that this party is calling for. He is at one with the Labor Party on this issue, as I understand his comments. Frankly, we have not heard from this government anything that gives us any certainty about what might happen. Is this going to be another issue of conflict between the Commonwealth and not just Victoria but all states which have an interest in the preservation of jobs in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

BREAK.PARA: The Premier of Tasmania, my state, is in Canberra or about to arrive, I believe, to discuss that very issue. He wants an assurance from this government that the industry will be protected so that hundreds of jobs in the state of Tasmania will be protected—just as the other premiers want assurances. There is terrible uncertainty over this issue.

While he is here he will also be talking about the RFA process and the agreement that is under negotiation in Tasmania. Premier Rundle is on the record as saying that the only thing that is preventing the finalisation of the negotiation and nailing down of the regional forest agreement for Tasmania is the money that the Commonwealth must put into the process to make it workable. Premier Rundle has said that the Commonwealth has not come up to the mark, to the expectation, to the promises made to fund the RFA process.

But it is not just Premier Rundle who is saying that. He has the support of the industry in Tasmania. I am not talking about the CFMEU, which has the same view, but also all the employer and contractor groups in the industry. They have the same view. What did the Prime Minister say yesterday? He effectively said, `Premier Rundle and all of you industry groups are not being honest; you are not being accurate. We have provided more than enough money for the fulfilling of the RFA process, for the completion of the process.' Frankly, he is the only one who believes that. There is no‐one in the industry in Tasmania who believes it. There is no‐one involved in the process who believes it. The Premier of Tasmania does not believe it and he is here to convince the Prime Minister that he is wrong. What sort of relationship can the Prime Minister have with his own political colleagues, the Premier of Tasmania being an example, when he is effectively saying, `You're misleading the public because we are offering all the money you need.' It is not true that this government is coming up to the mark on its promises on the RFA—just as it does not come up to the mark on many other issues.

Of course, there have been issues in relation to Queensland. We had the backflip by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) over drought relief for certain areas in the state of Queensland. And in relation to reviews of areas of Western Australia, I was present when Senator Crane was absolutely astonished by the process followed by Minister Anderson in relation to drought relief. The Western Australian government was equally critical of this government in relation to the withdrawal of the drought relief declaration in certain areas of Western Australia.
From the state of Queensland, the minister for primary industry, Mr Perrett, said he was:
. . . rapidly losing confidence in Mr Anderson's handling of the worsening Queensland drought conditions.

He also described Mr Anderson as `callous and foolish'. If that is the sort of terminology that describes a good relationship between state and federal ministers then, frankly, the English language needs a rework. It certainly does not mean that to any reasonable or thinking person.

And, while we are on the subject of Queensland, Mr Borbidge has said of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, that he has a personality problem. That depicts a great personal relationship between the Queensland government—a coalition government—and this federal coalition government. We have also heard what the New South Wales health minister, Mr Refshauge, thought about Mr Wooldridge.

We have also heard descriptions about what Dr Honeywood from the Victorian government said about the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp. As reported in the paper, he `called for his removal from responsibility for TAFE until he agreed to work with the states'. If you have friends like that, you do not need enemies. Dr Honeywood and all the other people that I have mentioned—ministers in state governments, premiers of state governments, territory ministers, chief ministers—have expressed views which are extremely deprecatory of this government and its relationship with the states and territories.

This government and federal ministers, including the Prime Minister, have made an art form of slagging state premiers and ministers whenever there is an issue on which there is a disagreement. If you go through the media clippings from Premier Kennett in relation to his relationship with the Prime Minister, I think you could fill a couple of volumes. On 27 February this year the Age said:

The Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett, risked further strained relations with the Federal Government yesterday by dismissing its much‐vaunted $600 million private health insurance plan as money down the drain.
On 8 March he said, when describing the actions—or inaction—of the federal government:
We're seeing our automotive industry under attack. We're seeing textiles, clothing and footwear under attack. We're seeing the pharmaceutical industry about to be destroyed.
On 7 March in the Australian he is reported this way:
Mr Kennett disputed Wednesday's claim by the Treasurer, Mr Costello, that 3.75 per cent economic growth by June was still "quite achievable".
He has taken you on on your economic forecasts as well as on policy issues. The Age of 14 March reads:
The Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett, yesterday again broke ranks with the Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, condemning his work‐for‐the‐dole scheme as crazy and irrelevant for the 21st century.
What a great relationship there is between this government and Premier Kennett.

Little more needs to be said other than that this government has an appalling relationship with the states. Enough has been said, particularly by Senator Jacinta Collins, about the awful cost shifting of this government. If I go to what Senator Tierney said about the basis for cost shifting, being the tired and worn reference to the so‐called $10 billion budget black hole, I am curious as to why he did not also mention the $3 billion budget black hole of Treasurer Costello, which Treasurer Costello decided to shore up by taking an advance from Telstra—asking it to borrow the money, which in effect is taking an advance from the sale of Telstra because it will reduce the value of Telstra. It must do so because it adds to its debt. By taking that money, instead of the money from Telstra repaying debt, which was the government's promise, the money from Telstra—or that portion of it—is going into recurrent expenditure. This is the great Treasurer of principle. Is it any wonder that this government's relationship with the states is so low? The states know that there is no principle that they can rely on behind this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to rise again in this place within 24 hours of giving my maiden speech. I regret, however, that I rise to speak on such an irrelevant and peripheral motion. I am confident that the political posturing to which this motion refers is very far from the hearts and minds of Australians. It is somewhat of a shame that the time we have given and will give to this debate could not have been more usefully spent discussing some of the issues more critical to the hearts and minds of Australians—perhaps even unemployment. But then, of course, Labor would have to admit to presiding over the highest unemployment levels that this country has ever seen—one million people. And so we have a Labor Party being as irrelevant in opposition as they were in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead we are here to discuss what is merely the natural flow of bids and counterbids between the Commonwealth and the states, a process that has been going on for dozens of years. In fact, the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Shane Stone, was asked on Sunday on the Nine Network this question by Laurie Oakes:
So you don't want $300 million?
Mr Stone said in response:
Well, I would have liked as much as I could've got. You know what it's like in federal‐state relations, there's always the big bid.

This motion of Senator Carr's, moved by proxy, seeks to drive out of desperation a wedge into the most successful political coalition this country has ever seen. It will not work. The Liberal Party or coalition is in government in every state and territory, other than New South Wales, and it is just a shame that the ALP cannot spend some of its time more usefully developing solid alternative policies.

Senator O'Brien talked of Queensland. May I, Madam Acting Deputy President, also talk of Queensland? Senator Carr's motion is simply an example of the pot calling the kettle black. We all know about Premier Wayne Goss's constant chiding of Keating for rarely visiting the state of Queensland. His party's polling showed that Labor voters in its Brisbane heartland were deeply hostile to the then federal government. After Goss's defeat, in The Victory by Pamela Williams, Goss brutally assessed the former government's chances of winning in 1996:

Queenslanders are sitting on their verandahs with baseball bats just waiting for Keating to come. They've been sitting there for a long time. But the really chilling thing is they don't care how long they have to wait. They will get him whenever he comes.
May I suggest, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that is an example of severe deterioration?

However, I would like to turn to the positives, and there are many positive examples of our party working closely together with our state and territory colleagues. One very recent example is, of course, the funding announcement of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line out of the Federation Fund: $300 million—a splendid example of territories and governments working together.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy, I would like you to listen to this, please. The federal, state and territory health ministers under Labor met once a year. Under our government, they have met seven times since March 1996, with a further meeting scheduled for November this year. The coalition recognises that dialogue and communication is critical and it is committed to that end. For the first time, the Commonwealth and the states are working together to address the underlying structure of the health system and are cooperating in exploring better ways of delivering services and pooling funds. Indicative of that is the COAG decision of 1996 and the Aus tralian Health Ministers Conference communiques of 1996 and 1997—and perhaps the ALP members on the opposite side might care to peruse those at some stage. For the first time, the states and the territories have joined together with the Commonwealth in combined integrated health promotion campaigns tackling the critical issues of child immunisation and tobacco usage.

SPEECH.PARA: In education, there are many issues and initiatives arising out of MCEETYA, the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs. These are just some of them: national benchmarks for numeracy and literacy; a new national review of the goals for schooling in Australia; a national strategy in schooling to prevent paedophilia; collaborative work on education programs for gifted and talented children; early childhood education; guidelines to implement apprenticeships and traineeships whilst in the school system; capital works programs to upgrade existing schools and build new schools; improving the immunisation rate of Australian children at school; a national approach to the Olympic education schools campaign; and a national teacher recruitment strategy. Clearly, these are not outward manifestations of a severe deterioration in relations between the Commonwealth, states and territories.

The bids and counterbids that I referred to earlier are not reflective of fundamental relationship difficulties but of our taxation system. We have a taxation system that is driven by vertical fiscal imbalance, a situation stemming from Labor's actions during the Second World War where the income taxing powers were taken from the state governments and, despite challenges, the federal Labor government retained them after the war.

In 1982, the Liberal Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, in a spirit of conciliation, passed legislation to assist the states in the event that they wished to raise income themselves. This legislation indicated that the Commonwealth would collect tax on behalf of the states, if they wished, and forward the money on to them.

In 1989, this legislation, having been passed initially to assist the states, was repealed by Keating as part of his ongoing war with the states. This mood of cooperation fostered by the Fraser government was lost until the advent of the Howard government last year.
The Hawke years were certainly not conducive to positive Commonwealth-state relations. The darling of the Labor left, Joan Kirner, said in the Herald‐Sun on 27 April 1992:
All the state premiers will be saying we cannot any longer tolerate the situation where we have to provide the services but the Commonwealth constantly cuts back on the money.
Does that sound familiar? I suggest it does. Further, Labor's Wayne Goss, proving that relations were not smooth, even with Hawke, said on 7 May 1992 in an ABC radio interview:

All states and territories want reform of Commonwealth State relations. The truth is the Commonwealth has cut the states back in their grants in the last 10 years. The states have been made to take the cuts while the Commonwealth has not cut its own budget.
This is Hawke; this is the ALP; this is the pot calling the kettle black.

We are working well together. The Premier of my home state, Jeff Kennett, acknowledges that governments `must not shirk the hard calls', as reported on 20 September 1992 in A fresh start for Victoria, published by La Trobe University.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we would come to Jeff.
—Hansard records that he said on 3 May 1995, Senator Conroy:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal government must reduce its expenditure and the number of areas in which it operates.

He was asking the then Labor government to attack the fiscal side of the federal economy. The government shirked the responsibility. As a result, we have a $10 billion black hole. This government has not shirked the responsibility—we will not and we are not. Now you are in opposition, and it is no wonder.

I referred earlier to the vertical fiscal imbalance. Until this country has a fully honest partisan debate on taxation, we will face the same issues year after year from coalition and Labor premiers alike. We have a dysfunctional taxation system which is the root of these problems—not personalities.

Tax reform is necessary so as to prevent the political grandstanding undertaken by premiers of all political persuasions at premiers conferences. Again, Victoria's Premier knows that and, as reported in the Age of 20 August 1997, acknowledges that the Prime Minister, John Howard, has:
. . . given him confidence that we are embarking on structural tax reform . . .
He was heartened that the Prime Minister was serious about fundamental changes to the country's taxation system. In the Age of 20 August 1997 he said:
[The Prime Minister] is committed to generational change. That is music for me.

In fact, Jeff Kennett offered to act as a roving ambassador to the federal government. That does not sound like a relationship in deterioration to me. The difficulty here is that the ALP cannot concede that in one coalition party we might have many exceptional leaders. I was interested to hear that Senator Jacinta Collins and Senator O'Brien are keen to hear my views about my state premier, Jeff Kennett, and my Prime Minister, John Howard.

May I suggest that in our party competence, strong leadership and vision are not mutually exclusive. They are not confined to one person alone. As I said yesterday in my first speech in this House, I am proud to have worked for the Kennett government. I think he is a man of vision and strength. I am equally proud of the Prime Minister, John Howard. He is a man of vision, strength, integrity and determination and he will see us through the fundamental tax debate that we have to have in this country. We will therefore no longer have to spend our valuable time in this House pondering personality differences that are merely a reflection of a dysfunctional taxation system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The federal coalition stands condemned for its smug attitude to Commonwealth-state relations. Vigorous exchanges are not new to this arena and you can always expect a bit of tension. But I think it has been many years since we have seen the state of relations so low. State premiers are sick of the lack of consultation of this federal government. This is highlighted by the debacle known as the 1996 Premiers Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Costello), who I think yesterday was described as the pre-eminent political figure of his generation, decided to hold a press conference to introduce a new sales tax regime on cars worth $300 million. It was at this forum that dog jokes reached their peak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dog jokes!
—Dog jokes. Let me give you some examples. In the Canberra Times of 12 June, Peter Cole-Adams said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, Costello, the man Kennett is said to have called "the dog" bit back.
The Australian of 14 June said:
Earlier in the day, the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Rundle, said: "Peter Costello's only been there a dog watch, but in that short time he's making (Labor treasurers) Willis and Dawkins look good."
The headline of the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 June read `Snarling meeting goes to the dogs'. The article states:
But last night Kennett was prepared to bury the hatchet—in Peter "Dog" Costello and, to a lesser extent, in Howard.

The usual reliable sources said bitter jokes were shared—with dog themes. Tasmania's Tony Rundle suggested Howard was the only one worth negotiating with and Costello was "only there for the dog watch". Queensland's Rob Borbidge suggested they might as well be "standing around a hot dog stand" for all that was being achieved.
Kennett said he would name the new tax "after my dog".
Egan is also understood to have referred to Costello as a "slimy, sleazy, sneaky lawyer". Howard was reported to have been nettled by Egan to the point of calling him—
and I have to find a parliamentary word; perhaps member will do. It goes on:
Howard's people denied this vehemently, so it's probably true.
It seemed the dog had had his day, Howard had taken over.
Another Australian article entitled `Premiers put bite on in dog of a day' states:
Yesterday's premiers conference in Canberra proved to be a dog of a morning for the Treasurer, Mr Costello . . .

The acrimony over the $1.2 billion sales tax issue and the manner in which it was handled by Mr Costello saw the conference drag on well into the evening, with the States putting a series of offers to Mr Howard which the Commonwealth will now consider over what has turned into a chilly three-dog night.
The best summary was from Ross Peake in the Canberra Times . His article, entitled `It seems the PM's dog was sold a pup', states:

The cranky state leaders were incensed that the Federal Government was proposing to impose sales tax on state and local governments for the first time. When the stroppy guests assembled with their advisers in the Cabinet room for formal hostilities, they were determined to give Howard and his Treasurer Peter Costello a first-rate battle.

As Howard tried to direct the conversation, he was openly ignored. Often he found himself talking to a leader's back, the person having turned to have a more pressing conversation with another summiteer.
This is the Prime Minister in a premiers meeting, and the premiers are turning their back and not even listening to him. The article further states:

Tempers became frayed as the meeting progressed. Michael Egan, Carr's Treasurer, got into the fray. The PM, irritated, shot back that Egan was childish. Why don't you grow up, act your age for a change?

This is the Prime Minister talking to a state Treasurer. Even in private, the meeting was very acrimonious. Some radio stations actually used that term which I cannot use because it is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the `B' word?

—No, the member word. Howard got angrier. Officials went around the press gallery to correct the story. The meeting became ugly, with the states and territories for once remaining united. The outraged conservative leaders felt they were being betrayed by a government of their own political colour. The bottom line from this disastrous meeting must be to teach the federal government a lesson about not taking the state and territory leaders for granted. As for Costello, he should have known that this tax grab plan had been rejected by the former Labor government when it was put up by Treasury. The dog had been sold the pup.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the consultative process? The Council of Australian Governments, COAG, is there to address major policy issues, such as the implementation of micro-economic reform, the structure of federal-state financial relations and the determination of roles and responsibilities of each tier of government in the provision of services.
