No meeting of COAG has taken place since 14 June 1996. There was one scheduled in November 1996 but put off because of the Western Australian election, and fair enough. But the promise was made by the Prime Minister, `We'll have one in the first half of 1997.' It is September and there is no sign of a COAG meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising.

—It is not surprising that the PM will not call a meeting of the premiers. Look at the spray he gave them in the party room last week. It is extraordinary! I wonder whether the senators opposite were the ones who were clapping and applauding. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald entitled `PM lashes out at Kennett and co' states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has attacked the conservative State premiers of Victoria, WA and Queensland, accusing them of shunning the national interest and claiming they could not be relied upon to actively back the Coalition in a federal campaign.
The comments, although startling a number of MPs, drew loud applause in the partyroom.
Any volunteers? Loud applause? It continues:

In the case of Mr Kennett, it related to the outspoken Victorian Premier's constant complaints of Federal Government timidity and his belief that it was using its lack of a Senate majority as an excuse for inaction.
Mr Howard said the criticism showed a basic lack of understanding of how the federal political system worked.

He expressed exasperation with the recent performance of the Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, pointing out that he had been forced to berate him for his behaviour during the Federal Government's attempts to put together a financial rescue package for the States after the High Court's franchise fees decision.

Mr Howard was not finished there. He still had Mr Court to go. The article further states that Mr Court had made a decision to undertake a $1.3 billion currency swap with Thailand. Mr Howard said Mr Court had been given the wrong information or was just acting irresponsibly in his comments. What a state of affairs! It is truly extraordinary.

If the High Court had not forced a review with its decision of the federal-state relations, Howard would have continued to avoid the issue. What is the Commonwealth's position on tied verses untied grants? Why has there not been a meeting of COAG to talk about it? The states are claiming that specific purpose assistance represents 53 per cent of total payments, and they have been calling on that to be relaxed for years. The Labor Party was not going to be in it, but what is the government's position? Labor promised a fixed formula to maintain real per capita funding levels. The Liberals have reneged. The cowboy manner of the Howard government runs amok across a raft of issues.

I will go through some of the recent issues that highlight this. There is legal aid. The Northern Territory Attorney-General, Mr Burke, said it was an absolute disgrace that the federal government had allowed legal aid to get to this state. Mr Burke said that he and one of the Supreme Court judges had already written to the federal Attorney‐General, Mr Williams, about an earlier case where the Aboriginal Legal Aid Service could no longer defend a client. He said that no replies had yet been received. Perhaps the three coalition senators over there are among those who have written to ministers and not received replies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we get replies.

—That is certainly an improvement. You have been replied to in the last week, have you? They finally sent you a reply. Why were backbenchers on your side complaining about responses from ministers? The Prime Minister rebuked his ministers, didn't he; that is what happened. But he is not alone. As you can see, the Northern Territory Attorney-General has not been able to get a reply either. So you should not feel that any of your ministers are picking on you; you are not alone.

SPEECH.PARA: There is Mr Kennett—a big fan of the government. I quote from the West Australian:
Jeff Kennett was up to his old tricks yesterday, adopting the role of outspoken armchair critic of the Howard Federal Government.
But senior Liberals in Canberra are finding Mr Kennett's meddling irksome and distinctly unhelpful.
Yesterday, Mr Kennett was at it again. On Melbourne radio, he fired a broadside at Mr Howard, saying Australia needed firm national leadership to set a clear‐cut reform agenda.
For good measure, Mr Kennett, also took the Federal Government to task for failing to put in place a coherent policy of industry assistance.

He said key manufacturing industries—cars, textiles and pharmaceuticals—were in danger of winding down or folding in Australia unless the Government took urgent steps to encourage enterprises in the manufacturing sector.
The Federal Government's official "no comment" response to Mr Kennett's meddling in affairs outside his bailiwick belies a seething resentment at his interference.
Senior sources liken Mr Kennett to a "yappie little dog"—
it goes both ways; they have a dog fetish over that side of politics—
who does not know when to shut up.

That is senior federal government sources. Then there is health cover. On this, probably the opposition wholeheartedly agrees with Mr Kennett; at least he was prepared to tell the truth about it. An article in the Age of 27 February states:

The Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett, risked further strained relations with the Federal Government yesterday by dismissing its much‐vaunted $600 million private health insurance plan as money down the drain.

With the Government due to introduce tax incentives on 1 July for people with private cover, Mr Kennett said the tax rebates offered were likely to have little effect on the dwindling number of privately‐insured Australians.
"The question is, will it stabilise the decline or will the decline continue," he said. "I think the likelihood is that it will be good money chasing bad."
Mr Kennett said the recent rises in health fund premiums showed that the rebate would be offset by the increase in charges.
Another Age article reports Mr Kennett's comments as follows:

"At the moment there is no industry policy. There hasn't been for 10 years," he said. "We're seeing our automotive industry under attack, we're seeing textiles, clothing and footwear under attack. We're seeing the pharmaceutical industry about to be destroyed."
The Federal Government's frustration—
that is you, the federal government—
reached the point where the Health Minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge—
a Victorian, it should be pointed out—
when reminded in Parliament that Mr Kennett lived in his electorate—
Mr Kennett lives in Mr Wooldridge's electorate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he vote for him?
—Probably not—

SPEECH.PARA: snapped back in frustration: "You can't choose your family either!"
That is the health minister talking about the Victorian Premier. But it goes on to state:

Last week, the Prime Minister embarked on a conscious strategy of turning the attack back on Mr Kennett. He opened with a rebuttal of the health rebate criticism, pointing out that the Premier, six months ago, had praised the measure. The follow-up was a considered warning against the spread of gambling—
which I have already spoken about earlier today—
a form of activity with which the Kennett Government has, to put it mildly, been strongly connected.

But it does not stop there. I know it seems that after 15 minutes he must have run the gamut of issues he wanted to attack the federal government over. But no, there is a set of steak knives involved too. It further states:
The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, was forced yesterday to rebuff the Victorian Premier, Mr Kennett, over his attack on the federal work‐for‐the‐dole scheme unveiled this week.
Mr Kennett will write to Mr Howard today seeking federal funding to allow Victoria to go it alone with a radical alternative to the federal plan.

Under Mr Kennett's proposal, young unemployed people would work with private businesses for five days a week instead of the federal proposal where young people work up to 15 hours a week on community projects.
Mr Kennett said he wanted young people to be able to work in a business environment where they could learn "real skills" rather than being allocated to community projects laying bricks.

"The concept is fine, the principle is right," he said. "My only worry is I am scared that these, in the main, children will be having experience on community projects for which there is no long-term employment prospects."
Absolutely right, Mr Kennett. It is not often I will stand up in this chamber and say that about Jeff Kennett, I will tell you. But it further states:
But the Prime Minister said that if the Premier had "some additional proposals to tackle the (unemployment) problem—
and this is the Prime Minister—
I'm delighted to look at it and I welcome it".
I will bet he is; that was through gritted teeth.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not what he said on the car phone.

—It is not what he said about him on the car phone, no. It gets better again. The Prime Minister decided he had had enough. Federal‐state relations had not plummeted far enough yet; he had not had enough. In the Age of 23 May, under the heading `Prime Minister attacks Kennett on high taxes', it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has accused the Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett, of imposing some of the highest taxes of any state after the Victorian leader claimed credit for forcing Canberra to tackle tax reform.
Being from Victoria, I have to agree with Mr Howard, the Prime Minister. Further:
Mr John Howard also flatly rejected Mr Kennett's denunciation of immigration cuts—
immigration as well. It continued:
Mr Kennett, who prompted 3AW's Neil Mitchell to ask him about immigration, said he disagreed strongly with the Howard Government's decision and "hoped" it had nothing to do with Mrs Hanson.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet it did.
—There are times you can almost warm to Mr Kennett, you are right, Senator Gibbs.
—The man becomes more attractive to me every minute.
—But it does not stop there.
—Doggone!
—Thank you, Senator Hogg. I now refer to Essendon airport. You would have thought that they could at least agree about an airport, but no.
—Order! Senator, address your comments through the chair please.
—Sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. This is from an Age editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: Last week, when the Federal Government decided to keep Essendon Airport open and sell it to a private operator, the senator—
Senator McGauran—

said Mr Kennett's opposition to retaining the airport had been a factor. The Nationals wanted Essendon to stay open, and on Thursday Senator McGauran said: "We were happy to lobby Cabinet with Kennett against us rather than for us. I think he helped our cause."
It just goes from farce to farce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was Senator Julian McGauran. He said that it was better to have Jeff Kennett barracking for the other position. We hope you are going to contribute on this soon, Senator McGauran. The absolute lulu came in only last week. I refer to TAFE funding and trainee funding. A newspaper article, referring to Mr Honeywood, states:

SPEECH.PARA: "That's why the resolution says we disagree," he said, describing yesterday's meeting between the states and Dr Kemp as "extremely heated".

Mr Honeywood called into question Dr Kemp's motives, saying that at a recent meeting of training ministers, Dr Kemp had tabled an Australian National Training Authority document that canvassed a "deferred payment mechanism" for TAFEs.
He said this indicated Dr Kemp was thinking about a fee system . . .

But the spokesman for the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) said, `No, in actual fact it was a state document', and he had supported keeping the clause. Mr Honeywood then responded by saying, `That's not true; we were keeping the clause.' Jeff Kennett rolled Robert Hill on Coode Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happens all the time though.
—That is true. He is not on his Pat Malone on that one. The editorial says:

SPEECH.PARA: "The Federal Minister for Schools and Training, Dr David Kemp, was more interested in his profile than solving youth unemployment", Victoria's Minister for Tertiary Education, Mr Bill Honeywood, said today.
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy's level of debate can only reinforce the public attitude to politicians and the way in which they speak in the chamber. I can only hope, Senator Conroy, that your rumoured departure for the safe seat of Gellibrand will raise not only the level of debate in this chamber but also the level of intellect on the opposition side of the chamber. In fact, the muffled sounds of applause that I thought I did hear did not emanate from your own side but, indeed, from Senator O'Chee slapping himself to keep himself awake during that somewhat puerile level of 20 minutes of abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are talking about the level of replies to backbenchers, the level of immediate replies that I have had from ministers is eminently satisfactory. However, I would like to quote a letter that I wrote to the then Minister for Communications and the Arts, Michael Lee, when I was a backbencher. I wrote that letter in November 1994. Some 16 months later, by which time the coalition had attained government, I received a response from Minister Lee. The Age was kind enough to calculate that, for the time it had taken the letter to travel from Minister Lee's office in New South Wales to my office in Broadmeadows, Victoria, the rate of progression would have been something like 0.3 of a kilometre per day. I was extremely gratified to receive a response but, nevertheless, would point out what a very long time it took.

The fact that Senator Carr has proposed this motion today but is not here to debate it simply points out the sort of tunnel vision Senator Carr has and the time warp in which he lives. He is forever fighting the class war and he is forever noting, particularly, I suspect, the state of play in Victoria. As a senator you would suspect that his interests would be far more at the national level and that he would debate federal issues, but this is something that never happens.

I would, however, like to turn particularly to the area of child care and some other related issues before putting into context this whole debate, which is indeed based on the natural desire of state premiers to stand up for their own bailiwick and the natural desire of a Prime Minister to fight for the federal scene.

I would like to draw to the Senate's attention the booklet called Labor's child care mess which was put out by us in opposition and which criticised very strongly the way in which a federal minister—it was Senator Crowley at the time—had failed to coordinate in any way the relationship between the state and the Commonwealth in the child‐care system. The booklet, dated December 1994, says:

There is a lack of fit between state and Commonwealth systems and the Commonwealth and states have so far not reached an adequate level of coordination. The states provide heavily subsidised preschools which are not integrated into other child‐care services and yet lead to topping and tailing of other services to fit in. Child care is a key area which has been damaged by the Keating government's confrontational attitude to the states.
The editorial of the Age of 23 August 1994 said:

The Commonwealth and the states and territories must renew discussions and negotiations about the use and purposes of the whole range of children's services, kindergartens and preschools to ensure much more flexible usage and increased resourcing. In addition, the needs of children and their parents must be placed at the centre of these negotiations and the reforms which flow from them. This must replace policies which maintain demarcations and rigidities in service types, demarcations and rigidities between the responsibilities of the various levels of government.
Indeed, from an even more authoritative source than the Age , the Auditor-General's report of 1993-94, entitled Mind the children , said:
The needs based planning process carried out cooperatively by the Commonwealth and states in its current form—
this was in 1994—
is not adequate to provide an accurate assessment of needs or the development of appropriate services to meet those needs.
The Law Reform Commission interim report of November 1994 read:
It is clear that the present program of coordination between Commonwealth and state child-care systems imperfectly implements the principles of access, equity, affordability and quality.

In contrast, when the coalition attained government we moved immediately to right some of these wrongs. For instance, in the May 1997 budget, the Commonwealth government announced measures to effect the location and rate of growth through a fully integrated planning system for child care. This is something that I continually asked the then minister, Senator Crowley, about in the various estimates committees that I attended, and no adequate answers were forthcoming.

In the program that we put forward in the May 1997 budget, we announced that there will be a one-off period of two years—1998 and 1999—when new private long day care centre based places eligible for Commonwealth child-care assistance will be limited to 7,000 places a year. The reason for doing this was to provide for overall integrated planning measures to be put into place—unlike the previous government, which allowed untrammelled growth so that services were located in places that did not adequately serve the population.

Our measure of May 1997 provides that child-care assistance will be approved only to centres located in identified high need areas. We certainly saw that as a very necessary part of planning. Similarly, we forecast that during the coming years Commonwealth expenditure on child care is expected to grow from what had been a base level of $215 million in 1989-90 to approximately $1.3 billion in 2000-2001, with an average real rate of growth of three per cent from the years 1997-98.

Again, we expect to establish 83,000 new child-care places between 1997-98 and the year 2000-2001. The new child-care places are actually new places, unlike those existing child-care places which were shuffled about by Senator Crowley. That includes 44,000 new private sector places, which allows access for an additional 76,000 children. In addition, 39,000 community long day care, family day care and outside school hour care places will be established over the same period to cater for an additional 60,000 children.

At the same time, another initiative which was long resisted by the previous government—that is, to implement quality assurance for family day care—will be implemented by the present government. We are committed to developing and implementing quality assurance in an appropriate format for family day care and outside school hours care. Indeed, in the May 1997 budget, research funding has recently been provided to the National Family Day Care Council to commence work on the development of a quality assurance system for the family day care centre.

In all of these ways, the present coalition government is working with the states to ensure that child care is put on a proper basis. However, let us put this whole debate in its correct historical perspective. My colleague Senator Synon remarked that trenchant and stringent comments by state premiers have always been a part of the natural interaction between state and federal governments. Indeed, if we go back and look at some of Mr Keating's statements, as recently as November 1995 he, too, put this in its present context. He was busily engaged in stirring up trouble between the federal government and the states by making the sorts of comments he made on 9 November 1995 in a Canberra doorstop. He said:
But to give them a share of income tax?
He is talking about state governments. He continued:

BREAK.PARA: If we ever reached a point again where the Commonwealth income tax fell, they would be screaming blue murder that they want more money from us.
I mean, it's just an insincere ploy that they know has not a snowball's chance in hell of happening from us.

He also had something to say about the design of the casino in New South Wales. The subject of architectural design was always very dear to the previous Prime Minister's heart. He made this statement, which could only be designed to be extremely conciliatory, on 13 July 1994 on the John Laws program:
They want to build a building as ugly as sin in Pyrmont which will destroy that whole area over there and basically that's because of the lowest common denominator guidelines.

That comment must have been very well received by the New South Wales Premier. All of this is in the historical concept of federal prime ministers talking to state premiers. On that same program on 13 July 1994, Mr Keating, when talking about Robert Webster, who was the then minister, and about the Fahey government, said:
I'm not going to have some down the line National Party minister from a state government saying, "Well, Prime Minister, you give us a cheque and then don't ask any questions.

For a real look at federal‐state relationships, what we really need to do is look at the same federal and state government relationships—that is, governments of similar ilk which are in office at both state and federal levels. What better example could we find of this than in Victoria in 1992, when Mrs Kirner was Premier and there was the continuing leadership battle between Mr Keating and Mr Hawke.

If we think that the present tariff debate sometimes becomes somewhat acrimonious, we should read what Premier Kirner, as she was then, said on the eve of the 1992 National Labor Party Conference. In the Age of 12 June 1992, Mrs Kirner said:
I am sick and tired of the textile, clothing and footwear worker in Northcote and Bendigo paying $174 per head to the casino player or operator in the Gold Coast. It has got to stop.
When talking about relationships between the state and federal governments, Premier Law rence, on 23 March 1992 in an AM interview, said:
It simply can't be done—
she is talking about continued economic reform—

without the States, and it's not going to be done by a series of fragmented meetings between Ministers, one on one with Commonwealth bureaucrats and Ministers . . . it really is a matter of principle that has to be addressed by the Premiers jointly with the Prime Minister.
How does that differ from any of the comments made by Senator Conroy and the other speakers on the other side?
Similarly, Premier Goss, speaking in Queensland in 1992—and I would ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to note the date—said:
If we don't get it—
that is, Commonwealth‐state reform—

then Australians right around this country are going to see cuts in services like education or health or increased taxes because of the failure of the Commonwealth to adopt a give and take or co-operative approach.

That was 1992—five years ago! Did the then Labor federal government do that then? Not them. We had to wait for four or five more years, until the arrival of a federal coalition government, for that to happen.

As I said, I would like to deal particularly with Victoria and the way in which the then Labor government interacted with the then federal Labor government in 1992. Mrs Kirner and Mr Keating had no problem about discussing state governments. I think that, if the Labor Party senators on the other side took the time to go back and look at some of the press excerpts from then, they would see that it was a great pity that both Mrs Kirner and Mr Keating were not able to stick around for the announcement of Commonwealth funds for many projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they now?

—Indeed you may well say that, Senator Ferris. For instance, if we are talking about Liberal comments on Liberals, I would like you to think about this one as a Labor comment on Labor. This is ex-Premier Wran from New South Wales talking about Victoria on 3 September 1992. Mr Wran had this to say:

BREAK.PARA: I think Victoria is a basket case and has been for a long time.
You might like to think about that, Senator Conroy. Again, Premier Kirner said on 16 April 1992:
My view is I don't exist to set a pattern for a federal government—I exist to lead Victoria to jobs.

What a pity she did not actually make good her promise and spend the rest of 1992 doing something about leading Victoria to jobs instead of leading the state ALP to the most ignominious defeat that they have ever had. Premier Kennett would agree with that—that the job of a state Premier is to lead his or her state to jobs. It is a pity that your premiers have not thought more deeply about that and the way that they should do their state Premier job. Mr Beazley, your present federal leader, said in March 1992:
All the rest of us very much depend on Victoria hauling the rest of the country by hauling itself out of the recession in which it lies . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Go back five years? You need to go back 12 months.

—Senator Conroy, you are too young to be able to set these debates in their historical context. Fortunately, those of us who have been around somewhat longer are able to do that. What you do need in politics, Senator Conroy, is a long view. So just stay around for a bit longer, grow up, lift your debate—through you, Mr Acting Deputy President—to a higher intellectual level and you may be able to appreciate some of these national concepts rather than remain at the puerile level at which you choose to conduct your debate.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, the only way in which Mr Beazley and Mrs Kirner could get Victoria out of a rut was by a change in government and, fortunately, Victorians chose to do that in the 1992 election. Actually, I think it was 1 October. The date is very firmly ingrained in my memory, and that is what I mean by needing to have a long view in politics.
If we look at the Moody's report on the then state of Victoria we can understand why Victorians changed their government. Com ments such as this were taken from the Age of 4 March 1992:
There is clear scope for fiscal adjustment in Victoria and a fair amount lies in the areas of current expenditures.

That is not what your then government chose to do. It took a Liberal national government to go ahead and fix current expenditures. Indeed all Liberal governments, at both the state and the national level, appreciate they need to do that. We needed, as Senator Synon reminded us, to bring ourselves back from the brink of your $10 billion black hole and rein in our expenditure.

Jeff Kennett has done the same in Victoria, and it has been achieved only by both state and national governments working together. In spite of all the peripheral issues that you tried to bring in, state and national Liberal governments have a real consciousness about the need to put this country back on the road to economic prosperity. Senator Conroy, you obviously measure your life by weeks or days. With my longer perspective, I like to think about it in months and years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How old are you?
—Old enough, Senator Neal, to take the long view of politics. You lot over there just delight in taking a short-term view. It is 10 minutes ago, a day ago, last week.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Neal interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Enough to have learnt a great deal, I can assure you, Senator Neal. As I have pointed out, this debate needs to be set in its historical context. State premiers will always stand up for what they believe in; prime ministers will always stand up for what they believe in. There is friction around the edges but Liberal state and national governments are assured that we are putting the country back on the road to economic prosperity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been usual for some time for the federal government to come each year to the Premiers Conference and seek to reduce state grants as much as possible. The premiers come to try to argue both for more money and for a greater percentage of the pot to go to their state. The style is always somewhat gladiatorial. The situation arises from the fact that for historical reasons the states have given away much of their revenue making power. We learnt about a lot of that in school in relation to the powers that changed over during the war, but of course there are other issues historically as well. At the same time, there was never a formula devised to assure the states of a portion of the revenue or to clearly delineate their responsibilities to the people they administer.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray noted this morning in the debate on state grants that the states have also given away some of their existing revenue powers—not just in the deep dark history, but some of their existing revenue powers—like stamp duties on speculation in the stock market. So it is somewhat ludicrous for them to come and whinge too loudly. They have encouraged speculation and then say, `We haven't got as much money. Give us some more.'

There are also valid reasons why most taxation should be uniform and why taxation that is imposed sub‐nationally should relate to state, local or regional situations. A petrol tax on urban petrol, to go partially towards addressing the health problems and other problems caused by petrochemical smog and urban traffic, and to go partially towards reducing the cost to rural uses upon which cities depend, would be appropriately administered at a regional or state level.

There really is an issue of whether the states, as currently constituted, serve Australia. There is also the issue of why on rational, civil or ethical grounds Australians living in territories should be treated differently from those living in states. Perhaps the state-territory distinction is a colonial holdover that we could well do without. In many respects some of these issues are strongly related to the motion before us.

This government has specifically made deals to cut state funding in return for more autonomy and less accountability in how the money is being spent. The direct result of this policy is the sort of thing we see in Victoria—the boys club at the top playing fast and loose with revenue. In Western Australia we do not—oh, of course we do not—have those sorts of problems! Our Premier has quite responsibly invested his money—excuse me, state's money—in projects like Global Dance, set up by his father with his father's mate, or the Elle McPherson yachting venture!

But that pales into insignificance when you look at proposals to spend half a billion dollars on the Premier's brother's project at Oakagee in Geraldton for a port facility. When the original proponents wanted to go inland, the government said, `No, put it near the coast, will you, Ken. And here's half a billion dollars to help you get there. We'll provide the port facilities. And, by the way, we'll also give you subsidised gas for the whole project and you can sell it off at more expensive prices and put more money in your own pocket.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Very generous.

—Very generous. This is, of course, a very good use of money in a state which has substantial waiting lines in public hospitals, which has overcrowded and under‐resourced schools, which has a hard time providing adequate housing for the poor people in the state and whose public housing scheme, Key Start, is responsible for hundreds of aspiring home owners going into debt in spite of the lessons of the late 1980s!

SPEECH.PARA: But the Premier does have discretion on spending, given in return for taking on more responsibility for health and housing without getting a transfer of money to cover that. The deal was that any requirements, such as those this government supported in relation to such things as the housing bill, which required public housing provision to be tied to social and environmental outcomes, were wiped out and the money given untied. So health and housing go begging while money is poured into pet projects like the Northbridge tunnel, with its massive pumping requirements because it was built below the watertable and its heavy social cost in destroying the heart of the few thriving social centres in Perth. We have to wonder how much money is going to go into the government's new pet project of damming the Fitzroy River.

BREAK.PARA: What this motion is really about is not a one-sided issue. The Commonwealth wants the economic reins, to be able to make economies by squeezing the states economically and saying that it is in the interest of forcing efficiency on those profligate wastrels. At the same time, it is quite content to eliminate any effective control on what public money it gives. So, if there are wastrels in state government, they can indeed be profligate and the federal government no longer has to take the responsibility. There is no longer a requirement that ties road funding to things like rural highways or black spots. Now it is poured into stupid plans that devastate the central city or simply encourage more road use with no apparent social or economic gain.

It is not a unique problem caused by this government. Paul Keating also had his problems with the premiers, but his solution was to cut money and then to promise to give it back only if the states signed competition policy. That is now, ironically, being used against state Auditor-Generals to eliminate accountability at the state level. Paul Keating promised to give them back some—guaranteed—as long as they met his competition policy objectives as quickly as he wanted them.

This is also an issue about local governments, an area which is so often left out of the debate on funding and tiers of government. Local government tends to get routed—I was going to use a ruder word—by state governments, who simply ignore local wishes when they want to build a road or facilitate the construction of a hotel or office block or help a mate from the big end of town. It also gets the raw prawn from federal government, who refuses to recognise its existence and who, in organising competition policy, has harmed local government more than any other level of government.

This is a central issue. This is the issue of the tiers of government, areas of responsibility, accountability and the ability to obtain a secure revenue base. It should not be the case that the states are given responsibility and then have their funding reduced—in part because the federal government decides to generously lower taxes! Likewise, it should not be the case that states lower their own revenue through creating tax stamp duty reductions for stock speculation and then come pleading poverty to the federal government.

The states, or whatever intermediate tier of government may be appropriate, should have clear responsibilities and there should be some standard and accountability in meeting those responsibilities. They should also be guaranteed a portion of revenue on an equitable basis with other states that is adequate to meet their responsibilities. For some states that will cost more per capita. That is just the way it is, and the responsibilities still need to be met. Avenues for state governments to raise revenue should be clear and the minimum portions of expenditures to be raised in such a way should also be clear.

Likewise, local governments should have constitutional recognition and a clear definition of powers, responsibilities and avenues for revenue. They should get a clear portion of the Commonwealth revenue base either directly or through the states. It is ridiculous that it has become almost impossible for the Commonwealth government to communicate directly with local governments. They should also be held accountable for the proper fulfilment of their responsibilities to certain standards through the use of this funding. It is not necessarily the case that the Commonwealth is the organisation that should hold the responsibility for the oversight or setting of standards.

We have suggested that, in many respects, it is the collection of members of the same level of government that can most effectively set standards. For example, local government knows more about waste management than federal government. I think that if you had a congress of representatives of local government bodies, you would see far more effective and innovative standards for national waste disposal problems than through any top‐down process.

The resolution of powers, duties and responsibilities of the various tiers of government is a major issue in Australia. It is something that, ultimately, should be decided directly and democratically—from the bottom up. It is one of those issues that is crying out for wider community facilitation of the debate and it should be part of the entire debate in relation to the proposal for constitutional change in relation to the republic. There is no point in constitutional change of a minimalist nature without looking at the appropriate levels of government for such things as revenue raising and responsibilities, as well as the wider issues that the community wants looked at now within any debate on constitutional change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Woof!

—Yes, `woof' is quite correct because I join this debate this afternoon and it is interesting that, in so doing, I note that none of the people opposite have referred to the motion that is before the chair, and I think that that is fairly important. I am not going to go through the whole motion but, specifically, it refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the severe deterioration in the relationship between the Howard Government and the States resulting from actions and policies of the Howard Government;

That has failed to be addressed by those opposite. What they have concentrated on, unfortunately, is history past—history gone—which bears no relevance to the debate that is before the chair this afternoon.

Whilst there were comments made about the fact that politicians, politics in general and political debate may be robust, and that politicians will grandstand from time to time, this debate was portrayed by one of the earlier speakers as having `friction around the edges'. That will be shown to be clearly not the case as I go through the material that I brought to the chamber this afternoon.

I am going to look specifically at the relevance of this debate to the state of Queensland. There is no doubt that, on the material which I have before me, we are not looking at something that is just `friction around the edges'; we are not looking at just `robust political debate' or `robust politics'; and we are not looking at `grandstanding'. We are, in effect, looking at outright war—outright war between the federal government and, in the case that I will refer to, the Queensland government.

My colleagues spoke of the deteriorating relationships between the federal government and other states. But why is there such a war out there? Undoubtedly, in my view, it is a self‐serving war for both parties—the federal government and the state governments—and particularly with my state of Queensland where we have a minority government. So we have a real foundation for them to be at odds with the federal government. They are not just at odds with the federal government, but they are in open conflict with it because, from a minority government position, they want to adopt positions which make them look tough, seem tough and appear to be the answer to all people's hopes and prayers. Of course, that is not the case.

We also have within that framework a premier who is trying to gather a profile. The common factors between the federal government and the Queensland state government—and there are a number of them—are that, in both cases, they lack ability, foresight, policy and leadership. Those are the things that are common and, because they are common to both of them, one sees the ultimate happen, and that is an outbreak of war between them. When you look at a Queensland government that has not won an election and which fell over the line in a freak by‐election supported by an Independent, then you can understand why they are out there trying to prove themselves. They are posturing to show that they are tough and they want to appear, at least to the public, as though they have some sort of teeth and some sort of bite so that they are an electoral prospect in the future.

But how did all this come about? It is worthwhile looking at the Courier‐Mail of Monday, 4 March 1996. That is only a couple of days after the federal election which was held. There is a report in that paper about comments that Mr Borbidge made. It said:
Mr Borbidge said yesterday that Saturday's election result heralded a new era of co‐operation between the National Party‐dominated Queensland coalition and the Liberal‐led federal coalition.

On a cursory glance by a Queensland reader, they could think that peace had broken out, that we were going down the path of some form of love‐in or that there was going to be a holding of hands between the federal government and the state government in Queensland. One should not be fooled by that because exactly 12 months later, in a headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of Tuesday, 4 March 1997, we have gone from being in a `new era of cooperation' to `Strident Borbidge may well have an election in mind.' And what does that article say? It sums up how the relationship had deteriorated in that period of 12 months. I quote from the article, because I think it is absolutely essential to this debate:
Something happened to Rob Borbidge over the summer holidays.
What could have happened? Anything. Who knows? The article goes on:

After taking stock of his electoral prospects with the passing of the first anniversary of Queensland's Coalition Government, the normally mild‐mannered, middle‐of‐the‐road Premier started to talk tough.
It goes on:

Borbidge has accepted advice from the National Party that the sort of right‐wing, Canberra‐bashing demagogy that is increasingly marking his utterances is the stuff that successful Queensland leaders are made of.
So the gauntlet was thrown down. We went from a love‐in and an era of cooperation to the start of an era of confrontation. People must ask themselves why. The article goes on:
Yet Borbidge has taken a big leaf from the former Premier's book.
What could be more of a disaster than to take a leaf out of the former National Party Premier Sir Joh Bjelke‐Petersen's book? It goes on:
So once again the rest of Australia looks on askance as a Queensland Premier struts the national stage muttering dark warnings about the evils of Canberra decision‐makers.

We went from a situation where there was supposed to be an era of new cooperation to an era of confrontation. And this was a bit more than robust political debate or robust politics or friction around the edges and a lot more than grandstanding. It was purely and simply a means for the government in Queensland to try to make its presence felt.

BREAK.PARA: And what did we see in retaliation? We saw nothing more than the reaction of the federal government. As people know, to every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. What we saw emerging was war in terms of politics in the state of Queensland. This was a stark contrast with 12 months previously. The battlelines had obviously been drawn. They were determined to fight in the ditches. It was tantamount to trench warfare. And the old maxim, `Take no prisoners', was to apply.

Moving on, we see how this deteriorating relationship was manifest once again in the media. In the Courier‐Mail of 2 May this year, Wallace Brown, a respected Queensland journalist wrote in his column:
It would be a good idea if most major participants in the Howard‐Borbidge‐Coalition‐Wik‐Hanson‐Aborigines‐pastoralists‐and‐Right‐wing crazies maelstrom calmed down.

They did not leave anyone out, and there was no doubt that the right‐wing crazies maelstrom calmed down. Here we have Wallace Brown calling for calm in what was, apparently, war not peace breaking out.
That article goes on to pose the inevitable question. There were several questions and I am not going to go through them all here this evening, but the first question Wallace Brown asked was:

Is Premier Borbidge so desperate for survival in his own constituency that he and Queensland National Party director Ken Crooke have to threaten there will be some sort of a re‐run of the ridiculous Coalition‐splitting Joh‐for‐PM campaign of 1987, the bushfire that was going to sweep across the nation?
There we have a very simple example of how we were no longer at peace in Queensland. And there was the expected retaliation from the federal government as well.

And it did not end there. We go to the Courier‐Mail of 24 March. The headline there was, `High stakes in tilting at Canberra.' I do not think we are talking about Don Quixote here; we are talking about the Premier of Queensland. It is interesting to look at this article, because it says:
Mr Borbidge said his government could have got a better deal from Paul Keating than it had from John Howard and Peter Costello.

What an admission. No wonder war has broken out between the two governments. Without any doubt, he could have got a better deal from the Keating government. And Mr Borbidge by this time was coming to his senses. The article goes on to say:
Mr Borbidge says the Federal Government's cuts to specific‐purpose grants are unacceptable and he will wage a public campaign to overturn them.

Maybe one could interpret that as posturing or say that it is friction around the edges. But it does nothing but get worse. The tilting at the windmill was not about a better deal for Queensland but about the posturing of a government and a premier desperate to save themselves. What we have is a deteriorating set of relations between the state government in Queensland and the federal government.

But, as I said, it gets worse, because we go to the Courier‐Mail of Tuesday, 12 August. The headline on that day was, `Borbidge blast for Costello over tax.' I do not know what the blast was. I do not know whether it was a bazooka, a hand grenade or what, but it was a blast. The impact of that headline was that the blast was not something that was frivolous or just a little bit of robust political debate. In the article one reads:
Premier Rob Borbidge launched an extraordinary attack on federal Treasurer Peter Costello yesterday claiming he had a "personality problem".
It goes on to quote Mr Borbidge as saying:
"As usual, Mr Costello is not being much help . . . He can't help himself . . . it's a personality problem.
You cannot have me or anyone believe that this is a good, love‐in type relationship, not even a robust political relationship, but nothing more than fight, fight, fight; war, war, war—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all part of politics.
—It is not part of politics, it is destroying the Queensland view of politicians and politics. It simply relates to what this government is about.

BREAK.PARA: Arising out of that, we will take a look at Laurie Oakes's article of 26 August, and this is where the crunches start to come in over that particular incident. Laurie Oakes says in his article in the Bulletin of the 26th:
Howard phoned Borbidge to tell him the comments were completely unreasonable and shameful . . .
That is not a very loving sort of relationship; that is a relationship that is in tatters. It is a relationship that requires counselling, and I will come to that later. Laurie Oakes goes on to say:
Borbidge next day pretended to the media that the purpose of Howard's phone call had been to enable the two leaders to sort out personally the difficulties Queensland faced over the tax issue.
So it was pretended. That was put out the next day. The article goes on to say:
Howard was forced—
a pretty strong word in anyone's language—
to send his media advisers to the parliamentary press gallery to brief journalists on what had really happened—namely that the Prime Minister had given the Premier a blast.

That is certainly not a cuddle in anyone's language. A further article in the Courier‐Mail on 13 August again refers to the same incident. It is headed, `Howard carpets Premier for tax attack.' This shows how warm and loving a relationship these two people have. Down in the article it really shows how much they talk to each other. It mentions the telephone conversation between the Premier of Queensland and the Prime Minister where the Prime Minister blasted him. It says:
The telephone conversation—the first time the pair have spoken since the premiers' conference three months ago—underlines the tense relationship existing between the two leaders.
So no‐one could in any way interpret that as being a warm, loving relationship.

Then the debacle goes on to a letter written by Frank Jackson, who was the Premier's press secretary, I believe. He wrote a letter to Mr Oakes as a result of the article and copied it to Mr Grahame Morris, who is the chief of staff and the main political adviser to the Prime Minister. This prompted Mr Oakes to write another article in the Bulletin of 2 September. The letter, remember, went to Mr Oakes. The comment in Mr Oakes's article is as follows:

The letter asserts that my criticisms of Borbidge—painting him, according to Jackson, as a "bogeyman"—were "based on another mischievous and dishonest briefing which we strongly suspect came from th e prime minister's office".

So here we have the Premier's press secretary implying, alleging, that they strongly suspect that the briefing came from the Prime Minister's office. If that is not poison, nothing is. The article goes on:
That line, in itself, says heaps about the poisonous relationship that exists between Borbidge and his federal Coalition colleagues.
It goes on:
Given his view that Howard's staff fed me the anti‐Borbidge material he complains of, Jackson clearly intended, by copying the letter to Morris, to deliver the threat to Howard himself.
It goes on further in the article to really sum it up:
With friends like Borbidge and Jackson, Howard has no need of enemies.
On the same issue there is an article in the Courier‐Mail of the 28th. This is a different view of the world. In an article by Craig Johnstone, the national political editor, it says:
The letter's consequence is a further souring of the relationship between Howard and Borbidge.
It goes on:
Unlike Jeff Kennett, who has had his share of run‐ins with Canberra, Rob Borbidge appears to have little support among business and community leaders for his continued attacks on John Howard.
So this is not an era of cooperation; this is an era of deterioration of the relationship between the federal government and the Queensland government. It goes on to say:
Neither have the Borbidge Government's other tactics, including threats of physical violence, done its portrayal in the media much good.
The next article sums up most of it. It is headed, `"Blackmail" escalates Borbidge, PM tension.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Quoting journalists!
—This is the view of the world, Senator McGauran, through the eyes of people who, unlike you, have some appreciation of what is going on. I will quote the article in summary:

BREAK.PARA: In a series of clashes with Mr Howard, Mr Borbidge has attacked the Wik legislation, pay ments to the states, damned the revocation of the drought declarations and was involved in a heated phone conversation with the Prime Minister after claiming Treasurer Peter Costello had a "personality problem".

What we have seen is a trail of devastation in relations between the Commonwealth and the state government. Maybe colleagues who are going to the UN from this place may seek to have a peacekeeping force for the Premiers and the Prime Minister brought into this nation. It might be one solution to the problems we face. There may be faults on both sides in the federal‐state arena, but the losers are the Queensland public. Maybe our colleagues who are going overseas might approach Madeline Albright, Henry Kissinger or Jimmy Carter to see if they can intervene and bring some peace back to this nation in the relationships between Queensland and the federal government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hogg has referred to the substance of Senator Carr's motion here today, in an amazing diatribe plucked from the library. He must have spent hours in the library this afternoon. I suspect the journalists involved will be delighted with the publicity. Senator Carr's motion today is a bit of a mystery to me. He has not even spoken today. He has only just come into the chamber. Where has he been all afternoon while we debated this really important and substantial issue? He has never spoken on this issue before. It is not as if there are rafts of public information or utterances from Senator Carr on this very complex and crucial issue. Despite his motion today the database on Commonwealth‐state relations still does not have a tag for Senator Carr. I can only conclude that when it came to putting this motion, Senator Carr's bean came out of the barrel. It had nothing to do with his commitment to the issue or the priority that he has given it. He let other members of the sandpit club come in here and have a go instead.

SPEECH.PARA: He is not the only one, of course, who has given a low priority to this issue. After 13 years as a minister, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, can take absolutely no pride in his record as a member of the previous government. They were all totally irrespon sible on this most important issue. The former Deputy Prime Minister and one of Senator Carr's close factional colleagues, Brian Howe, was very revealing when he said, `I think it is entirely right that the Commonwealth should retain the whip hand in these taxation matters.' Let us be realistic; Labor has an absolutely abysmal record in addressing the balance between federal tax revenue and payments to the states. In fact, they spent most of the time when they were in government compounding the problem and fighting amongst themselves, as we all now know, over who was going to take over from Captain Wacky. It had nothing to do with Commonwealth‐state relations whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trampoline economics.

—Thank you for that contribution, Senator McGauran. I agree—trampoline economics. Labor's record on federal‐state relations provides a stark contrast to the coalition's approach. Quite recently we saw the opposition leader, Kim Beazley—I am very sorry that Senator Hogg has left the chamber—turn his face towards Queensland and whistle up Wayne. `Come on down, Wayne; come on down.' Mr Beazley will want to be very careful. He will need to watch that when the office of the Leader of the Opposition is inhabited by Mr Goss from Queensland it does not undergo a conversion to `Wayne's world'.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot tonight about Queensland. Let us look at what your previous Premier Mr Goss said when he was holding that office and passed a vote of absolute no confidence in Paul Keating's federalism. He was forever complaining that under Labor the federal‐state relationship was simply not working. In July 1993 he said that Labor operated premiers conferences as a `farce'. As a farce, Senator Conroy. He was one of your team. And he thought that you operated premiers conferences as a `farce'. Why didn't Senator Hogg include the comments of his colleague Premier Goss in his speech tonight? He did not include them because they did not suit the factional argument he was putting together, no doubt with his preselection in mind. What Premier Goss said at the time was: `Mr Keating acts as Mr Keating normally does at premiers conferences', that is, `He does what he likes.'

The Sunshine State was not the only state to have a view about federal‐state relations under the Hawke and Keating governments. Your New South Wales Treasurer, Mr Egan, has called for a `complete reappraisal of Commonwealth‐state relations, recognising that the system Labor left us with is simply not working'. Again I quote because I do think these quotes are quite interesting in the sense that they recognise the difficulties. How much more of a damning report card could federal Labor have from these colleagues, these state cohorts? Some still in, some thrown out, but they all said the same: the process was not working.

In May 1990, then Prime Minister Hawke made Treasurer Paul Keating the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Commonwealth‐State Relations. Wow, surely he must have known that he had just promoted the sorcerer's apprentice. Goodness me. What a promotion. Just 18 months later Paul Keating had taken over as king of the castle, and he had taken up permanent residence in the ivory tower. He had no contact with the people of Australia, and especially the premiers of our states. In the meantime, he torpedoed any attempts by the states and their premiers to achieve real reform of Commonwealth‐state relations. He was interested in a desperate campaign to take possession of the palace. During that time poor old Prime Minister Hawke lost all interest in reform of federalism because he was too busy trying to save his skin.

As we all know, his successor never faced up to the issue again. He did not need to. He had won—game, set and match to the sorcerer's apprentice. In contrast, the coalition's record in this area is already taking shape. Senator Conroy, you might be interested in this. The Howard government has forged powerful working relationships with various state premiers and in the process has notched up a series of quite significant achievements. Let us have a look at a couple of them. You might find them interesting.

BREAK.PARA: There was the Prime Minister's leadership in the aftermath of the tragic events at Port Arthur where the premiers all cooperated to get rid of some of our more insidious weapons that had been, sadly, available to too many inexperienced people in this country.

There was the very public spirit of cooperation during the recent negotiations on the Alice Springs‐Darwin railway line. I was privileged to be in the audience when the Prime Minister, together with the Northern Territory Chief Minister and the South Australian Premier, John Olsen, were able to hear how that vision, which under you had become a mirage in the desert, was about to become a reality. Let me say that last Saturday, as I stood on the stand at the Royal Adelaide Show, I was delighted to hear from so many railway employees of the relief that they felt that at last a federal government has assumed responsibility for the disastrous situation of the railways. They hope that their children, when they grow up, will ride on the Alice Springs‐Darwin railway, and I have no doubt that they will.

There has been a great spirit of negotiation and cooperation on the development of that proposal, and I have no doubt that, under this government, there will be a railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin for the first time since the empty promises of Andrew Fisher, on your side, in 1910. That's not a bad record—80 years and empty promises. But we are going to deliver on them.

Let us have a look at the extensive consultative process undertaken by this government with the states over native title. We are going to see the legislation in this place before the end of the year. The cooperation particularly, I might say, by New South Wales in supplying the leases for the schedule is a very good example of the cooperative federalism we are seeing from this coalition government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you sell town hall clocks as well?

—There is more evidence just this week with the Constitutional Convention, Senator Carr. Despite your side's attempt disgracefully to sink the reputations of some very fine young Australians, we have seen the state governments cooperate to ensure there will be balanced representation from around the nation. There was a disgraceful attempt by your side to besmirch the reputations of some very fine young Australians.

BREAK.PARA: I have got some more evidence for you, Senator Carr, of this cooperative federalism. Very typical of the can‐do attitude is the situation that we had in response to the recent High Court judgment on the excise taxes, where we saw our federal Treasurer (Mr Costello) immediately recognise the difficulty, the likely very severe financial problems and the implications for state revenue. He immediately put solutions in place and worked through the problem together with the states. There was not the empty noisy debacle that we became used to from your side in those dreadful days of Labor's neglect on this important issue.

Labor has consistently failed to achieve cooperative federalism—there is plenty of evidence of it—because those opposite are the great centralists who think that everything that is important runs out of Canberra. It is part of their attitude that the states are the B team and not important, so let us try to get rid of them; let us white‐ant them, let us undermine them, let us denigrate them and let us take every chance we get to tell them, `Hey, don't you guys realise this is as good as it gets? Never forget it.' And there is that other great quote from the emperor himself: `We are going to bolt it in.' Will you ever forget that, Senator Carr? `We are going to bolt it in.' We all know the result of that.
This government is committed to a cooperative approach to federal‐state relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke! You've got to keep a straight face when you say that.
—We are getting on with reforms. We are making this country operate efficiently and fairly for all Australians.
—Oh, yeah? Tell the homeless that.

—All those thousands of people who used to vote for you, Senator Carr, in Victoria decided there was a better way; they threw out the state government and they threw out you, and that is where you will remain—over there on the opposition side. This is what we are all about on this side of the chamber: we are about cooperative federalism; we are about talking to the premiers; and we are about getting on with the job. That is what we promised Australia, and that is what we are going to deliver.

BREAK.PARA: We are tackling the hard issues like tax reform—another of the issues that your lot opposite were not prepared to take on in 13 years. There was the absolutely disgraceful 1993 Keating scare campaign, which was rapidly followed when you got back into government by an across‐the‐board two per cent rise in wholesale sales tax. What a joke! What a cruel deception of those true believers whom you all welcomed on that night in 1993. What a reward they got. And they did not forget it when it came to March last year—they left you in droves. Even Labor Premier Bob Carr has welcomed the Prime Minister's announcement that we will be moving on tax reform—but those opposite have not.

Just like their record on federal‐state relations, Labor's policy reform is moving at their usual glacial pace. By the sound of it, and I have been dusting the cobwebs off my old archival box as well, I can hear the remnants of the scare campaign coming out again. I can see it now. I heard your leader the other day using some quotes that I was able to find in one of the emperor's old tax pamphlets, one of those scary old pamphlets that Australians are not going to believe any more because, Senator Carr, Australians have woken up. They have woken up to you and they will not fall for Labor lies the next time around. They will not fall for your lies.

In fact, that has already been demonstrated in a recent Morgan poll: 57 per cent of Australians are already in favour of tax reform. Can there be a greater example of an opportunity to improve federal‐state relations than tax reform? Can there be a better example of it? It is the coalition that has got this issue back on the agenda. We are not going to hide in the ditch at the first whiff of grapeshot from your side. We are actually going to stand there and we are going to fight for, as the Prime Minister of the time in 1993 said, `the gentleman in Melbourne who drives a tram'. Do you know any of those people, Senator Carr—the gentlemen who drive trams and those family people who actually fell for your scare campaign in 1993?

Despite Prime Minister Keating's utterances back in 1985 that tax reform was on the go, he walked away from it and you are going to try to walk away from it now without any policies, without any principles and without any chance for the families of Australia—none whatsoever. That is policy reform at a glacial pace. Maybe, just like the ACTU, you had better come up with some of those cash rewards and prizes. What was it I saw Jennie George suggesting? A cash reward for union membership of 50c a week off your petrol at the bowser. If ever I saw an incentive, it has to be that one—50c a week off your petrol at the local bowser if you have a union ticket! I do not think she will be crushed by the hordes going for that one, but we will see. Certainly the statistics do not show it.

We have put the issue of tax reform back on the agenda. We are going to do it fairly, equitably and, most importantly, honestly. There will be no scary stories from us. Thirteen years in government was not long enough for the now opposition to fix these and the dozens of other problems that we are discussing in this place every single day of the week. We are serious about fixing problems. It will not take us 13 years because, unlike you, Senator Carr, we will not just be talking about it but doing something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason the Labor Party has put this motion today is to highlight to the Australian people the fact that this government is at war with the states. Why is it at war? Because it has managed to break every promise it put to the last election. It has cut just about every social program it said it would maintain. Why they are really at war is that, in the case of the premiers, they understand that we have a Prime Minister that is essentially weak, insipid—(Time expired)
—Order! The time for consideration of general business has now expired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak with some sadness about a person whom I respect very greatly, a person who is a friend of mine and a person who has been very much maligned by people in recent days. I speak of Dr Dorothy McRae-McMahon, a minister of the Uniting Church in Sydney. She has recently resigned her position in the Uniting Church and is said to be under some threat of losing her ordination. I want to simply put on the record my appreciation of her life, the contribution she has made to the Christian faith and the support she has given to people who live on the edges of life in our cities and in our country—but particularly in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Dorothy McRae-McMahon was the minister of the Pitt Street Uniting Church, which was never a flash church like some of its other in Sydney. In fact, it was a church that was very run down. Dorothy McRae-McMahon turned it into a refuge for people on the edges of life, particularly in the city of Sydney.

She is a woman of great faith, great courage and deep spirituality. To show her courage, I have to recount to you some of the things she has had to face in the years she was minister of the Pitt Street Uniting Church. She had her church and property fire bombed; she had excreta and graffiti smeared over the front of her church; and she endured scurrilous attacks from the National Action, which is simply a Nazi group in disguise. The material about her that was circulated for years by that group I would not even bring into this chamber and table because it is so scurrilous and so false.

Yet, through all of that, she continued her work with people on the street in Sydney, people with AIDS and many other people who were at the bottom of the pile. She championed them. She stood against racism. She was a champion of the anti-apartheid movement and was one of its strongest supporters here in Australia. Yet this woman is being pilloried by people in her own church and outside it.

I just want to place on the record my deep appreciation for the ministry she has offered to me over the years and for the fact that she is someone with incredible perception of the pain of humanity. She was always willing to address that pain and to put her own life at risk, as she did on many occasions. Her courage is something that I could not hope to emulate and something that I can simply admire from a distance.

I have listened to Dorothy on a number of occasions, both as a preacher and as a teacher. I want to say that both her preaching and her teaching demonstrate deep faith and a deep spirituality. She does not deserve what is being done to her in a public way by certain people.

I do not want to enter into that debate, because I believe that is something the church itself must address. But I do want to bear testimony to this woman and publicly support her in the struggle she is going through. Dorothy, you have my support. I hope you will come through this. You will be a better person. But I hope the church will become a better church through its support for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —At the last election the coalition was swept to power by the overwhelming vote of a group of people who have come to be known as Howard's battlers. Readers of Pamela Williams's recently published book The Victory will know that, in the lead-up to the election, the coalition measured its policies against a typical Australian family: a young couple known as Phil and Jenny. In this profile, Phil was 38 and Jenny was 34, they had been married for eight years, they had always voted Labor—even in 1993—and they had a six-year-old son Jason, who had just started school. They were battlers; they were battlers on $30,000 a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Jenny had three part-time jobs to try to make ends meet, and these are the people—and there are thousands of them around this nation—whose enterprise and enthusiasm have been cruelly nobbled by the present Australian taxation system, with all of its absolutely hopeless complexities made all the worse by 13 years of Labor neglect.

Let us have a look at how this complicated and quite unfair taxation system affects the lives of the Phils and Jennys of this nation. It would be a very good idea for those opposite in the chamber to pay attention to these experiences because they might find out the reason why these people voted with their feet to sweep to power John Howard's coalition government.

Phil heads off in the morning to the warehouse where he works, as I say, at $30,000 a year. His employer might even be one of the companies that pay only 17 per cent of the total tax burden in Australia. He is wearing his tax exempt work clothes. They might look like clothes that you and I might wear, but they are designated as work clothes so there is no tax on them. He drives his 1982 Commodore. He cannot afford a new car, even though he would like to get one so that, with lead-free petrol, he can improve the environment for his son, Jason. His Commodore does the job, but it is well overdue for a service. He cannot afford to get the car serviced. Even if he could afford to get it serviced, he would find himself paying 22 per cent tax on any replacement parts required for the car.

At lunch, Phil's counter meal is tax exempt but the tinny he washes it down with is taxed by excise—again, a hidden tax. The carton of milk that he has on the way home is tax free, but the packaging is taxed, as are the truck that picked the milk up from the farm and the processing machinery that made sure the milk was hygienic for his family to drink.

But it is the weekly visit to the supermarket, Senator Faulkner, that would open Phil and Jenny's eyes. If only they understood the hidden web of taxes that has been put on the shelves of every supermarket in this country. Most of the products that they would choose are taxed at one of three tiered levels of wholesale sales tax. Their household detergents are taxed at 22 per cent. Their chocolate, ice-cream, biscuits and potato chips as well as the cordial their son likes to drink are all taxed at 22 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: The sliced bread, cornflakes and dog food are not taxed at all, but the chain store cosmetics that are all Jenny can afford and the personal chemist items that she would like to buy are taxed at 32 per cent, because Labor decided that they were luxuries. In fact, by the time Phil and Jenny get to the checkout with their trolley, the tax man has got his hand in Phil's wallet, even though he cannot feel it and he cannot see it; make no mistake, it is there. Eighty per cent of what is in the shopping trolley goes to the tax man in one form or another in one of these hidden three-tier tax levels.

Along the road from the supermarket there are people eating lobster and caviar at a restaurant of their choice, and they are not paying any tax at all. They are in the service sector. At the local market on the way home where Phil and Jenny buy their vegetables and fruit, trying to live as healthily on a low budget as they can, they realise with a great deal of resentment that many of the items available there could be part of the cash economy and that, unlike them, these people have the opportunity to minimise the tax they pay.

As I said, Jenny has part-time jobs. She works in the service sector, where most of the work she and hundreds of others do is on a cash transaction basis—no tax there. But Phil is not so fortunate, and that is why he does not want to work any overtime. He is a PAYE taxpayer, and at $30,000 per year, if he worked back one night a week, the factory would put him into the top tax bracket. What a joke! Instead of working back to improve the productivity of the company that he works for, he goes home and has a relaxing evening; something that not many of us are able to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you didn't spend any time working on this speech.

—He watches the television, not realising that there is a 32 per cent tax on it because it is another luxury item, as would be the camera that Jenny might buy Phil for the Christmas stocking. He is relaxing with a book, which is exempt from tax, while sitting in his—wait for this one, Senator Faulkner—low, leather‐backed couch. The couch is taxed at 12 per cent but, if it was a chair, and if it had a high back, even if it was made from the same materials, it would be taxed 10 per cent higher, at 22 per cent. Have you ever heard of anything more ridiculous than a lounge room with chairs and couches, each one taxed at a different rate? Labor's madness at work again! Let us move into the kitchen.
—Let's quickly move out of the kitchen and into the dunny and flush this down the toilet.

—If you would like to get out of the kitchen, I can tell you about the costs in the smallest room in the house, Senator Faulkner. Let us just talk about the taps on the sink. Even though the sink has a 12 per cent tax, there is no tax on the taps. So far there is no tax on the water either. The chain store shirt that Phil is wearing is exempt from the wholesales sales tax, as would be the finely tailored three-piece Italian suits that he cannot afford—although he might be able to pick up a couple around Canberra; some of the cast‐offs the emperor does not need any more.
—Some of those public servants that you people have sacked.

—In the bathroom, Senator Carr, the tax man is really active, but again not in any consistent or coherent way. When they pick up the toothbrush, it is tax exempt but toothpaste is taxed at 22 per cent. The widespread anomalies in the current wholesale sales tax system are readily apparent to those who like to look at it but, sadly, not very often to the Phils and Jennys of this world who have no idea just how often the tax man has got his hand in their wallet.

BREAK.PARA: An increasing number of Australians, though, do know it. They will not be frightened off by any of the airy‐scary campaigns that might have worked for those opposite in the past. There will be no more silly stories as there were in 1993 about how everything will go up under a GST, when every Labor politician back then knew that many products, and in particular those that had been taxed at 32 per cent, would have cost a great deal less.

The New South Wales Premier, Bob Carr, knows that tax reform is desperately needed; he has said so several times. We are not going to hide in the ditch when it comes to the tax reform debate; nor is the community going to fall for Labor's lies. Australians, like Phil and Jenny, desperately need tax reform. Clearly, only the coalition is interested in it, since Labor remains wedded—and, Senator Faulkner, no tax on wedding rings, only on engagement rings—to our archaic wholesales sale tax system.

The inconsistencies and anomalies in the current tax system are now absolutely clear and very well known. The tax reform debate will move steadily forward, as Australians like Phil and Jenny know that they and hundreds of others have a real chance of getting a fairer and more equitable tax system which is open to greater scrutiny; and when the tax man puts his hand in their pocket, they will know how much they are going to pay, why the tax is being charged—and, more importantly, how it will be spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight on the retirement from parliament of Senator Bruce Childs. Bruce has been a political and industrial activist from a very early age. He was apprenticed in photoengraving and then became the clerk of the printing chapel at 17. He led his first strike over a £2 wage increase while still an apprentice at 17, and was reported to the arbitration commission by his employer who sought to invoke penal clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: At 18 he was elected to the board of management of the Amalgamated Printing Trades Employees Union. At 21 he became vice‐president of the union and the clerk of the Herald‐Sun chapel. At 22 he became an organiser of his union—a full-time official. At 30 he became the assistant federal secretary of his union. At 31 he became the New South Wales secretary. He was part of the negotiating team that led to the amalgamation of two printing unions that led to the formation of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union. So in 1966 Bruce became, at the age of 32, the Joint State Secretary of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union.

BREAK.PARA: But, though he has made a significant and important contribution to the trade union movement, his contribution to the Australian Labor Party has been extraordinary. He has been a party activist since the age of 16. He was a delegate to the famous 1954 annual conference of the New South Wales branch of the ALP and to all conferences since that time.

For people of my age and generation, it was Bruce's election in 1971 to the position of assistant general secretary of the New South Wales branch that was a real watershed in New South Wales Labor history. I have known Bruce very well since that election—a tight election, in fact; one that he won by just 19 votes in nearly 1,000.
