I have known Bruce Childs longer than I have known anyone else in this chamber. We have shared some confidences that neither of us or the Labor Party could afford to have shared by others. For a quarter of a century we have worked closely together. So Bruce's retirement means an enormous amount to me in a personal sense. It is a very big change.

I recall his early days in the Labor Party office in Sussex Street. They were pioneering days of power sharing in the Labor Party. They were not easy days. They were particularly difficult days for Bruce. He suffered more than his fair share of slights, of snubs, at that time and more than his fair share of humiliations. He was often isolated. But he came through that, and so did the Labor Party. Our party was better for the experience. I suspect that Bruce himself was better for the experience. We all learnt from those experiences.

By 1980 it was time for Bruce to leave the machine, full‐time machine politics. He was replaced by a loose cannon by the name of Faulkner in Sussex Street. I have always thought, I must say, that, if you serve a 10‐year sentence in Sussex Street, you deserve a seat in the Senate—and I am sure that is common ground between Bruce and me.

Bruce's parliamentary career has been a distinguished one. He has always treated the parliamentary Labor Party, our caucus, seriously. He has always treated the caucus committees and the caucus processes serious ly. He has been a real contributor in the parliament, and in the committees of the parliament. Senator Ray paid tribute yesterday to his service on the Privileges Committee. I think he said that his was service he did not expect anyone to match in the future. But Bruce has shown that same commitment across the board.

I wanted to say on the day of his retirement from the chamber that I am sure there have been disappointments for him in the 16 years that he has spent in the federal parliament. Bruce was very unlucky not to be a minister in a Labor government. But, for all that, he was always there. He was always willing to take up causes on behalf of the people he so ably represented. He was always there during the difficult times and the difficult issues. He was always willing to have a go and he never—not once—let the side down.

Tonight I, obviously also as a member of the Left, also want to acknowledge Bruce's service to the Left of the Labor Party, particularly the parliamentary Labor Party. Bruce has been a convenor of the national Left from the early 1980s until now and a convenor of the parliamentary Left from the time of the election of the Hawke government until now. That has been a very long innings and it has been very important service. It has been important to the faction that we are both members of but very important, more broadly, to the Labor Party. He has been a real unifier both within the Left of the party and within the party itself. I think that is acknowledged well beyond just the Left of the party.

Bruce was also the convenor of the Palm Sunday anti-nuclear rallies in the 1980s. He was a leading Labor voice in the peace movement and the anti-nuclear movement. Without his efforts, they would have been very different movements indeed. That again was not an easy task. It took someone with his skills, patience and capacity to undertake that role. It was important for our party and it made a very substantial difference in community attitudes on those issues.

I wanted to say to Bruce tonight how much I appreciated his personal support over the years. I really cannot say any more than this: I know that you supported me at times over the years when you actually thought that I was wrong—and you were probably right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably right pretty often.

—At least I am not wrong as often as you are. That required an enormous degree of loyalty on your part, Bruce. I think many in our party got that same level of support. It is important for all of us in politics and, in a personal way, I appreciate it very much indeed. I am sure that without your support I would not be standing here today, and I appreciate that also. It is true for many other members of the parliamentary Labor Party at both the state and federal level.

BREAK.PARA: You are very well regarded, Bruce, on both sides of the parliament. You are held in very great regard in our party. You are a decent, loyal, honourable person. Your role in this party has been outstanding. We are going to miss you enormously from the caucus, from the faction that we are both members of and from the parliament. On a personal level, I say again that I will miss you very much. On behalf of your colleagues, I thank you very much for your contribution. We wish you and Yola very well for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words on my own behalf, and on behalf of my colleagues who are not able to contribute to this debate, to wish Bruce well in his retirement from parliamentary life and to acknowledge his contribution to the Senate and to public life. It was interesting listening to the contribution of Senator Faulkner because I, from the other side of the chamber and the other side of politics, share the views pretty much as expressed by Senator Faulkner.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately in this business sometimes we get rated by our public profile. A high public profile does not necessarily mean that you are making the greatest contribution; sometimes to the contrary. Senator Childs may not be as well known by the public at large as some others, but we who have worked with Bruce, albeit across the chamber for the last 16 years such as I have, recognise the contribution that he has made. It has been a very important contribution to public life and to the standing of this institution in particular.

The sorts of words that come to mind when I think of Bruce Childs as a politician and a man are that he is straight, fair, decent and very committed to his beliefs. I think that that is something that is vitally important in public life. I see him as somebody who really has committed himself to work for the disadvantaged, or at least those who are not as well off. I think that is very important too, because the strong and the wealthy will always be able to look after themselves but there are many others who need a strong voice to look after them. That has always been part of Bruce's contribution. Those beliefs and the strong sense of social justice that they lead to will be identifying marks by which I and my colleagues will remember the contribution of Bruce Childs to public life.

Bruce, I think that you have been a bit unlucky too. When I match your talents against those of many others on your side of politics—some of whom you would have seen achieve loftier office—I think that you could have done a much better job than many of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Think how lucky you've been on the same principle.
—That is right. He would have been harder to pick off than some of yours who held ministerial office. There is a lot of luck in this business, and some of us have been luckier than others.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember the Palm Sunday marches. I do not know whether I am allowed to say this these days, but I took the Liberal Party into the Palm Sunday peace marches, and I modelled our contribution on that which Bruce Childs was making in New South Wales, which was interesting. I can tell you that it was harder to take my party into it than it would have been for you to take your party into it. But that was in the mid 1980s, and the world has changed a lot since then.

TALK.START.PARA: —So has the Liberal Party.

—Yes, the Liberal Party has broadened and improved; that is correct, Senator Carr. I thank you for your interjection. Bruce, we on our side of the chamber wish you well in your retirement from this chamber. I say `retirement from this chamber' because I know it will not be your retirement from public life. I believe that you are the sort of person who will keep working for the benefit of others all of your life. You can retire from here proud of what you have contributed, and we will remember you fondly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day when we say goodbye to our colleagues whom we have known, in the case of Bruce Childs, for 14 years. I would like to join with both Senator Faulkner and Senator Hill in congratulating Senator Childs on the way he has represented his side of politics in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose when we think of Bruce, we all think of different things. Senator Hill has given his attributes. The word that I would describe Senator Childs with is `fair'. We have been on some committees together where he struggled to get a consensus. In the earlier days of the government, I think the government always had the numbers on the committee. In those days, he could have used the force of numbers to just push his or the government's point of view through. But he did not. He sat there and struggled to get an agreement on all sides. As a new member at that time, I was very impressed with the way Senator Childs handled his responsibilities as chairman of the particular committee.

After 16 years as a senator, Bruce, I suppose a lot of different things are going through your mind: freedom; `I don't have to cop this'; and `I don't have to come down here every week.' Yet you will miss your colleagues, particularly those on the left of the Labor Party, and you will miss the day-to-day activity of being part of driving a government when you were in government and being part of a vigorous opposition now.

You have stuck to your beliefs. You are from the left, and you have stuck to the principles of the left. You have stood up for the underprivileged and the people who do not have a strong voice. On the more conservative side of the parliament, I know that you have represented those people well.

You have had a successful career in the union movement, and you have had a successful career in parliament. You can measure success by the friends you leave behind, and I have never heard in this place a bad word against Bruce Childs or any word that would condemn you in any way. So, if you can leave parliament without anyone ever saying anything critical about you, then you have been a success, irrespective of your not having had a position in the ministry. Luck is a fortune in anything. Luck is a fortune in politics. It is a fortune in farming. People say that one inch is the difference between a good farmer and a bad farmer. You were always knocking on the door of ministry, but that was never to come to you.

Bruce, I wish you the best when you go out of this place. I wish you a happy retirement. I wish you success. Whether you go into business, into some help organisation or back to assisting the Labor Party, I know that you will be successful because you will give it all you have got as you always have given all you have had in the past 16 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The most notable thing about Bruce Childs—it is interesting that everyone who has spoken before me has said the same thing, and I wrote this down before I heard them say it—is that he is a really genuinely good man. He is a decent human being. He is honourable, and he is absolutely trustworthy, and he always has been.

SPEECH.PARA: I met Bruce in the early 1980s when he started here. He was a senator, and I was a staffer. From the day we met he has always treated me absolutely as an equal. I certainly cannot say that about everybody, especially in those days.

I have been on Palm Sunday marches with Bruce. He always made sure that I was invited to things that he thought I would be interested in and which he has had some hand in organising in Sydney. He has probably allowed the Democrats and me to have far more publicity than perhaps his colleagues would have liked. I thank him for that. I do not suppose that you can be done over for that any more, Bruce, so I am pleased to say that.

He and I have been in offices in the same building for I think the whole time he has been in parliament. He has always been a really charming, easy person to get on with and a really decent person to share space with.

He is also notable for his wonderful staff. He has always had wonderful staff. I can see that two of them are here in the chamber tonight. They have always been really good people. Many of them have gone on to much bigger and better things.

Bruce, you really are a decent human being. You deserve the absolute best. I was so pleased when I heard that you had married, I think about a week ago. I think it is just the most wonderful way to start a new life. On behalf of all the Democrats senators and all the Democrats staff, and I include former Democrats Senator Colin Mason, we all wish you good luck in absolutely everything you do. Good luck to you and Yola. I personally will miss you a great deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Bruce came into the Senate six years after I got here, and he may well have had the same view of this place that I had when I got here. I suppose you were used to getting things done—I will not say fixed up—in the political sphere but it seemed to be that you could get more results more quickly in an organisational sense in the areas from which we came—though, I might say, on different sides.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, over the years Bruce has recognised the importance of this institution, as has been said by a number of speakers. It is interesting that he was appointed to the Privileges Committee only two years after his election to this place. As was mentioned last night by Senator Robert Ray, Bruce has been on that committee continuously since 1983 until the present—something that, as Senator Ray said, may not be equalled. Bruce has also done a stint on the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, an important committee of this Senate which is necessary, I believe, to ensure that this institution maintains its integrity and maintains its important position in a parliamentary democracy.

Bruce has been on a number of other committees, including the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee. I have served on a lot of other committees, but I have served on only some, not all, of those committees. Our paths, therefore, have not crossed a great deal in that particular forum. But I can say that I have always found him to be a civilised human being. Our association, from my point of view—and I hope from his—has always been courteous. I would like to join with my colleagues in the Senate in wishing you, Bruce, a very good retirement. I am a little envious of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of Labor senators who were unable to get on to the speakers list for one reason or another tonight have asked me to pass on their high regards to Bruce and to wish him well in his new form of political work. Senator Chris Evans has had to leave, as has Senator Barney Cooney, who asked me to make this statement on his behalf:

SPEECH.PARA: I have known Bruce Childs since coming into the Senate in 1985. Over that time he has forever been a man of good grace, true humility, keen intellect and enormous energy. He has done well by this chamber, the state of New South Wales and Australia. He will continue to contribute mightily to this nation.

In saying farewell to Senator Childs in terms of his contribution to the parliament, I want to pay a personal tribute to him. I hold him in very high regard personally. I have valued enormously his friendship and his advice to me—particularly since I came into this chamber but throughout the 1980s, when he and I worked very closely together as co-convenors of the national Left. His strong commitment has impressed me enormously, and on many occasions he has provided me with enormous inspiration. I am sure many others share his values and have equally been inspired by his commitment.

Bruce comes from a long line of Labor socialists who believe that the Labor Party is the most important vehicle for social change in this country. Bruce, like many before him and, I believe, the many who will follow him, has a commitment to the need for substantive social reform, which is being expressed through the Australian Labor Party and through the trade union movement. It is through only the Labor movement that there can be any real attempt to address the inherent inequalities of this society.

I think Senator Faulkner very adequately summed up Bruce's history in the trade union movement and his enormous contribution to it from the age of 17. It is through the Labor Party that I have known him most and through his work in, firstly, New South Wales and later the national Left of the Labor Party.

I think Bruce has always understood the dual nature of the Labor Party and the dual activity that those socialists within it see as an important and fundamental ingredient to making sure the Labor Party works effectively. He understands the policy priorities of a political party are inseparable from the development of a strong organisational base within that party, and to this end Bruce has devoted much of his time and energy to ensure that the Left is effectively represented within the various councils of the Labor Party.

However, it would seem to many within the Labor Party that, despite what seems to be a gigantic, heroic and all‐consuming task, Bruce has never lost the broader perspective of political work. He has always understood that there is more to being part of Labor than just winning elections and wielding power for the sake of it. He has always understood, in my experience, the dual nature of the work within the community at large and the importance of ensuring that strong socialist values are being articulated through not just the trade union movement but the broader community groups at large.

Bruce has also understood how important it is to work closely with the peace movement and a range of other progressive community movements and organisations. These are the links that he has inspired many others to follow and that he has maintained in his political work throughout the 1980s and 1990s.

I know Bruce to be a tireless campaigner for disarmament and a vocal opponent of uranium mining and Australia's contribution to the nuclear fuel cycle. But it is not just on peace and disarmament issues; it is on human rights and various other social justice issues rather than just the straight economic issues that some people sometimes see as being the fundamental issues of inequality. Bruce's political work has been based on the firm belief that only by collective action could the resources of the state be channelled effectively to ensure that all people, regardless of the circumstances of their birth, have the opportunity to actually fulfil their full human potential.

I think at various stages in his political career, and probably right now, it has been fashionable for many to argue that it is a market driven economy that is the basis on which we should distribute social goods. Bruce has not accepted that. No matter what pressures were on, no matter how fashionable it was to hold such a notion, he has not succumbed to that view. In fact, some of those views are often fashionable for only a very short time, as we are seeing now. He has maintained a coherent philosophical set of values and he has argued those values whenever it has been necessary. It strikes me that this is a characteristic of Bruce's personal courage and his personal commitment. It is a commitment that I think all senators here tonight would recognise is essentially based on integrity and basic decency in terms of his human relationships. In politics all too often we see examples where there is a lack of integrity. I do not think that case can ever be made out in the dealings that anyone has with Bruce.

He has always been a person one could turn to for an honest opinion, and I think that applies to just about anybody in the Labor Party. No matter how important they thought they were, Bruce was the sort of person you could rely upon to tell you as it was and to provide advice on the best way of achieving a result that actually was consistent with the values that we aspire to.

Bruce is often known to be a very gentle and kindly-spoken person. I have seen him in other circumstances, not that he expresses himself necessarily in the same manner that I do from time to time. But I do know that he is greatly moved by the injustices and hypocrisies of the political processes. He has stood up against those forces wherever it counted throughout his political life.

What I particularly admire most about Bruce is that he has not latched on to the latest trend and fad. He is not the sort of person who is easily won over by cheap popularity. He has the capacity to stand straight and true, no matter what the personal cost is. In politics, including Labor politics, that is all too rare an ingredient across the broad spectrum of opinion. It is very important that we acknowledge this in our public figures, and Bruce is a shining example of those qualities that result from his personal strength and integrity which is founded on a coherent philosophical view of what it is that actually moves society.

What I find remarkable about Bruce is that he has not been intimidated by the cheap put‐downs. He is not the sort of person that is persuaded easily to give up the struggle when so many around have over the years. I do not believe that he has been persuaded that it is easy to alleviate social problems by cosmetic changes. While it has been said that he is retiring from this place, there is no way that Bruce will be in any way retiring from the struggle of the Labor movement. His work as the President of the Evatt Foundation will see him move into a new arena of struggle. I look forward to him being able to articulate those visions and those values on behalf of a wide spectrum of Australian opinion, a wide spectrum of opinion that is given far too little airing in this country.

I am confident that he will be able to provide enormous benefit to the Labor movement in the period that follows this one. I am sure that his participation will continue to be valued. His experience and his wisdom will be able to be shared with many that come after him. I trust that he will be able to take up that challenge. I sincerely hope that Bruce, in the next stage of his very active life, enjoys perhaps a little more personal peace and perhaps a little more time to develop his own interests. I trust that he will be able to develop a great deal in terms of personal satisfaction.

Bruce, I take this opportunity to thank you for all the assistance you have lent me, many of my colleagues and many of the younger members of this Senate who have turned to you for advice. Bruce, I wish you and your family very well for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to join with my colleagues to say farewell to a friend and to thank Bruce for his unselfish contribution to politics. Bruce's life at times has been tinged with sadness, but never did he express his sorrow or anguish. At all times he kept his personal sadness to himself. Although I have not necessarily agreed with all of Bruce's views, I must say that on many occasions we shared common interests and common views, particularly in relation to manufacturing in Australia. I have come to respect his very significant contribution to committee work and his dedication to the less well off and to a world at peace.

SPEECH.PARA: Bruce has served on and participated in many committees of the Senate, but I will refer to only two. He was chair of the Economics Legislation Committee while I was a member. We have served together on the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation for many years. During those times his consultative manner and his genuine desire for soundly based and informed decisions has been invaluable both to me and to the committee process.

One of his own colleagues referred to him as a decent human being. From my experience in working with him, I would concur with that assessment of his character. Glenn Milne in the Sydney Morning Herald once described him as mild-mannered and cautious. Another reporter from the same paper wrote of him as being gentle and unassertive. Whilst I might question that `lack of assertiveness' description, I know that he has many achievements that are not on the public register. It is these sorts of qualities that I have come to respect and for which I hold Bruce in very high regard.

Although committee work can be very tedious, it is only when one is working with people like Bruce that one is able to identify the most appropriate alternatives and to focus often on the real issues. Senator Childs has always made a habit of fully consulting with his colleagues on committee work. I have found this to be a special skill, and his effectiveness in this area is particularly praiseworthy.

The constitutional role of the Senate as a house of review can only be undertaken when there is a commitment to consultation and also to negotiation. Bruce was at the forefront of the taxation debate during the Hawke government and he presented views on behalf of the left wing of the party. Again, while I might have differed on the direction he proposed, I want to acknowledge his genuine contribution to what was an informed debate. I noticed with interest the paper that he issued to members of the Labor Party in January 1985 that he was prepared to acknowledge, amongst many other issues, that broad consumption taxes do have some merit in that they are relatively difficult to avoid.

As an activist for peace, he was prepared to distance himself from the party's position on the Gulf War. He also led opposition to nuclear testing in the Pacific by personally organising Australians to protest in French territory in the Pacific. It is this type of commitment to ideals that has been demonstrated in the role that he played in organising a Palm Sunday rally in Sydney as convenor of the Sydney nuclear disarmament coordinating committee. He commented that this kind of peaceful demonstration is really representative of a very healthy democratic process.

Bruce will, in his parliamentary retirement, still be very much at the forefront of ideas in leading the think‐tank called the Evatt Foundation. Tonight, we lose a senator with a social conscience in this parliament. I take this opportunity, Bruce, to wish you every happiness and trust that you will be able to indulge more frequently in some of your pastimes of reading, going to the theatre and other activities. I thank you for your contribution and for your friendship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as the most junior of the Labor senators in this place tonight. I say that in the sense that I am the last of the Labor senators to come to this place. I became acquainted with Bruce Childs before he came to this place. Nothing that Senator Faulkner said tonight surprised me because I have known, both through my personal observations and by the observations of many of Bruce's colleagues from the past, of the high regard in which Bruce has been held within the trade union movement, within the ALP and, now—not surprisingly to me—within the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Bruce, my short time here has shown me that you, with your experience, your lack of pretension and your unstinting willingness to help a new senator such as me, are an excellent role model for a new senator in terms of the integrity and diligence with which you approach your tasks, both here and, as you have always done, within the ALP, particularly the left of the ALP.

It must give you great satisfaction to know that you have come through, from your union involvement, your party involvement and now your involvement in the Senate, as part of the vanguard of a group of people who have pursued the issue of peace. I can recall when the pursuit of peace was not a popular issue; in fact, it was something that was somewhat sneered at, even within the ALP. In the mid‐1960s it was people such as you, Bruce, who led on the issue of opposition to the Vietnam war. I think that you must get great satisfaction now, to see the acceptance that those issues have in the whole of the community, not just within the party. It must be good to know that, having reached this high point in your life, you can look back and say, `I really have achieved something; I've achieved something that will never be taken away.'

I could say more, but I think that Senator Faulkner has probably said more than I could say about your involvement in the ALP and, certainly, in terms of your involvement in the Senate. So let me, in those few words, wish you and your new wife Yola a very pleasant and happy time for the future. We will certainly be thinking of you and I know that your comments, your guidance and your leadership will always be welcome to me, and I am sure I am speaking on behalf of a great many of us here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly about a colleague who is leaving this chamber. When I think back over the seven or so years that I have been a senator, I have actually had very little to do with Bruce Childs. That may be to Senator Childs's good fortune. If the truth be known, our paths rarely crossed over the seven years, but I would just like to make two observations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have found in this chamber that I very rarely agree with Senator Kim Carr, but I have written down two words that you said that I did agree with, Senator. I think I can share these confidences with you. You said that Bruce Childs is a man of integrity and basic decency. I think that is a view which is shared, certainly on this side of the chamber, by people whom I have spoken to and had dealings with.
On the one occasion we did have a lot to do with each other—a rather unfortunate inquiry which was set up and then seemed to collapse fairly quickly—

TALK.START.PARA: —You got off very lightly.
—I think you got off very lightly, Senator Carr. I did think that, within the constraints in which we all worked, you handled that very difficult and highly political inquiry well. I recognise that.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that you are returning to a think‐tank. I came from a think‐tank.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must have been empty.
—Not too empty. We managed to convince the Labor government to follow down many of our paths. Not too empty—
—Just quit while you're behind.

—Quit while you are behind. And thank you, Senator, for reminding me of the privatisation issues and the enterprise bargaining issues which the former government pursued and which I think the Institute of Public Affairs helped lead the debate on. The Evatt Foundation has never been one of my prized bodies, I have to say, Senator, so the debate may well continue until long after you have left this chamber.

BREAK.PARA: I wish you well. It is always sad to see someone as distinguished as you leave this chamber. I share the sentiments that many of our colleagues have mentioned today, and I wish you and your wife a long and happy future together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —As a fellow New South Wales Senate colleague, I am very pleased to be able to stand here tonight and join with all other members of the Senate in wishing you well. I also do so on behalf of all those other people who will not get the opportunity to wish you all the best on a long and distinguished career.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot recall precisely the first time I met you, but I know it was back in the 1970s, when you were involved in the Vietnam moratorium movement and I was a student at Sydney University. Irrespective of the factional politics within the New South Wales branch at the time, everyone appreciated your leading role in that struggle. Despite the criticisms you—along with others—had to bear in the early days in that movement, you were proved right.

I also recall your days at head office as assistant secretary. If people in politics think that the life of a politician can be tough at times, one of the toughest—if not the toughest—jobs in the nation is to be the left faction's representative at 377 Sussex Street.

TALK.START.PARA: —A piece of cake!

—You will never get the chance to even contemplate it, Senator Kemp. It is tough. You need heaps of courage and perseverance as well as a tough hide and, particularly, patience. Bruce, you have all those qualities, and that is why you were able both to survive whatever was visited upon you at that time and to come on to have a distinguished career here in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested in Senator Carr's comments, because I am not sure whether some of your successors as assistant secretary—on both sides—who have come to this building have been able to demonstrate the same degree of patience, although they, equally, have many of those qualities.

Last night, as you know, I was not able to get to the function early on because of another commitment. I will be going to the one in Sydney, but I managed to get to the one last night towards the end. I stood there for a while, and I stepped back. I saw Senator Faulkner, who is a former assistant secretary, Anthony Albanese and Leo McLeay, also both former assistant secretaries, all deep in conversation, discussing their various exploits and achievements in the well‐known pastime of branch recruiting. It is a great club this group of former branch officials and, if everyone got together from both sides, it would probably be the strongest faction we had in the place.

But, Bruce, in the short time that I have been in this place—and, as others have said, in all the years that you have been here—you certainly have demonstrated the qualities of patience, of perseverance and of sheer hard work on behalf of the party and of the state. People have spoken about your work on committees, and I certainly remember being able to ask you for advice when I first arrived and being able to rely on the advice you gave me in the committees we shared membership of.

I particularly want to mention also, as Senator Faulkner did, your service to the trade union movement and the fact that you have continued to pursue the cause of trade union members and of working people generally in this place. On this side we regularly get criticised and attacked for having trade union backgrounds by people on the other side, but you wear that as a badge of pride. So do I, and I know all the others on this side do. We know that it has given you, as it gives us all, the opportunity to understand more fully the issues that affect the working people of this country.

When I came to this parliament I replaced Senator Richardson, who was a resident of Phillip Street as well. So, along with Senator Bourne and you, we have been able to share experiences at Level 12, 70 Phillip Street and, as you know, there has always been a great cooperative attitude amongst the three offices there. I extend the best wishes of the members of my staff and particularly those of my staff member Marion Grace who has worked for people going back to the days of Tony Mulvihill and Les Johnson. I know that you will appreciate the sincerity of those best wishes.

As a Labor senator you have had to look after duty electorates throughout New South Wales, as we all do. You have been responsible particularly for ALP members in Cook and the Sutherland shire. For quite a few years you were the duty senator for Cook. I know you have a lot of friends and a lot of colleagues in that area who equally would like to be able to speak tonight. Some of them have moved on, like former Senator Arthur Gietzelt and others, but I am sure I speak on their behalf as well in thanking you for the work you did for the party members and for the electorate there.

So, Bruce, to you and to Yola, all the best. I know you will continue your work on behalf of the peace movement, for Amnesty International and on behalf of the Labor Party and working people of this country for many years into the future. Thanks, mate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, can I say to Senator Childs that I apologise for not being here for the start of the valedictory speeches. Unfortunately, I had to go away for an hour or so, but you more than anyone else would understand that in this place you cannot always be where you want to be at any particular time.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very fortunate when I came into this place some 5½ years ago to be appointed to an industry, science and technology commit tee of which Senator Childs was the chairman. I was fortunate also because on that committee was former Senator Brian Archer, whom many of you will remember. I do not know that anybody could have had a better introduction to the committee system—how politics can sometimes work with two sides getting together—than working on a committee with Senator Archer and Senator Childs.

Let me say that right from the very start, when you first come into this place, you think everybody on the other side is the enemy. After you have been here for a while you think they still are, but you have a different view of things. I remember saying to Senator Archer one day, `I don't know whether we ought to be doing this.' He said, `Listen, laddie, don't worry, just sit and listen for a while and you will see how things work out.' In fact, it was a very quick lesson, because I quickly learnt from Senator Childs, the chairman, and Senator Archer, who was his deputy chairman, just how much good can be done by a little bit of cooperative thinking and a bit of cooperative working to try and get a result which they both believed was in the best interests of Australia and of the Senate and what we were all trying to do.

Those early lessons followed on for a long time, because I have continued to work with Senator Childs in the whole 5½ years I have been in this place. I would not want to give away any secrets, but I do remember that after I had been here for a couple of months a friend of mine at home said, `Do you know any Labor guys?' He did not expect that we would mix very much. I said, `Yes, I do. As a matter of fact, even at this early stage there are a couple of them that I prefer to a few of my own.' I would not want you to repeat that anywhere else, and I would not want to identify anyone on this side. But Senator Childs and I, while we have been away, have been able to have some very good discussions and talk about a wide range of topics.

I do not know of many senators on the opposite side of the chamber of whom I can say this, but in all my time here I have never heard on our side a bad word said about Senator Childs. I never heard a bad word said either about his integrity or his trustworthi ness, because he was totally trustworthy in everything we ever did. I remember that soon after I became chairman of the committee and Senator Childs was my deputy, we had one new young Labor senator who I found was being particularly difficult in the writing of a report that we would have liked to have been unanimous at the end of the day. I can still remember Bruce saying to me, `Come up into my office and we will see what we can do.' So he and I went up there and he said, `Let's sit down and talk about all the things we agree about first.' So we sat down and talked about all the things we agreed about in 10 chapters, and there was only one chapter where there was any disagreement at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the conclusions.

—No, it wasn't the conclusions. It was right in the middle, actually. He said, `There is one thing I can't agree with because the government wouldn't agree with me saying those sorts of things.' I said, `That isn't actually what I want,' and he said, `In that case we won't have a problem,' and so we came up with the unanimous report that was approved the next day. That was the way that Bruce Childs worked. He always stood up for exactly what he believed in and he never gave an inch, but he was prepared in the end to come up with a decision which was in the interests of everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: So, Senator Childs, I think what we will miss in this place with your going is the information that you can pass on to newer senators as they come into this place. Your long service in this place means you have an understanding of the institution itself and the procedures and the way things ought to be done. In recent times there has been a large turnover of senators in this place. I have been here for just over five years and there have been 42 new senators in the five years that I have been here, and the sort of knowledge that was in this place for so long and the rapid changeover of senators means that sometimes new senators do things that they would not do if they knew what the procedure really was. I think it takes older senators, and particularly senators like Senator Childs, to pass on that information so that people can actually learn as they are coming through this place the way things ought to be done.

I particularly remember in the last couple of years, while I was chairman and you were on that committee, Bruce, the difficult times you went through with the illness of your second wife, and the way that I had nothing but admiration for the way you continued with your work. You hardly ever missed a meeting. We always worked things so that, if possible, you could be there. You always did the same thing. I thought your dedication to your job and the way you handled yourself were just amazing.
I really wanted to place on record the fact that I have appreciated working with you. I certainly wish you well, and I hope that you and your wife have a long and happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I have known Bruce for a long time through the Left of the Labor Party, which we are both members of, and in which we have both worked for a long time—Bruce a lot longer than I have. Bruce and I have been at many meetings, conventions and seminars together in relation to both the party and the Left. I am very proud to know Bruce.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first came in here I was asked whom I would like to sit next to. I knew most of the people up here already. I have never told Bruce this but I said, `I'd like to sit next to Bruce Childs.' It is true. The reason I said that was that I had known Bruce for a long time—many years. I knew he was an honest broker and had years and years of experience. I knew that there was a lot I could learn from Bruce. And, also, frankly, I liked him. Since I have been here I have got to know and like Bruce a lot more.

I will let you in on a little secret. I do not know if this is very well known, but Bruce is very interested in Freud. Many a time when we were sitting up there Bruce would analyse you people on the other side. It was a fairly interesting perspective. Bruce's knowledge of psychiatry is far more detailed than mine.

I am very proud to have known you, Bruce, and I am still proud to know you. I am proud to have worked with you here and I enjoyed our discussions. I enjoyed your sagacity and your advice. You are to me a true comrade, and have been all your life and always will be. I will miss you very much here, and I think you will be sadly missed by all of us. You bring a measuring force into what is a volatile atmosphere—I am not talking about the Senate here. We all genuinely wish you well. I am also very pleased to hear about your recent wedding, which was a pretty well kept secret. I wish you all the best. It has been a great privilege to work with you and a great privilege to have known you in this place. All the best, comrade. I hope things go well for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me to join in this valedictory tribute to Bruce Childs.
—Just say `comrade' once; go on.

—If Senator Collins insists, we will have to address him as Comrade Childs. I first became aware of Bruce Childs when he came to the Senate in 1981 after the 1980 election when I was serving the latter years of my period in the House of Representatives. Bruce was still here when I returned to this place as a senator in 1987. The thing that struck me about Bruce was his quiet and gentlemanly demeanour, particularly in this chamber, which was in marked contrast to the usual firebrand attitude that we expect to see from Labor's left wing. I notice Senator Carr sitting over there in the front row. He is an exemplary example of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from observing that, as I say, gentlemanly nature, I really did not get to know Bruce all that well until we served together on what was the Senate industry committee. That was a result of an amalgamation in early 1993 of the previous Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, on which I had served, and the industry committee. Ever since that time I have served with Bruce on that committee and its successor the Senate Economics Committee. It did not take long after joining that committee to realise how knowledgeable Bruce was on the range of matters that came within the bailiwick of that committee's responsibility.

He certainly was a member of the left wing of the Labor Party, but in pursuing the work of that committee, without leaving his basic underlying philosophy behind he certainly left party politics behind. He tested evidence that was brought to the attention of that committee in its various inquiries very strongly. He obviously tested it on the basis of his philosophical beliefs, but, as I said, he left party politics behind. The conclusions which Bruce reached in those committees were always based solidly on the evidence that had been put before the committee. He then worked with his quiet persuasion to persuade other members of the committee to similarly accept those conclusions.

In doing that, as Senator Ferguson has already mentioned, Bruce always worked very hard to maximise the possibility of achieving unanimity in committee reports. He did that not simply for the sake of achieving unanimity but because it revealed the measure of Bruce's political wisdom—dare I say perhaps a bit of political cunning—in that he clearly understood that the way to maximise the chances of having the recommendations of a Senate committee accepted and implemented by a government, whether of our persuasion or of his own, was to have the recommendations and the findings of that committee unanimous. He also recognised, on the other side of the coin, that if there was disagreement among a committee then there was very little likelihood of the committee's recommendations being accepted.

Of course, I did observe on committee trips occasional exceptions to this quiet demeanour and non‐partisanship. I well remember last year—I think it was in Brisbane—during the hearings that the committee was conducting on the proposed industrial relations legislation of this government, when Bruce took leave of the committee for a while and disappeared from the hearings. The hearings were being held in a hotel conference room and, as it happened, I had occasion to leave the conference room to go in search of a telephone to make some calls during the hearings. I wandered out into the street downstairs to see, lo and behold, Bruce there with a megaphone to his mouth, haranguing a crowd of trade unionists for all he was worth. So the quiet demeanour we saw of Bruce in the committees did not always hold true. Nevertheless, Bruce returned a little later to the work of the committee and was certainly subjected to a bit of chiacking for the activities in which he had been involved during his absence.

When we were on those committee trips interstate, Bruce was good company after hours, over dinner or elsewhere, as Alan has already said, discussing a range of issues and personal matters. So I will certainly miss his contribution to that committee work and the association that I have had with him through the work of what is now the Senate Economics References Committee. I wish him and his new wife a long, interesting and very happy retirement and an enjoyable one together. His successor will certainly have big shoes to fill. He will find it very difficult to fill the shoes that Bruce Childs leaves behind in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up on a point made by Senator Chapman earlier because last year, when I was a new senator, Bruce Childs showed me just how supportive and what a good comrade he is. His guidance in my early days in this place was absolutely critical in my coping with the pressures of the new job. Bruce, I would like to take this opportunity to thank you very sincerely for that support.

SPEECH.PARA: That support has continued, of course. I have been here for only 18 months, so I do not share the length of association with Bruce that many in this chamber do, but I heard about Bruce Childs many years ago when, as a young union activist working on building sites in Canberra, I and my colleagues knew of Bruce Childs the legend. We knew him as someone who kept in touch with the rank and file of unions through the branch structures and who would let us know what was going on in federal parliament from Labor's point of view. Bruce, I remember our local branch receiving correspondence from you on matters at that time as part of your strategy to keep rank and file members of unions informed of what was going on in this place.

I wanted to mention that because it shows that, in his capacity as a senator, Bruce has always got part of his mind turned to the working people out there on the ground. Part of his mind is always attuned to the needs of those people, and that is one of the great strengths of Bruce and of his views and of his contribution to this place. If I am able to follow that lead in any way, it will put me in great stead to perform my duties as a senator in the best way possible.

The practical guidance in this place that I spoke of earlier goes far beyond just being good at what he did. It is Bruce's methodology in making a difference in the broadest political sense that has made him, in my view, a person of such substance. It is one thing to have a strong ideology and to have commitment; it is another thing to be able to put in place a working strategy so as to have those views expressed and fulfilled through the work that you do in your capacity as a senator. Bruce was able to achieve that. We have already heard the references to his work on committees—in developing committee reports that had strength through unanimous recommendations, and in the depth that Bruce's contribution has added. But ideology without the skills to progress those views is not complete and, Bruce, you complete the full circle in effectiveness. I do learn from you.

The other thing I want to say about Bruce—and this is touching on an area where I only know of his past deeds through legend and, as I say, through the anecdotal evidence that I have certainly heard not only over the last few days but also over the last 18 months—is that I do not think that the depth and substance of his contribution can be fully appreciated unless one has an appreciation of the history of the labour movement in this country. It is those stories and anecdotes that have helped build the character of Bruce Childs in my mind. Whilst we have people like him as part of the Senate, it will always be a stronger and better place. Bruce, in losing you, the whole Australian Senate is losing something extremely significant. We will all miss you very much, and from me personally: thank you, comrade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself with the comments made tonight in the valedictory for Senator Bruce Childs. I suppose each of us addresses this matter from the way that we have come to know Bruce during our time in the Senate. In my case, it has been on the Privileges Committee over the last four years, and during that time I believe the committee has done a lot of good work for the Senate and I think that has been largely due to the contribution made by Bruce.

SPEECH.PARA: I joined that committee as a new senator, and I learnt greatly from Bruce's experience. I think Senator Lundy's description of his methodology is a very good one and one that I would certainly endorse. Sometimes you can advance your cause in this place much more by logic, methodology and force of argument than by bluster, and that is where Bruce has been formidable. I want to pay tribute to the way that he has advanced his views. Where he comes from on the political spectrum is not a place where I find myself, but, nonetheless, I respect the views that he has expressed in this chamber. During the time that I have been here, he has expressed them with conviction and force while, at the same time, being able to understand the other side of the argument.

I want to pay tribute to Bruce as a person who has served not only his party well but also the Senate well. I think both of those are extremely important attributes for a Senator to have. After all, the party system is an essential part of Australian democracy.

So I say: Bruce, thank you for your cooperation, your contribution, your counsel, which I have found to be very substantial, and your wisdom in relation to matters on the Privileges Committee. It has been a pleasure working with you. I learned only today that you were newly married. I congratulate you on that and wish you and your new wife a very happy time in your future life after this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some sympathy for Bruce. I will not keep the poor bugger any longer than he needs to. You have had to endure a lot here tonight, as, indeed, you have had to endure a lot over the years that you have served the people, the trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party in this place. You have done all of them proud in your contribution, and recognition of that has been made by previous speakers. I will not dwell any further on that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will draw attention to the disservice you do us by leaving this place, because you age each and every one of us. As I look around this place at the senators assembled here, there is only one in this place who has served longer than I have after you have gone. While Senator O'Brien talked about himself being a junior senator, next time we assemble he will not be quite so junior because there will be somebody who will have served a shorter time than him. So you are doing us a disservice and ageing us in the process.

The other disservice you are doing me particularly is that by you moving out and getting replaced I will lose my uniqueness of being the only Irish-born senator, or the only Irish-born member of the Australian parliament. Your successor will actually share that honour with me. I suppose that will be a magnificent achievement for the Australian parliament to have two of us; the representation will have increased by 100 per cent. Again, another disservice, but perhaps in an around about sort of way it is a real service.

I have worked with you for many years—before I came into this parliament—as an activist within the trade union movement and within the Labor Party from the distance of Perth and from Western Australia. You assisted enormously with advice in those early days when we were trying to build up the faction, trying to counter some of the things that were happening within our party.

The early years were perhaps very difficult because we were not in government, and we certainly did not have the numerical strength within the party to exert a huge influence. However, on reflection—as one does; as one ages, one reflects—I think the most difficult years we had were when we were at the pinnacle of our power. This was the period between 1990 and 1993 when you and I had the glorious honour of being conveners for the parliamentary wing of the Labor Party. They were very turbulent years—in particular, 1991 when the party was tearing itself apart.

I reflect, too, on my performance in that and on my leadership role. Perhaps there were times when I should have more readily taken your advice, been a bit cooler and had a longer fuse or waited before I put the match to the fuse. You and I did not always agree, not so much on the individuals who were involved in the tussle, but on the methodology during those difficult times.

I thank you for your comradeship during those times. Even though we did not agree on each and every thing, we were still able to discuss things with each other—as we were able to do with the rest of the comrades and other factions of the parliamentary party at the time.

You played a role much broader than the parliamentary left wing of the party at that time. That should be properly recognised some time in the future. Perhaps if you do get around to writing your memoirs you can correct some of the records that have been kept to date.

I have had the pleasure of serving on a couple of committees with you—none the least of which was the old Industry Committee—where I learned a tremendous amount from you on how committees should operate and how you should relate to your colleagues on those committees. Colleagues from all sides of the chamber have paid tribute to you on that. I add my thanks to you for your assistance there.

But it is not so much what happened during the committee work that sticks in my mind. One night the committee was in Adelaide for, I think, one day of hearings and a day of inspections. We had to go and have a meal. We enjoyed our meal and were walking back to the hotel when we witnessed an altercation where some individual had been apprehended by the police. They were trying to put him into a police van.

BREAK.PARA: Bruce said, `Let's just stay here and see that this individual is treated properly. He deserves to be treated properly.' I think there were three, possibly four, police trying to get this one individual into the van. Bruce had a concern for the individual. I think I might have been happier had we kept on walking and gone to the next pub up the road. But he had a concern for the individual, who was clearly outnumbered.

When the police saw this gathering of individuals—and there was another senator with us, I think it was Bryant Burns, but I might be wrong—watching their law enforcement methods, they did not like it very much. They asked us about what we were doing. They actually suggested to us that we ought to move along or we might be invited to enter the van with the individual they were putting in.

Bruce pulled his card out of his wallet, gave it to him and told him that he was a member of the Australian parliament and just going about his lawful business. The individual did not get bashed up—at least, he did not get bashed up in front of us. But that little incident stayed with me. The work of Bruce Childs the man is much more than what we have seen in the parliament, much more than what we have seen in his parliamentary committees and much more than what we have seen within the Australian Labor Party or, before that, in the union movement.

You are leaving the parliament tonight, but you are not leaving political life; you are not leaving active life. You will be continuing with the Evatt Foundation. Undoubtedly, you will, as you promised last evening, be making contact with each and every one of us, particularly on this side of the parliament. But I hope that you will not forget those who sit on the other side of the parliament or those who sit in the centre of the parliament in aiding and assisting in that work. It will be good for those in government to have an alternative and different view being put to them.

I join with each of the previous speakers to congratulate you on your recent marriage and to wish you and Yola all the best for the future. I trust that you will have a long and happy life together. You certainly deserve a long and happy life together. Those wishes are extended beyond you and your wife; they are extended to the rest of your family and to those grandchildren that I know you adore. Thank you very much for all you have done for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to be associated with the tributes that are being paid to Bruce tonight. On looking through the whip's seniority list, Bruce, I note that you are No. 7 on the list, which is no mean feat. I note that you were elected at the same time as Dominic Foreman, Robert Hill, Robert Ray and Nick Bolkus. You were elected that particular year in 1980 amongst the people we would call the fathers of the Senate. I am one of those people who have been here for 10 years. I have never had the honour of serving on a committee with you, nor have I been on a delegation anywhere with you.
—That's a wonder; you have been on most.

—All I can say is that, from my knowledge of meeting and working with you, Bruce, I would support all those kind words that have been said about you. I know that when you leave this place you will look back with much pride on your achievements here.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt when we finish tonight I will get another abusive phone call like I did after we had valedictories for Jim Short. Some person rang up and said, `What are you so and sos doing there wasting all your time and taxpayers' money saying things about each other just to make yourselves feel good?' I said, `Look, we are human beings. This is not a circus. If we cannot say something about one of our colleagues, there is something wrong with this world and something wrong with this country.'

Bruce, I would associate myself with what has been said here tonight. I wish you and your wife all the very best for the future. It has been a pleasure to know you. I can say one thing, Madam Deputy President: when he and I worked together as temporary chairmen, he was never late; he was always on time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with the wishes that the Senate is passing on tonight in relation to the retirement from parliamentary life of Bruce Childs. I have known Bruce in relation to his association with Parliamentarians for Global Action, and foreign affairs, defence and trade. But I guess the area which springs to my mind most is in relation to Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapons Free World. In particular, Bruce was very much involved with the trip organised for parliamentarians from Australia to travel to Tahiti in relation to the French nuclear tests. That was an area in which Australia was seen to be leading the world in terms of parliamentary action but also community response in relation to French nuclear tests. It was an interesting team organising that event. There was Bruce, Ian Cowan and Franca Arena. Bruce and Franca have quite different styles.
—Bruce has style.
—Bruce is the quiet achiever and Ian is the action man. Ian used to surf on surfboards in front of nuclear warships, so he ended up on a yacht near the testing area.

SPEECH.PARA: From my point of view, it was extremely important to know that on issues important to me—human rights, nuclear weapons, nuclear testing and proliferation—there are people within the major parties who will always stand up and be heard. It is so important for the community to know that. It is not just Independents or minor parties who are standing up on those issues. We know it has been a very firm part of the Labor platform for a long time, but it is important that there are individuals who will stand up and be counted on those issues.

Bruce, I want you to know that I have always appreciated that from you, along with your quiet strength and willingness to get down and organise those things which need to be organised. I shall miss your presence in the Senate. Good luck for you marriage and your future life. I am sure it will be very busy out of the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —All the words have been said, and I do not want to repeat them. I simply want to associate myself with the words that have been said and to say my parliamentary farewell to a very genuine bloke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —As a fellow senator from New South Wales, I want to take this opportunity to associate myself with all of the words that have been said tonight, Bruce. I first learned about you in the mid-1970s when I joined the Labor Party, albeit in the right wing of the Labor Party from New South Wales—and the battles were fierce. I had the joy of seeing you as a contestant in that situation. I have also had the pleasure of working with you as a friend and a colleague here. To be able to see the difference that takes place and the working together is very good.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing you are known for is your loyalty; your loyalty to your faction and your loyalty to your party. That is something that is very highly appreciated and very much revered by everybody. I know that you are going to enjoy not being here. There is a very special little girl whom we both know, and I do not know how I am going to explain to her that grandfather is now no longer in the red house. I know that you will enjoy the time you spend with your grandchildren. Congratulations to you and Yola. It is wonderful news. May you enjoy many, many years together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I would like to thank all senators for what has been said tonight. I would particularly like to thank Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr and others who helped organise such a long time tonight for a discussion about me. It seems quite wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make sure that I do thank also my staff who are here, and one of them away—Tanya Plibersek, Miriam Williamson, Christine Hawkins—and so many former staffers who have been so important to me. I would also like to make a point of thanking Harry Evans and Anne Lynch, who are not here just at the moment; they have another very important meeting to attend to. But I would particularly like to place on record my long association with, and thanks to, Anne Lynch in working over so many committees on privilege. I have been absolutely impressed with her dedication to that privilege work.

I should thank all the members of the staff, and I will not try to thank all the different departments of the Senate. But I would just like to mention a couple, apart from Hansard, who are so important and who we probably will be holding up at any moment now. I would like to thank a couple of officers from the industry economics committee's process, and Rob Diamond is sitting here at the moment. I have worked so closely with him, and he has worked so well.

Peter Keele is in the same category of having worked in the same area—and I think he is just about to go on an overseas trip, taking parliamentarians to other places—and Peter Hallahan, who has also worked closely with me. I do have to say, because I know we all feel it, it is such an intimate bond, when they do all the hard yakka and finally report results and we as chairs of those committees get usually the credit.

But I think the thing I always feel is that you learn from everyone. It is a great privilege that you learn from your staff, from the secretariat, from your political opponents. I think that is one of the charming things. It is very hard for the press to understand that. They think it has been sort of a bit lovey‐dovey in the last couple of hours. But I illustrate it always by how I have learnt about the farmer's perspective from people like Senator Alan Ferguson, Senator Crane and the late John Panizza; they taught me so much. I hope that I might have taught them something about a trade unionist's perspective as well in the same process.

Of course, when I talk about farmers, Madam Deputy President, I want to make it quite clear that if it were something about rural or regional Australia, and particularly New South Wales, then I would certainly ask you too in checking what they told me. Nevertheless, it is one of the great advantages. It means you do learn so much. It means that a person of average intelligence always looks better when they have had that great experience that we enjoy.

If it sounds as though what I am saying is a bit soft, I looked at my first speech, and I must say that on the fundamentals, the ideological differences that we have, then I have not changed one iota from my first speech and the feelings of where I come from. Nevertheless, it is that contradiction between your basic fundamental beliefs and what you learn in the process that is so broadening and so marvellous, and makes you proud to be a parliamentarian. I have never identified with being a politician, but I really do identify with being a parliamentarian.

I support a strong parliament. That was why it is a bit strange that John Faulkner and others have mentioned the issue of privilege. Why is a leftie so concerned about privileges? Why has the Left of the Labor Party supplied so many people on the Privileges Committee? From my perspective, once I went onto the Privileges Committee, I realised that it is about protecting the committees of the parliament; it is protecting our witnesses, even to the extent finally of the whistleblower—one of the extreme of the people who we need to come before the parliament.

Why I as a leftie support this strong parliament is because you have to have an effective countervailing force to the executive government, because my long experience now with executive government is that there are unintended consequences, there are foul‐ups and muck‐ups all the time. And there are little people being squashed at any point, if we do not have all these democratic procedures to try to protect people with. Whether we are supporting people coming before a committee, or whether we are just giving people the right of reply, which this chamber has pioneered, then we are guaranteeing that we are preventing them from being abused by too much power which sometimes can be in the hands of people in power.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, where I would differ from my colleagues on the other side—although I am sure that some of them would agree with not letting big government get too much power—is that I would go a bit further: I would want to apply the same principles to the private sector. I would like to devolve power in the private sector—and, of course, that would be called a dirty word like `industrial democracy'. But that is a debate for another time, and I will not develop it.

I would just like to thank everybody for the kind words that they have said tonight. I thank them on behalf of my wife Yola, and I do appreciate those words. I thank my trade union mates. All I can do is thank my friends here tonight from every part of the chamber and wish you good health and wisdom in future deliberations of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
